movie_review_blurb: When it was over, I couldn't move. Despite a couple of slow stretches -- and Dylan has them, too -- I'm Not There turns out to be worthy of its subject. This isn't faint praise. It's a full-on rave.

Of the three major documentaries about edible insects presently making the rounds (Bugs on the Menu, Bugs, and The Gateway Bug), Bugs is probably the most ambitious and, without question, the most eloquent of the lot.

A pet project of Watts and Norton for years, the two actors clearly have great affinity for the story and capture authentic chemistry of young marrieds at odds, who develop respect -- if not necessarily love -- for each other.
In the end, the film is a straight-ahead boy-meets-girl story -- half a century too late.
The stately Gong looks fantastic, the regal Chow looks cruelly calculating. Yet lacking the inner spark a richer script would provide, even they blend into the scenery.
If you've ever wanted to see a prehistoric man hurl fire-extinguisher foam in Stiller's face, this could be your only chance.
It's a grand thing to watch these two Academy Award winners, who easily could be back in Oscar contention with this film, have at each other.

It's definitely worth setting aside your urge for lightweight escapism and diving into this heavy, provocative tale, set so closely to our times and so recognizably an extension of our world that it offers an intriguing chance for reflection.
It makes a good case for some all-American free enterprise to come up with an alternative.
movie_title: This Film Is Not Yet Rated (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Like Life Is Beautiful, The Tiger and the Snow incongruously offers sharp laughs and touches of tenderness amid moments of drama and danger.
movie_title: La tigre e la neve (The Tiger and the Snow) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Half Past Dead may be the year's funniest unintentional comedy for its inane plot, repetitive, unimaginative stunts and dreadful dialogue.

The movie strives for a positive message about growing up and embracing the joys of fatherhood, but when the baby's this ugly, you're left wishing the filmmakers had practiced a little cinematic celibacy.
A mishmash with a distinctive but disorderly animation palette whose top-notch voice cast -- including Robert De Niro, Madonna and David Bowie -- gets lost in the muck.
movie_title: Arthur and the Invisibles (Arthur and the Minimoys) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Watching the earnest but under-qualified Ulliel perpetrate Hannibal's initial grisly slayings is like going back in time to hear the screeches of a violin virtuoso's incipient swipes on the strings the first time he picks up the instrument.
An unusually smart, tense and engaging film amid the usual dreck that lands in theaters this time of year.
One of the many mysteries about the number 23 is why Jim Carrey and director Joel Schumacher thought audiences would share their fascination over the mysteries about the number 23.
Wild Hogs has little story and even less characterization to its stereotyped players.
This is not horror. It's sadism.
The movie is sloppily edited, the gags limply staged, the dialogue and jokes stiff and stale. Even the action on the basketball court is unimaginative and boring.
The movie is dead from the outset given the artificiality of the premise about a lonely rich guy who hires the folks living in his boyhood home to be his family for the holidays.
Bland pretty boy Speleers is overshadowed by his dragon and human co-stars, with Irons especially impressive despite some very silly dialogue.
In the end, the film wraps up awfully neatly considering how sloppy and unraveled the characters' lives had been at the height of their conflicts.

Soderbergh, screenwriter Paul Attanasio and their colleagues get much of the mood and atmosphere down, but they fail -- or chose not to try -- to emulate the sense of wily playfulness that made old film-noir characters so rich and engaging.

This is Hollywood's first big-screen attempt at portraying the plight of the tens of thousands of Americans returning from Iraq. They deserve a deeper, more substantive portrait of their transition back to the homefront, and some day, they'll get it.
Fearless is an OK way to say goodbye, but its stagy fight choreography may just leave Li's fans wishing for something more.
movie_title: Jet Li's Fearless (Huo Yuan Jia) (Legend of a Fighter) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Kevin Costner and Ashton Kutcher's The Guardian drags on like a slow boat ride to Anchorage, its standard-issue heroics and flavorless dialogue gone stale long before the movie arrives at the big, valorous finish.

Following Mitchell's delightful 2001 rock musical Hedwig and the Angry Inch, the director's Shortbus is another marvelous mix of very adult, very overt themes and images coupled with a sense of childlike innocence and awe.
Jessica Simpson, Dane Cook, Dax Shepard and colleagues will not be in the running for Hollywood's employee of the month for their new comedy.
Mirren and Sheen present gracious, humane portraits of two people whose conviction over their place in the world is shaken by unprecedented circumstance.
What keeps Man of the Year alive is the homey interplay of its principals.

By film's end, the notion of a rational and satisfying climax has hopelessly disappeared in a silly spiral of one-upmanship and a barrage of half-baked revelations that won't make you marvel so much as shrug and forget about them.
The dull dialogue and predictable action corrals the actors.

Allen looks silly, tired and bored this time in the fat suit and beard, while the movie presents the irritating Martin Short as Jack Frost, nipping at your nerves as Santa's nemesis in a bid to take over and (gasp!) commercialize Christmas.
movie_title: The Santa Clause 3: The Escape Clause (2006)

movie_review_blurb: [A] vibrant film that's pure class, pure imagination and pure Almodovar.
Is it more interesting and entertaining than a straightforward biopic of Arbus would have been? Maybe. Is it more illuminating? Probably not.
movie_title: Fur: An Imaginary Portrait of Diane Arbus (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Unpleasantly grim and often nasty just to be nasty, writer-director David Ayer's Harsh Times is more an ordeal than a movie.
Taking the world's greatest spy back to his roots as a raw, impressionable brute whose cockiness at times fails him and who can lose his heart to a woman was a keen stroke of intelligence.
The gags may be hit and miss in For Your Consideration, but the performances often are comic gems. This gang has worked together so often that they blend together effortlessly.
A comedy sketch, painfully prolonged to movie length.
movie_title: Tenacious D in The Pick of Destiny (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The History Boys feels too much like a filmed play, and filmed not all that gracefully.
Slight and wispy, it's a film that could only work with the gracious presence of someone like Morgan Freeman , who delivers an amiably laid-back performance.

The blood and gore become so extreme that they provoke titters of ridicule, undermining a simple, stirring story of family devotion as a man races from vile captors to return home and rescue his pregnant wife and their son.
How do you defang and declaw caustic standup comic and commentator Lewis Black? Stick him in a PG-rated holiday family movie, then stand back and watch the laughs not pile up.
Packing all the tired trappings of the raunchy road-trip genre, this loutish comedy plays out as a loosely threaded collection of shrill jokes and cliched sight gags.
Someone connected with the psychological thriller Premonition should have been clairvoyant enough to realize that when you don't have a good finale, it doesn't pay to substitute two bad endings.
A quiet powerhouse of a film, an implacable, uncompromising French police drama, both old-fashioned and modern, that underlines the reasons impeccably made crime stories do so well on-screen.
[The film] has enough buoyancy to remain afloat, though without the vigor of Terrence Howard and the charm of Bernie Mac, it likely would sink in its own sea of clichés.
A surprisingly plain, sappy, even insipid comedy, considering the filmmaker behind it.

Cusack and Coleman are on screen together most of the movie, and the fact that they don't completely overstay their welcome amid the maudlin action says a lot for the restraint they bring to the characters.
Much of the movie plays like a civics lesson.
With boundless ambition far exceeding his ability to tell a coherent story, Kelly manages only an artistic apocalypse.
It's stirring, even gut-wrenching, on the strength of John Cusack's terrifically restrained performance as a husband in denial over the death of his wife in Iraq.
As with the first movie, Book of Secrets leaps around like a choppy travel documentary.
Nicholson and Freeman are so lovably companionable, they almost make you forget the glaring contrivances screenwriter Justin Zackham concocts.
The movie might satisfy bloodthirsty action fans, but for most people, this is one Stallone do-over we could have done without.
You can only see so many snarling hissy fits by vampires with perpetually bloody chins before they start looking less like monsters and more like ill-tempered circus clowns whose makeup is running.
Everything about the movie is as clunky and unimaginative as the title.

The Spiderwick Chronicles may not be in the same fantasy league as the tales of J.R.R. Tolkien, C.S. Lewis and J.K. Rowling. Yet the family flick based on the books of Tony DiTerlizzi and Holly Black is an all-around class act.
The assassination thriller Vantage Point might have been a triumph of form over content, technique over substance, if only there were anything worthy about its form or technique.
No offense intended, but a pig snout is very becoming on Christina Ricci.
Horton may hear a Who, but the rest of us may hear a lot of hoopla, and it's not all the charming sort you expect from a benign Seussian world.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Barbershop is a cozy place to hang out for a while, even if you don't need a little off the sides.
Lack of originality is where 21 really deals a losing hand.
The film leaves you longing for a few Hail Mary end-zone passes, while the filmmakers stick to a story that tries to pound it out with a safe, tedious ground game.
The film leaves you longing for a few Hail Mary end-zone passes, while the filmmakers stick to a story that tries to pound it out with a safe, tedious ground game.
Truth be told, everyone and everything about Welcome Home Roscoe Jenkins is pretty unlikable.
Like The Yards, We Own the Night is broody to the point of anesthesia and operatic to the verge of bombast. And like its predecessor, the new film takes itself far too seriously.

Peter and Bobby Farrelly's take on the 1972 Neil Simon-Elaine May original is not nearly as funny as you'd like for a movie that reunites them with There's Something About Mary star Ben Stiller in another gross-out romance.
The stories are sketches, often without resolution, and while individual segments succeed admirably, taken together the portraits are a fitful match.

[There's] enough funny material for a great little Saturday Night Live sketch. The trouble is, there's an extra 80 minutes or so of down time in which Ferrell, Heder and their co-stars are pretty much repeating their characters' shallow schtick.
The film is a timely reminder that even the savviest and most skeptical audience can get snookered by the natural desire for a great story.

Part of the filmmakers' point is that any old nutcase might be lurking behind the drawn curtains of the house next to you in just such an anonymous locale. Still makes for a mighty limiting, boring place to set a movie, though.

What you get from Hot Fuzz is what you rarely see from Hollywood: Something genuinely smart and silly at the same time, a film and filmmakers that respect their characters, their audience and the genre at which they lovingly poke fun.
Unfortunately, after setting up this fresh blue-collar scenario in the movie's first hour, Del Toro wallows in pyrotechnics.
The paranormal thriller Next shows how a solid crew of filmmakers and performers can apply a big-studio budget to a good story idea and still have absolutely everything come out wrong.
Lucky You is a curiously ordinary and uninvolving tale from the filmmaker behind such insightful character pieces as Wonder Boys and L.A. Confidential.
We've heard that before. And we've seen it all before, as this woeful sequel presents a strained story and a barrage of turgid action that looks like inferior outtakes from the first movie.
There are a couple of genuinely funny sight gags, but most of the roadside attractions of Wild Hogs are either boring or outright annoying.
When your best character is a serial killer's imaginary friend, you know your movie's in trouble.

Ocean's Thirteen still feels like one trip too many to the craps table, playing the same hunches, with the outcome unimaginatively clear from the start: Categorical victory for the rascally good guys, utter defeat and humiliation for the villain.
Amid all the vapid dialogue and visual fireworks, the performances seem like afterthoughts, particularly those of Gruffudd and Alba.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: 1408 generally survives and thrives on the strength of John Cusack's passionate performance as a skeptic of the supernatural who learns that spooks may be real, plus a spirited supporting role by Samuel L. Jackson and some effective chills.
For a pure summer power trip, it's a decent throwback to the pure-brawn heyday of Willis and Arnold Schwarzenegger, an agreeable respite from today's cartoonlike ballets of computer-generated action.
Familiarity is not quite breeding contempt for Harry and his friends and enemies. But it's starting to breed indifference.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The action sequences are so turgid it's sometimes hard to tell which 'bot is doing what, but with Bay steadily hurling fireworks you won't really pause much to think about that, or about how truly inane the story is.

The early intensity of Sunshine wanes in the third act. The film becomes a ferocious jumble, and rather than a supernova finish, it winks out amid stale New Age notions of the continuity of life and connectedness of all things.
While Mr. Bean's Holiday is hardly a memorable vacation, Atkinson proves an agreeably silly tour guide.

It's certainly a goodhearted story, and the movie does offer a little plot twist that deviates from the usual formula. After that, though, The Game Plan quickly reverts to the established playbook for safe, sappy family fare.
Michel Gondry makes more interesting films when he's chasing through screenwriter Charlie Kaufman's playful thoughts than his own.

This fictionalized tale of two Los Angeles detectives assigned to the gruesome 1940s murder of a real-life wannabe starlet begins as a slow but intriguing character study that gradually unravels into a turgid mess.
... Sherrybaby is not so much a film as a performance, and it's a great one from Gyllenhaal.
Beerfest unfolds like a decent college kegger, the best moments coming late in the carousal, as more suds are quaffed, inhibitions loosen up and everything starts seeming funnier.
In reality, you take the highs with the lows because there's no other option, but that mix makes for a fitful, fidgety movie experience.
A heartbreaking counterpoint to big war spectacles, beautifully performed by Christina Ricci, Cate Blanchett, Johnny Depp and John Turturro.
If you want social commentary but absorbing entertainment, gritty realism but fictionalized whimsy, something for the head but something for the heart, too, Bread and Roses delivers.
Beautifully shot and lyrically told, Simon Magus is a beguiling study in contrasts, good and evil, darkness and light, hope and despair, joy and melancholy.
Swordfish drowns in cliche, implausibility and cryptic little mysteries and misdirections that viewers are supposed to accept as intricate and edgy storytelling.
Beresford (Driving Miss Daisy) allows Bride of the Wind to spend too much time spelling out the film's passions in words rather than letting the players show them.
The verdict on the big-screen Lara Croft: Angelina Jolie, hot. Tomb Raider, not.
The Closet will not appeal to all moviegoers, but it will find a niche audience of viewers hungry for brisk, smart comedies.
A sweet, sumptuous sonnet to film and its universal lure.
Kiss of the Dragon has little of the balletic grace of better martial-arts flicks and none of the thoughtful restraint of these forms of combat.
Got class and smarts that put recent bombastic heist flicks such as Swordfish and 3000 Miles to Graceland to shame.
The movie is one to savor for its good humor and big heart, despite some hackneyed fairy-tale notions.
Yet another lesson to Hollywood that a fright film need not be awash in blood and elaborate special effects.
Insomniacs take heart: The soothing sounds of Captain Corelli's Mandolin are an invitation to snooze away a couple of hours.
Hardball is a two-hankie sports soap opera, but don't hold that against it. With surprising melodrama, the film packs some powerful emotional swings that will hearten the toughest of jeering crowds.

As a writer, Khouri knows how to craft believably contentious women and fire off witty one-liners. She's far less handy at translating the characters and dialogue to the screen, generally miring her elderly foursome in comic or melodramatic histrionics.
movie_title: Divine Secrets of the Ya-Ya Sisterhood (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.

Koppelman and Levien manage nice camaraderie among their young thugs, but most of the characters are too bland, repugnant or dunderheaded -- in some cases, all three -- for viewers to invest much emotional interest.
Deruddere seems intent on indicting the television culture for promoting unrealistic hopes of stardom, but the film ultimately embraces the medium as a means of self-fulfillment.
A satisfying blend of action, intrigue, snappy dialogue and dark humor.
Brendan and Trudy and company deliver a grand good time.
A captivating, sharp-tongued, very funny romp.
A decent action romp.
Ends up a sloppy exercise in irritating audiences instead of the sharp satire the story line promises.
Maybe Kenneth Branagh should have left the Hollywood musical where he found it, back in the 1930s.
X-men is fitfully satisfying.
Roberts has never been better as she glares and swears her way through the movie.

There's plenty of surface action -- lion, buffalo and snake attacks, elephants slain for their ivory, highway robbery, a vicious windstorm. But the action plays out tiresomely, one nasty turn piled on another, compounding the movie's gloominess.
The Flintstones in Viva Rock Vegas is cute and funny, with plenty of slapstick and cuddly creatures for the kids and enough adult wit to keep parents reasonably amused.
movie_title: The Flintstones in Viva Rock Vegas (2000)

movie_review_blurb: The intriguing idea of The Kid is squandered with a simple-minded story line that never meaningfully scratches the surface of questions most people ask themselves.
A slight but entertaining update.
Worthwhile for the performances.
The film builds an implausible scenario into a credible and utterly charming romantic comedy.
A caustic, raunchy, often hilarious examination of how men use women, and how easy it is for a determined female to do the same to a passel of self-centered males.
When the characters just shut up and dangle, Vertical Limit becomes one heck of a wild time.
One of the year's smartest and funniest films.
The comedy inherent in toupee gags gradually runs dry, and the interplay between the main characters sometimes doesn't offer enough sparks to pick up the slack.
A bright and original homage to pre-talkie days.
Begins with an engaging setup but gradually lapses into a messy web of cloak-and-dagger contrivance, implausible action, silly plot twists and dumb dialogue.
Save the Last Dance squanders nice performances by Julia Stiles and Sean Patrick Thomas by confining them and the supporting cast to cookie-cutter roles and hackneyed inner-city subplots.
Works oh-so-hard to make everyone in it oh-so-likable that at times the audience is going to feel oh-so-nauseated.
A ticket to tedium, a horror movie so devoid of horror that mouths will open wide in yawns, without a scream to be heard.

A stronger word than preposterous is needed to describe the, well, preposterous lengths director Jon Avnet and company go to engorge this movie with idiotic action, incomprehensible twists and loads of other nonsense.
Chamber of Secrets is fairly fun despite its length.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Beneath its glossy surface, this unabashedly feel-good movie is full of substance.

The trio of youths at the heart of first-time screenwriter Anthony S. Cipriano's script do shocking, outrageous things, events seemingly arising not so much from genuine character motivations as from desire for the film to shock and be outrageous.
It's a suitable companion piece to past Altman forays into the arts such as Nashville and The Player, though lightweight by comparison.
The thin story and thinner characters are just setups for the race sequences, which are punctuated by lavish parties where lithe women seem to outnumber the guys by a 5-to-1 ratio.
movie_title: The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Thorough it's not, but the concert documentary Leonard Cohen: I'm Your Man gathers solid interviews, anecdotes, recitations and tribute performances that present a fairly engaging portrait of the wry, dark poet who became a distinct voice.
The result is an Adam Sandler movie that works -- to a degree -- for just about everyone.
A light, breezy documentary that introduces us to a genial gang of crossword puzzle fans whose passion for the pastime is gleefully infectious.
Garcia needed better guiding hands and eyes in the editing room to jettison the many parts that bog down the story.
It's a lively, informative whodunit about an energy-efficient vehicle that debuted with fanfare and died with a whimper.
The sometimes dreamy pace of Peaceful Warrior is offset by good rapport among Nolte, co-star Scott Mechlowicz and an engaging ensemble cast.
You have to suffer through a lot of down time in The Groomsmen to get to the good stuff.
This comedy is so unfunny, it's like director Ivan Reitman and company had their senses of humor tranquilized from guzzling kryptonite lattes.
Though the movie strays deep and often into saccharine country, the filmmakers treat the characters with more respect than teen protagonists normally get in Hollywood.

Pepe, Fulton and screenwriter Tony Grisoni, who had worked on Gilliam's Quixote picture, inject great detail into the Howes' story, yet the siblings feel distant and disconnected, a couple of ciphers you never really get to know.
The movie's thrill-and-chill sequences are nasty and suspenseful, though once the creatures start to attack, the scenes get repetitive.
Burger crafts a movie with a sumptuous visual palette but little heart, the characters detached and cold-blooded.

For all the promise of a cast led by Julianne Moore and David Duchovny in an urbane, adult chronicle of love and marriage, the movie just strings viewers along through phony contrivance, like any other romantic comedy.
Bukowski deserves better than this dismal, wearisome adaptation of his novel, and so do Bukowski's fans. Director Bent Hamer's movie is ugly, depressing and persistently off-putting.
How to Eat Fried Worms is a lot tastier than its title implies.

The premise -- a mystical water nymph living under the swimming pool of a drab apartment complex -- is intriguing, yet the mythology Shyamalan builds around his main characters is forced, pretentious and outright silly at times.
The action is so relentless that even hard-core martial-arts fans might need to pause for breath. And much of it is so repetitive that the film occasionally plays like a rerun of itself.
There's plenty of fat to cut from Goal!, which would have been a stronger story at a lean, mean 90 minutes.
movie_title: Goal! The Dream Begins (Goal!: The Impossible Dream) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The Proposition is no bloodier than many a schlocky horror flick, but the violence feels real and ruthless, carrying a much more visceral impact.
Quote not available.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle (2004)

...this soccer tale is about as exciting to watch as a scoreless match between opponents so defense-minded the ball never gets beyond midfield.
An intriguing little action thriller, a half-and-half story divided between sequences of vicious violence and quiet, wryly comic scenes of newfound domesticity.
The Shaggy Dog is a well-dispositioned but forgettable mutt without any new tricks.
An elegantly crafted drama that derives its eerie, ethereal mood as much from the sounds of war -- and their absence -- as the sights of combat.
V for Vendetta lands somewhere between the neo-noir freshness of the original The Matrix and the indecipherable bombast of the two sequels.
Director James Gunn has infused Slither with a wicked sense of parody while still crafting a clever, maniacally paced twist on B-movie slimefests.
The movie is right on par with the 2002 original: brisk, pleasant and loaded with slapstick that should keep young children giggling.
It has heart and soul (and sole). What Kinky Boots lacks is kick.
A thoughtful, thoroughly engaging portrait of fractured family and friends pulling together for an impossible dream.

Robin Williams' latest Hollywood vehicle has its own kitchen, sleeping quarters, luggage compartments and toilet, where the studio should have flushed the script the minute it crawled through the door.
Trying to be lighthearted, it turns lightweight and bland.

The impassioned performances make you care what happens to these people, even when the film's noisy overindulgence makes you almost wish their home would collapse on itself like The Fall of the House of Usher.
Maybe Kenneth Branagh should have left the Hollywood musical where he found it, back in the 1930s.
They're such lovable goofs that you can't help wishing their quest for White Castle fast food and their flight from Gitmo could live up to the sort of sharp satire these two bright boys deserve.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Despite occasional moments of inspiration, Freedom Writers simplistically focuses on maudlin highlights and glosses over the obstacles to rallying a dangerously disparate group of youths more accustomed to loathe than trust one another.
Myers wants us all to love him, wants us all to be in on his jokes. But love and laughs are earned, not given just because you mug for the camera behind a wild wig and beard.
"What's Your Number?" sticks to the low common denominators of most Hollywood romances, and it ends up a commonplace one for doing so.

It's hard to buy into the notion that fans could ever be as rabid to watch a couple of machines tear each other apart as they are to see two men sweating and straining and bleeding on the canvas. Without human consequence, where's the drama?
Sticks to the formula of the original while adding enough variety to give it a life of its own.
In her directing debut, Aardman veteran Sarah Smith and her co-writer Peter Baynham offer a fresh look at the Santa legend: a flawed Claus.
"The Muppets'' marks a very welcome return for Kermit the Frog, Miss Piggy and the rest of Jim Henson's creations after a 12-year big-screen absence.
"The Sitter" really fails in the physical comedy department with an assault of mean, humorless sight gags.
Craig is an anchor of cool rationality and judiciousness around which Mara revolves like a demon.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Whatever the movie's shortcomings, director Bird more than compensates with a bullet train of action and an arsenal of cool gadgets. Maybe making cartoons has expanded his conception of what's possible in a live film.
The tension del Toro and Nixey create promises much more than it delivers.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A cloying exercise in sentimentality, the film also winds up extremely annoying, even infuriating.
The presence of actors as good as Caine and Guzman only highlights how dreadful and dumb the banter is.
A marvel of image and color, its old-fashioned pen-and-ink frames vividly bringing to life the world of children's author Mary Norton's "The Borrowers."
A Thousand Words is not worth any more dismissive words. It needs to make like a tree and leave.
This is not a property requiring respect and devotion to the source material to satisfy longtime fans, so the filmmakers wisely make a "21 Jump Street" all their own.
"Safe" is the worst Jason Statham movie since the last Jason Statham movie, carrying on the bargain-budget action star's tradition of building a body of work out of, well, dead bodies.
It's just a bore; quoth the raven, "Go see something else."
Dancy, Jones and Pryce are dull, while Gyllenhaal plays the spitfire with far too much spit, thumping the other characters and the audience over the head with her do-gooder crusading.
The animation is grand, and the lovely images may be enough to send really young kids away happy. Their parents might leave feeling they've been taken in by some carny sleight-of-hand, though.
The question that needs to be asked about Madonna's "W.E." is why?
Stone, Davis and Spencer forge something quite beautiful, a sense of sisterhood and equality that unfolds with ease and grace, never feeling forced or untrue to their era and circumstances.
"The Whistleblower" is a one-note affair that offers glimpses of the rich, broad life Bolkovac clearly lives but deifies her into someone inaccessible and unbelievable.
Favreau slipped from fresh and flamboyant on "Iron Man" to lame and listless on its sequel, and there's more of the latter on "Cowboys & Aliens."
Hop has one of the cutest bunnies you'll ever see and plenty of other eye candy among its computer-generated visuals, yet there's not much bounce to the story behind this interspecies buddy comedy.

In a Better World demonstrates Danish director Susanne Biers' supreme gift at telling the gloomiest of stories that, while not exactly winding up in feel-good territory, at least finish with a strong affirmation of the decent things in life.

Co-writer McBride and his collaborators apparently set out on a quest to ram as much coarse language and as many adolescent sexual gags into a movie as possible, maybe to cover the fact that the movie doesn't contain much else.
Despite Mirren's estimable presence, the new Arthur has little of its own to offer. It's the same story, told with much less heart.

Honestly, it's not an unwelcome thing to watch the return of Neve Campbell as the slasher victim who wouldn't die, Courtney Cox as the tabloid hack in bloodlust for a story and David Arquette as the bumbling Barney Fife of fright-flick cops.
Witherspoon and Pattinson are a three-ring snooze-fest together, bringing little passion to a love story supposedly so fiery, it blows the roof off the big top.
Pretty cars, prettier women, insanely absurd action that truly thrills even as it shatters all physical laws, and enough testosterone-fueled violence to satisfy the most-rabid WWE SmackDown crowd.
The Norse gods are off to a decent, though not divine, start in Thor, the latest movie in Marvel Comics' big-screen expansion of its superhero pantheon.
Woody Allen has found the right time and the right place with "Midnight in Paris," his lightest, funniest and most-satisfying movie in a long time.
With The Beaver, Gibson shows that for all his personal turmoil, he still may have a career in the twilight years.

The result is one of the best Marvel adaptations, packed with action, humor, retro 1960s style that's both campy and sexy and a revisionist history lesson that puts the X-Men at the center of the Cuban missile crisis.
With Submarine, it's what lies beneath that counts, and it's a grand voyage tagging along with Oliver as he finds them out.
Coogan and Brydon, building their performances largely through improvisation, have such rapport that it's easy to digest their brand of affectionate chatter laced with mildly mean-spirited ribbing.
The players are not so much teens as miniature adults, dissecting their own natures with insightfulness that typically comes through decades of reflection, if it comes at all.
A fairly satisfying though by-the-numbers drama about an illegal Mexican immigrant struggling to build a decent future for his teenage son.
It's a thin line between the idiotically incomprehensible Revenge of the Fallen and the merely incomprehensible of Dark of the Moon.

James hurls himself into this sad scenario with energy and teddy-bear charm that makes him impossible to hate. But it's easy to hate "Zookeeper." If we could talk to the animals, they'd probably hate it, too.
The trouble is that the modern story whipped up for "Snow Flower" isn't very compelling. Yet it dominates the movie, continually oozing back in just as the period drama is getting interesting.
movie_title: Snow Flower And The Secret Fan (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Cooper has done such a good job bringing Uday to life, it's a bit of a trial simply sitting in the audience and watching.
"Lola Versus" deals with relationships in standard-issue Sundance style, ostensibly smarter and more genuine than what flows from the Hollywood rom-com pipeline yet really just as shallow at heart.
In short, we get Sandler, doing what he always does, with whatever edge he once had continuing to erode as he ages and looks sillier at what he's doing.

It's not Nero who's fiddling, but Allen, bopping and dithering around the city like a tourist so desperate to cram in all the sights that he comes away only with a few crisp highlights and a lot of out-of-focus snapshots.
Fantastic though the story may be, the people in it need to make it feel real, and no one in "Timothy Green" has any claim to authenticity.
movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Masterfully paced, the movie builds slowly, introducing the mythology, habitats and lifestyles of Tolkien's creatures.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)

movie_review_blurb: With The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King, Peter Jackson delivers a decent ending to his fantasy trilogy -- actually, about 12 endings.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A strange delight awash in visual splendor, understated humor and clever body-and-soul transmogrifications among its bonny band of weirdos.
Part two is more a straight-ahead action flick, substituting brawn and brawling for the pastoral radiance of the first film.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

movie_review_blurb: People in Hollywood should never work with children or animals, W.C. Fields once said. Maybe that should be expanded to hyper-realistic computer-generated children and reindeer, too.
While the situations sometimes feel forced, Anderson has mounted an elegant production, beautifully filmed and accentuated by pleasant narration from Alec Baldwin and classy storybook transitions.

Morris ultimately lasted two partial seasons in the majors, and the film's rendering of his minor-league struggle is so enjoyable you want to see more of that and less of the everyday life preceding it.

For all the 118 actors listed, the movie offers almost no sense of authentic humanity. The faces the filmmakers plaster on their characters are as flat and stereotyped as those on war-recruitment posters.
Producer Bruckheimer and director Bay have sunk to a new low for irresponsible, inhuman violence, dragging Will Smith and Martin Lawrence along for a ghastly, deafening display of bloodshed.
How such a cruelly empty and infantile movie got made is mystery enough. More puzzling is why Cary Elwes, Danny Glover and Monica Potter would sign on as co-stars.
Blade II is a better vampire movie than recent entries such as Queen of the Damned or Dracula 2000. That said, Wesley Snipes' return as slayer of the undead still is fairly anemic.
Performances are solid throughout, with the actors managing to straight-face their way through some truly inane dialogue.
Sleepover objectifies early teenage girls in a manner that's disagreeable and indelicate at best, cheap and vulgar at worst.
High hopes, flat results.
The movie has plenty going for it: a terrific cast led by Joan Allen, Jeff Bridges and Gary Oldman, a captivating story line, a sharp script. Most important, The Contender has timing.
Like the failed humor, the sight gags aren't so much bad taste as merely bad.
Chuck & Buck is a dark misfit of a movie that's sweet, scary, thought-provoking and off-putting all in one package. It's a bold, original achievement.

While the movie continually teeters on the brink of abject corniness, it never quite topples off. And it doesn't hurt to have Robert De Niro, Rene Russo and Jason Alexander camping it up as cartoon villains come to life.

The story line of Hannibal is far less interesting than Silence of the Lambs and lacks the emotional subtlety of its predecessor. However, Hannibal is visually and aurally sumptuous, powered by Hans Zimmer's lovely score and brimming with flashy imagery.
The highlight is Pacino, who gives his best performance in years.
The monks don't speak their minds often, but when they do, the actors infuse their utterances with bottomless grace and humility yet very human dread and doubt.
Finding Nemo is laced with smart humor and clever gags, and buoyed by another cheery story of mismatched buddies: a pair of fish voiced by Albert Brooks and Ellen DeGeneres.
The movie is a toxic buzz of sweetness that Duff's teen gal fans might lap up, while all others suffer through a prolonged sugar fit.
The good time clearly had by the filmmakers rubs off on the audience.
"Won't Back Down" lives down to its bland, us-against-them title with a simple-minded assault on the ills of public schools that lumbers along like a math class droning multiplication tables.
When [James] starts winning some bouts and becoming a contender, the movie's credibility skyrockets into "Rocky" territory and beyond.
Casting Perry as Cross was a bad idea, though it's not necessarily the worst in a movie built on bad ideas.

Lee and screenwriter David Magee find rich and clever ways to translate even Pi's stillest moments, the film unfolding through intricate flashbacks, whimsical voice-overs, harrowing sea hazards and exquisite flashes of fantasy and hallucination.
If "Hitchcock" ultimately feels inconsequential, it always aims to please, and for the most part, it does.
Guillermo del Toro has crafted a masterpiece, a terrifying, visually wondrous fairy tale for adults that blends fantasy and gloomy drama into one of the most magical films to come along in years.
Tolkien's brisk story of intrepid little hobbit Bilbo Baggins is drawn out and diluted by dispensable trimmings better left for DVD extras.

If you weren't in a failed band yourself, you know people who were, and Chase's story IS their story, if not in the particulars, then in the spirit and the passion. The music may fade, but what's behind it never does.
''Django Unchained'' is Tarantino at his most puerile and least inventive, the premise offering little more than cold, nasty revenge and barrels of squishing, squirting blood.
"West of Memphis" is nonfiction filmmaking at its best, a film with a fierce point of view yet one that doesn't pretend to have all the answers or a monopoly on truth.
The shock value wears off quickly and writer-director Shyamalan strands us in a boring cautionary tale with an infantile eco-message about humanity needing to live in harmony with nature -- or else.

Stripped of almost all the brothers' usual crudeness, Fever Pitch proves what we've suspected all along: That beneath the gross-out gags and freak-show humor, Peter and Bobby Farrelly are just a couple of lovable romantics.
Loud, crude and outlandish, Rollerball is a parody of itself, a frenzy of extreme-sports stunts masquerading as social commentary on violence and the corporate forces that feed off it.
For all the hate and hostility it depicts, 42 is a film about decent-hearted people. Hate can be infectious, but so can decency. It's the decency you'll take away from 42.
With a huge, well-chosen cast and the blessing of Miller, who was on set as Rodriguez's co-director, Sin City is a gloriously stylized world unlike anything you've seen before on screen.
All but the faintest flashes of humanity and pathos are flattened by the cinematic cyclone that is Michael Bay.
These all are amiable people, decent people, sometimes funny people. But unfortunately, the peeps of ''Peeples'' just aren't very memorable people.
An excessively derivative what-if rehash of themes and interactions that came before, most of the characters lesser copies and even caricatures of the originals.
With earnest, unpretentious delivery, Maguire is an eminently likable hero audiences will root for from his earliest moments as the class wimp.

The action tale I Am Number Four is mostly familiar stuff, presenting the latest teen outsider coming into possession of his latent superpowers just in time to battle evil forces intent on world chaos.
Time for a little gladiatorial gore with your Milk Duds. Gladiator is here, and it's big, glorious and eminently dumb.

Adam Sandler and Jennifer Aniston's romantic comedy, idiotic even by their usually low big-screen standards, is stuffed with unpleasant narcissists saying and doing the stupidest, often cruelest things in hope of cheap laughs.
It may not merit the adjective in its title, yet the animated yarn Fantastic Mr. Fox offers some of the most goofy fun you'll have at a theater this season.
A story that strays about without finding its center.
There's more Partridge Family hugginess than sedition and subversion behind this rock 'n' roll story.

What remains on screen is impressive -- grand battles, dazzling action, sumptuous sets, magnificent panoramas. What's lost in the abbreviation is the emotional element as Woo chronicles an epic clash of warriors in the 3rd century.
All three lovers are so joyless, it's hard to imagine why any of them would want to spend eternity together.
Old Dogs is no fun whatsoever, just a collection of stale kibble.
Reitman has an impeccable talent for tearing out the spine of a novel and transposing it to the big screen, streamlining and simplifying a literary work without dumbing it down.
Jackson crafts lovely but ineffectual dreamscapes of the afterlife that eviscerate much of the human side of the story.
What button, on whose box, did Kelly push to get the money to make this awful, preposterous thriller?
Ron Clements and John Musker deliver a satisfying gumbo of snappy dialogue, lovable characters and bright-hued images, spiced up with just the right touch of voodoo peril.

The songs become anthems inhabited by Bridges, whose Bad Blake may wish his life had turned out differently but is never going to dribble tears in his shot glass so long as he still can find a stage somewhere to belt out a tune.

The Young Victoria is good, old-fashioned period drama _ not terribly lively, not terribly insightful, but rich in pageantry and fine moments of drama, the whole show hinging on a beguiling performance from Blunt.
Ritchie piles on the excess. It serves him well in fashioning a dazzling, detailed version of 1880s London, with the pardon-our-dust construction of the landmark Tower Bridge a pivotal element.
The story's not entirely predictable. Yet it's anything but complicated.

This sad little movie is built entirely to set up Chan's stunt sequences as he fights with pots, pans, ladders and other found objects or hurtles stairways to chase bad guys. The action stuff is more tolerable than the jokes, but barely.
As period dramas go, Creation is quiet and modest, sparse in action and decked out with classy but unassuming costumes and sets.
These three are so dull the story might have had more spark and tension had Green stranded three strangers aloft on a frozen chairlift.
There's more emotion in the monster's howls, which were created by a baritone opera singer, than in Del Toro's monotone mutterings.
Calculated to be show-stoppers, the songs often end up as quaint throwbacks.
Lee Daniels, in just his second film as director, crafts a story that rises from the depths of despair to a place of genuine hope.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: In fits and starts, director Heslov captures a lot of the drolly incredulous spirit of the book. It's just too bad the dots don't connect better.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: In the end, this homage to '80s horror is little more than a faithful flashback -- authentic in execution but about as scary as something you saw again and again way back when.

The filmmakers cannot resist embracing the conventions they were tweaking. Hancock turns from a moody, darkly funny character piece trimmed out with a bit of engaging action and veers into a poor impersonation of a standard superhero movie.

With crisp images and depth that makes you feel you could reach out and stick your hand into the middle of the action, the movie projected in digital 3-D form actually makes that theme-park ride kind of fun.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Reasonably fun if generally forgettable.
Mildly educational and not all that entertaining.
While Ritchie stumbled with his last two flicks, RocknRolla has the kind of manic energy that made audiences fall for the rogues of his earlier films.

A potentially original premise and an eager voice cast led by John Cusack and Molly Shannon are left to decay amid a clunky story vaguely reminiscent of Monsters, Inc. and images often resembling visuals rejected from Tim Burton's Corpse Bride.
[A] far-fetched take on Iraq War homecomings.
No doubt it was fun assembling so many close associates, but like Kym, Demme doesn't know when enough is enough for those who aren't part of the family circle.
It all just seems like window-dressing for Jolie's best-actress clip at the Oscars.
With so many characters to cram in and not much for many of them to do, Escape 2 Africa ends up a choppy, episodic affair.

While Robert Wise's science-fiction classic The Day the Earth Stood Still" was a simple story of deep ideas, the remake is an overblown, puny-minded tale featuring extraterrestrials too stupid or lazy to do a background check on the species they condemn.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Deschanel and Carrey make for indifferent romantic partners. Both are pleasant enough, but no one's going to look at the two together and think, what a great couple they make.
Almost inevitably, Hoffman and Thompson are charming. Even they can't turn Hopkins' thin story into a credible tale, though.
There are chuckles, maybe even a belly laugh or two if you're in a charitable mood. But the movie's mostly a waste of time and talent.

Sadly, Wolverine's journey is one long run-the-gauntlet scenario, with people pounding on him from all sides until he emerges at the other end as the lone-wolf amnesiac bound for membership in the X-Men gang.

The movie was emblematic of his output of late -- slight plots, slighter characters, lackadaisical storytelling that recycles enough of the neuroses-fueled charm of his earlier films to keep the Woody Allen machine in business.

Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince is the franchise's best so far, blending rich drama and easy camaraderie among the actors with the visual spectacle that until now has been the real star of the series.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Swank and Nair play it safe to the point of benumbing this woman's life, leaving Earhart as remote and muted as she is in the black-and-white photos and news footage of the aviator included at the film's end.
The movie's a chaotic, infuriating mess that will challenge the most-devoted of the Napoleon Dynamite faithful.
It's more a list of ingredients than a movie-magic potion to enjoy from start to finish.
movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: If a film is going to pile on the doom and foreboding this thickly, the payoff better be worth the hard road viewers have to slog.
There are more revisionist bloodsucker stories out there than you can shake a stake at nowadays, and they're getting tiresome.
Brosnan and Williams are the real highlights, both such dynamos that you feel their absence and yearn for their return during the long stretches when McGregor is mucking about on his own.

Despite their weird interrelations, these mismatched folks do seem like people you might know for real, the players in another of life's random acts of kinkiness that help to keep our curious species fresh and interesting.
The stars remain a boring threesome, Stewart limping through supposedly impassioned speeches as though Bella already were one of the cold-blooded undead.
While uneven, repetitive and occasionally nonsensical, The Girl Who Played With Fire still offers a fair dose of suspense and action for those who can stomach its brutal violence.
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Cholodenko and her cast turn what could have been an utterly artificial story into a warm, funny, sharp-tongued and broiling examination of the volatility underlying even the happiest of families.
The low-budget movie continually shifts from comic-book spoof to gritty crime story to mental-health drama, the inconsistent tone preventing it from ever fully working as one or another.
Offers a chilling look at current nuclear arsenals and the weapons programs of North Korea and Iran.
For a filmmaker who has worked mostly in contemporary settings in television, film, music videos and commercials, Schneider shows eyes and ears marvelously attuned to the past.
The good news for fans: there isn't all that much downtime between the relentless action, which, after all, is what that fake Machete trailer promised, and what the audience has come for.
Anyone remotely familiar with the story of Secretariat knows the outcome before the movie begins, but that Belmont climax still is intoxicating to watch.
This latest adaptation of a hip graphic novel fails to fill in the spaces between the action with anything terribly interesting.
When she lands the right part, Swank delivers with as much conviction as anyone working in Hollywood today.
Lisbeth stuck in a confined space is like Superman trapped in a phone booth: It's a blueprint for a mighty boring superhero movie.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Unfortunately, the underdeveloped story and characters seem to be there to service the visuals, rather than the other way around.
One of the funniest movies of the year.
Despite its dramatic pretenses and far racier sex scenes than the typical studio romance, the movie is as predictable and ultimately as sappy as any other run-of-the-mill Hollywood love story.
Less a boxing drama than a drama with some boxing in it, The Fighter turns Bale loose in a supporting role that dominates director David O. Russell's film.
Grit your teeth through the fairly short though agonizing duration of its stay.

The movie was needlessly converted to 3-D. The images are not blurry and distracting as some 3-D conversions have been, but neither are they terribly impressive, adding nothing but a few extra dollars to the price of a ticket.
Agonizing to watch yet relentlessly compelling.
So short, and so bad, you cringe at the thought of how awful whatever ended up on the cutting-room floor must be.
Winter's Bone is raw, real, understated, fiercely intense and surprisingly gentle and decent amid bursts of ferocity in the rural crime culture where the story's set.
It's a fairly fun time for families, and Hollywood can -- and continually does -- build franchises out of far worse concoctions than this.
Every turn of Letters to Juliet is obvious and expected, even insufferable.
Other than a few dashes of humor managed by Hawke, the movie is relentlessly bleak and barbarous, Fuqua grinding viewers down through his cavemen-with-badges depiction of police work.
Writer-director Andrea Arnold has created something so real and raw, you may come away with a twinge of guilty voyeurism, a sense of peering too closely and impolitely into other people's lives.
Chandrasekaran's book is a work of sharp, informative journalism. That "inspired by" credit sounds a little insulting when the result is tired, standard action fare such as Green Zone.
It's a nice palate cleanser among all the computer-generated action of Hollywood's summer blockbusters.
Greenberg is a perceptive look at coming to terms with, if not entirely embracing, the life you weren't expecting and by no means wanted.

With How to Train Your Dragon, the filmmakers tone down the glib factor and tell a pretty good action yarn, a boy-and-his-dragon story filled with fiery Viking battles, swordplay and dazzling aerial imagery aboard the flying reptiles.
Atom Egoyan's sex thriller Chloe is a pure guilty pleasure, if you take away that part about pleasure.

The story rests too often on easy '80s potshots -- Look, a Jheri curl! Check out those leg-warmers! Can you hear me on my brick cell phone? -- and today's parlance falling on deaf '80s ears -- E-mail? What's that?
An admirable attempt even if the film only works spottily.
Stewart and Fanning handle the vocals admirably, their live performances blending seamlessly with actual Runaways recordings on the soundtrack.
It's hard to go along for the ride when the characters act more like statuary than people.

While Li, Lau and Kaneshiro bring warmth, humor and pathos to their roles as blood brothers bound for tragedy, they're better to watch in action or when quietly brooding than when pontificating on what they owe to one another and the warriors they lead.
Audiard has talked about the prospects of a sequel to A Prophet. With the foundation he has built here, it would be a welcome one.

These are two of the funniest people ever on television, yet their big-screen Date Night is a dreary, uninspired waste of their talents -- and those of the top-name cast inexplicably appearing in small throwaway roles.
Wojtowicz-Vosloo just piles on the nonsense back and forth in a laughably incomprehensible muddle.

Director Matthew Vaughn has made an action comedy so bloody funny -- double emphasis on bloody -- fans might need to see it again just to catch the gags they missed from laughing so hard the first time.
It makes for good, although not great, satire of the consumer culture that helped wreck the economy.
The film is a curiosity. It's both an attempted documentary of an artistic movement and a bemused examination about why the movie failed in that mission.
The movie might have resonated more if it threw out some of the grief-counseling cliches and let the idiosyncrasies of the characters dictate more of the drama.
Be warned. When the makers of Must Love Dogs want you to like somebody, they slam your hand in a drawer until you say uncle.
It's many things: a terrific performance piece for a handful of good actors, an engaging metaphor and a so-so piece of storytelling.
The film's sophistication -- and it is an immensely sophisticated film -- lies in its refusal to tuck in too tightly its shirttails.
[The director] has made a paint-by-numbers horror film without a shred of originality and then added onto it, like a second head, a paint-by-numbers courtroom drama without a shred of originality.
After a while, to put it coarsely, you wish they'd just juice the guy and end the movie.
Feels like a French Romantic novel shot without a trace of irony.
it's simply too depressing that people sat in a boardroom, read this script and said, 'We're ready to go!'
As things progress, the magic of the story asserts itself over the audience.
Extremely well written in the fearless way of a smarty pants on a roll in the university cafeteria.
For all of its, um, workmanlike assembly, Magician: The Astonishing Life and Work of Orson Welles is textbook. And given its charismatic subject, that's a real shame.
movie_title: Magician: The Astonishing Life and Work of Orson Welles (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Well-produced with nice camera work and great sound, To Be Heard is wisely allowed to unfold on its on terms, loosely structured around poetry slams, escalating personal dramas and time between students and teachers.
Wetlands is relentlessly engaging thanks to Wnedt's exhilarating, exuberant direction and his profoundly self-assured command of the form.
Resnais's interest lies in how [a] steady drip of quotidian moments can be individually parsed and how the steadiness endows the material with dimension and weight.

In the tradition of television holiday specials, Netflix has blessed its fans with a well-crafted 30-minute backstory in Marco Polo: One Hundred Eyes. One of the most beloved characters from season 1 gets a well deserved origin story.
Coco wonderfully explores familial themes, identity, and learning what it means to grow up in a world that isn't perfect.
While Smith is as full of charm and bravado as ever, it's Edgerton who steals the show.
This aggressively stupid comedy tries to have it both ways, advocating sexual probity while its cameras linger over acres of golden female thighs.
Some genuinely affecting moments punctuate their accounts, but overall this amiable documentary is as mad as a sackful of whippets.

35 Shots of Rum draws its power from silences, glances, hugs and smiles - all of which speak more eloquently than any dialogue. It's a profound, discreet, hugely touching work that resonates in the memory.
It's an odd, uneasy mixture of sword-and-sandals epic and high-minded moral debate, but it's shot beautifully and there's no denying its ambition.

In his maturity, [Almodovar] remains a distinctive stylist and a dazzling film-maker with technique to burn. Yet while his new film Broken Embraces parades his many virtues, it treads water rather than breaks new ground.
Surrendering to the film's languid rhythms is pleasurable, even invigorating. To resist its forbidding pace and style is to deny oneself its rarefied rewards.
movie_title: The Man From London (A Londoni Férfi) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Clearly, the story relates to the Israeli-Palestinian divide - Lemon Tree is not a film for those who like their metaphors understated. Yet it is remarkable for the mere presence of Hiam Abbass alone.
Inkheart is cheerful and amiable, and in the absence of a Harry Potter film this winter, it fills a gap neatly.
It's generous-minded, and though it labours awkwardly to move you, that doesn't mean you won't be moved.
Yet despite the crudeness that finally overtakes Lakeview Terrace, it may be a more accurate representation of racial attitudes in Los Angeles than many inhabitants would care to admit.
Philip Glass's score still takes the breath away.
movie_title: Mishima: A Life in Four Chapters (1985)

movie_review_blurb: Its overall tone is cheerful, amiable and kid-friendly - and in these straitened times, one learns to be grateful for small mercies.
Smith, an eloquent subject with a wry view on her life, generously pays tribute to such influential mentors as Dylan, Burroughs and Ginsberg. Her fans should be entranced.
This efficient British chiller ticks the right boxes.
Luc Besson's modestly-budgeted but wildly successful franchise shows signs of broadening to include romance and humour.
Agreeably short, but it's hard to overlook that it's only a parade of still images. A film, certainly, but not quite a movie.
Seeing such talent wasted on this dross is dismaying.
A jolting journey towards a swaggering notion of manhood, directed with assured expertise by Jamshed Usmonov.
movie_title: To Get to Heaven, First You Have to Die (Bihisht faqat baroi murdagon) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Calling a diamond-heist movie Flawless is a valiant choice - especially when it's anything but. Suspense is essential to this genre, but here you couldn't care less what happens next.
Pure razzle-dazzle, of course - fittingly for this industry, it's a con-trick.

Such life lessons could clearly seem maudlin and patronising. But director Jean Becker and his two excellent leads opt for understatement, and the film finally achieves a subtle triumph - a mood that is both celebratory and bittersweet.
movie_title: Dialogue avec mon jardinier (Conversations with My Gardener) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: There is much to admire about Blindness, but this striking work is all too often undermined by its sense of its own importance.

Great music and costumes, but with a woeful plot and jaw-droppingly stilted dialogue. Cuban-born Garcia's main complaint against Fidel seems to be that rich, corrupt Cubans could no longer dance the night away.
This adaptation of a novel by American provocateur Chuck Palahniuk is profane, offensive and obscene, and packed with balefully weak jokes.
Feels oddly detached from the compelling genre of music it claims to advocate.
Tautou is just terrific, and to recall an actress who could so dominate your memory of a movie, one needs to think back to Audrey Hepburn.
A thin, wan script, acting that's mostly embarrassing, and a stream of foul expletives where a script should be.
Its many memorable characters, adrenalin-charged action sequences and heart-stopping car chases make for a guilty pleasure.
Powerful, gripping and always intriguing...
A mature, wise reflection on life's joys and sorrows, Another Year can take its place beside the very best films in Mike Leigh's career - Secrets and Lies, Vera Drake and Life is Sweet.
It's not terrible, but many of the metaphors employed by writers Derick and Steven Martini are crashingly obvious.
It sounds like damning with faint praise, but Woody Allen's You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger is easily the best of his recent London-based films.
movie_title: You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This is a far better bet than Oliver Stone's ghastly Doors movie.
One hesitates to over-praise such a delicate, small-scale work, but Whitfield seems like a major talent.
It's so smart, well-acted and fast on its feet that the journey trumps the final destination.
French animator Sylvain Chomet's The Illusionist is a gushing love letter to Edinburgh, its unique geography, architecture and distinctively pale, wintry light.
The concert footage is excellent, with Brown in decent form, even if in truth he was already a decade past his creative peak. Good music movie, thin documentary.

It's hard to feel ill-disposed towards a family film that treats the children in the audience as intelligent citizens rather than just young consumers, and presents its child characters as complex people with contradictions, nuances and surprising traits.
What a letdown.
Funny, angry and deadly accurate.
Its essential niceness should not be discounted; niceness is a rare commodity in films today.

This 1953 Howard Hawks film, a lightweight but agreeable adaptation of Anita Loosâ(TM)s acid novel and play, is mainly notable for cementing Marilyn Monroeâ(TM)s public image of breathy, faux-innocent sexuality.

Unhappily, thereâ(TM)s no dramatic arc here, just a series of encounters with unsuitable or undesirable men. Writer-director Xiaolu Guo puts her heroine through trying ordeals, but her character remains elusive.
Ortega has applied himself studiously to his task, and the film is some recompense for those deprived by his death of seeing Jackson live.
The Soloist has its imperfections, but its ambition trumps them.
The humour is lame and more than a little smutty, while the plot barely hangs together.
The story feels thin and faintly incoherent, the action is loud and relentless. A milder version of many other Bruckheimer films, then - which doesn't mean kids won't love it.
The whole exercise feels exploitative.
What's true? What's not? Is it a Banksy fabrication, a knowing stunt satirising the art world? Tellingly, there's no director credit. Whatever the truth, it's an amusing, curious documentary.

Miller's film is a triumph. Uniformly well acted, it boasts a psychologically knowing script, clearly written by a smart, assertive human being rather than a software programme. As for the luminous Wright Penn, awards season beckons.
movie_title: The Private Lives of Pippa Lee (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Well-meant but gruel-thin British comedy in which a failed film-maker helps wheelchair-bound teenagers to make a movie.
The film is a maddening mix of mild fascination and boredom. Bulle Ogier plays Séverine, as Deneuve opted not to reprise her role. Without her, the film lacks the required frisson.
Rubbish, of course, but some teenage boys love this stuff. Don't rule out sequels.
It's laboured and obvious, and not even a Yuletide movie: Christmas is little more than a device to bring the family back under one roof. Still, its plot is as overstuffed as any turkey.
Above all, there's the sense of immersion in a world of harsh beauty whose time is running out. It's to be hoped that non-American audiences embrace this film: it's one of the year's very best.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Taut, stylish French thriller, based on a novel by Ted Lewis.
This brilliant premise falls apart in the final act.
No film starring Juliette Binoche can be totally negligible, but this comes close.
movie_title: A Few Days in September (Quelques jours en septembre) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: OTT action and amoral humour are the entire point.
Well-intentioned, but teeth-grindingly earnest, with a voice-over that seems to consist entirely of clichés.
Certainly the story's climax in Buenos Aires is unexpected, yet many scenes resemble staged reality TV moments: group hugs, tears, mumbled monologues about overcoming obstacles.
movie_title: In the Hands of the Gods (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Disturbia's limits are those of its hero - an amiable, faintly clueless young man with a brief attention span.
A Very British Gangster, his portrait of Manchester crime boss Dominic Noonan, raises awkward questions about his methods, as well as the question of whether "documentary" is even the right word.
Literally laughable.
