Unlucky to miss out a Best Foreign Film Oscar, this moving war flick is a nerve-jangling odyssey into the underground world. Recommended.
A powerful, punchy slice urban thriller that shows off Kebbell at his most compelling.
Honest and disarming, although with the obligatory Sparks pathos.
If this proves to be the last in the series, it's a bloody shame it ended not with a Scream but a whimper.
Just as good as the last outing, this is great kiddie fare with some filmic references for the adults.
Lighter than its predecessors.
Technical shortcomings aside this is a good story well told, elevated by McKellen on top form.
A quiet and disquieting masterpiece which gets under your skin and stays there long after you leave the cinema.
A quirky drama with finely drawn characters and some kinetic ping-pong action.
Grim, gruelling but beautifully shot, this is intelligent, sophisticated horror.
For Japanimation fans it's a big-screen must-see.
The actors' understated performances, coupled with an underwritten screenplay, ultimately leave the audience dangling.
An unforced, engaging and surprisingly incisive account of the disintegration of British rule in Africa.
The Night Listener is intriguing, thought-provoking and harrowing by turns, with fine central and supporting performances and a richly satisfying feel.
Seems like a spoof at first glance but this proves to be a compelling Post-modern thriller with gumption.

If weapons and wizardry get your blood up, and you prefer your movies dark and brooding and minus the sandals, Solomon Kane fits the bill. It may lack The Lord Of The Rings' majesty, but Robert E. Howard fans will lap it up.
Funny, whimsical and as warming as a big bowl of Irish stew.
Despite an impressive bag of special effects tricks, old Fred is starting to resemble one of those dead horses that studio execs insist on flogging.
movie_title: A Nightmare on Elm Street 5: The Dream Child (1989)

movie_review_blurb: It's a surprise to see Wim Wenders embracing 3D in its full, feature-length glory but the medium works well to capture the graceful swirl of the German choreographer's work.
As appealing as a cigarette in a beer can.
A timeless tale, beautifully remastered.
An indie with real pedigree and smarts, Holofcener's comedy of manners is well-observered and well worth watching.
Despite dozens of interviews and Rock's personal agenda, this isn't the hard-hitting expose it should have been.
Decently made and well-acted, but with a whiff of glossy, high-life voyeurism.
The Duplass brothers enter the mainstream with a touching, original and supremely funny film.
Schnabel doesn't comes close to the quiet power of his last feature, The Diving Bell And The Butterfly...
It's good, but from this director we have come to expect great.
Does to the medieval era what Cage's Wicker Man did to Anthony Shaffer.
Better than The Transporter but not as much fun as Crank.
Totally crackers but it gets powered by pure invention and eccentricity alone.
As urgent as Hidden Agenda was, Loach's latest is insightful and explosive, so torn from today's headlines it leaves newsprint on your hands.
Five star entertainment for the under-tens, deduct two stars for everyone else.
A loopy joy from start to finish, Bradley Cooper proves that he's the real deal.
Moving if low-key, Jim Loach's debut feature is proof that compassionate, socially conscious filmmaking runs in the family.
Goofball fun that will have kids -- big and small -- rolling in the aisles
Anchored by a typically flawless performance by Jones, Strickland's second film begins as an audio geek's dream, before spiralling inexorably into the stuff of David Lynch's nightmares.
Contraband is a cut above cookie-cutter heist thrillers, and director Baltasar Kormákur looks ready for the big time.
Ruby Sparks belongs to Zoe Kazan, who joins the likes of Sarah Polley and Brit Marling in the rarified ranks of actress/screenwriter double-threats.

Your opinion of this unasked-for but likable comedy sequel depends entirely on whether your reaction to the statement "It's better than the first one" is 1) "Dear God, it could hardly be worse" or 2) "Awesome!"
Pawlikowski has a photographer's eye for composition, and every crisp, monochrome frame could be a postcard from Poland's tragic, turbulent past.

Julianne Moore gives the performance of her career (no mean feat, given the strength of her previous work) in this heartbreaking yet life-affirming tale of a woman determined to hold onto her identity while under attack from a debilitating mental disease.
A laudable introduction for anyone yet to experience the joys of Nashville, M*A*S*H, Short Cuts or The Player.
The heartfelt telling of a truly extraordinary true story with a mesmerising central performance.
A brittle black comedy that has plenty to say about modern manhood and the human survival instinct.
If Chris Morris had grown up in Sweden watching Jacques Tati and Ingmar Bergman films, he might be making films like this.
movie_title: A Pigeon Sat on a Branch Reflecting on Existence (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Ultimately, this has the feel of a lazy literary adaptation of a half-remembered novel.
Triebel is an outstanding presence in this slow-burning thriller, which continues to smoulder long after the credits roll.
As bleak, unflinching and utterly unmissable as its predecessor, while the number of people credited as 'Anonymous' in the end credits is as bone-chilling as what has gone before.
A sensitive, slight French romance that marks a promising debut from French filmmaker Cailley.
Some of his Salgado's depictions of human suffering are not for the faint-hearted but, like this fine film, demand to be seen. Unmissable.
The former comedy co-stars are superbly cast in this fascinating, fact-based story.
A flawed yet fascinating Aussie indie.
Fails to realise the potential of a potent premise.
[A] flawed but fitfully entertaining film, even if it all goes a bit Pete Tong at the end.

If only he had probed a bit deeper, and widened his scope beyond the predominantly white, male subjects (including our own Rob Brydon, Steve Coogan and Stephen Merchant), this could have been a fascinating film as well as a funny one.
It's undemanding, heart-warming fodder with mass appeal. Sadly, it's also predictable and its big emotional beats are often harder to stomach than an overripe brie.
A surprisingly enjoyable if instantly forgettable crowd-pleaser that takes the audience for a ride - in more ways than one.
It's a powerful, provocative filmmaking that could potentially inspire a new generation of Dolores Huertas.
Has little new to say about the perils and pitfalls of stardom, but the talent behind and in front of the camera give the clichés a fresh coat of grease paint.
movie_title: Bingo: The King of the Mornings (Bingo - O rei das manhãs) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Holm's well-judged adaptation of the bestseller keeps the maudlin to a minimum and plays the black comedy just right. A strong contender for feel-good film of the year.
movie_title: A Man Called Ove (En man som heter Ove) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The Wailing takes its time to burrow under your skin, but by the time it weaves its dark, potent spell, it leaves you with a lingering, unshakeable sense of dread that Hollywood horror films can rarely muster.
This engaging -- but, crucially, never quite gripping -- thriller is a gloomy yet classy affair.
Tune into its offbeat frequency ... and there is much to enjoy.
Crackling with energy and fizzing with ideas, this fresh take on Frankenstein is a thrilling adaptation that reinvigorates a well-worn tale.
Nicholas Hoult does his best to bring Niven's weapons-grade scumbag to life, in a film hobbled by amateurish acting and absence of production value.
While Ascher brings the experiences to life in a way that could conceivably induce nightmares in casual viewers, the potency of these scenes is ultimately diminished by repetition.
A bold portrayal of a boy soldier in a brutal, bloody conflict, anchored by commanding performances from Idris Elba and 14 year-old newcomer Abraham Attah.
Visually striking, intellectually challenging and emotionally harrowing.
An exposition-heavy opening gives way to a modestly effective Australian mash-up of sci-fi/horror hybrids.
The late, great Robin Williams brings great nuance to the anguished Nolan's inner struggle in a slight but sensitive story about a man facing a life-changing choice.
A fitting memoir to a memorable political life.
Tom and Anna are so thinly sketched that by the time the painfully slow set-up starts to pay off, we no longer care who does what to whom, or why.
Mainstream audiences may find this too oddball to appreciate as a straight thriller. But tune into its strange frequency and there is much to enjoy - perhaps even adore.
Wingard is on his way to becoming the next Sam Raimi, and You're Next may well be your next favourite horror film.
Anchored by a charming performance from Greta Gerwig, it's as light and breezy as a walk in Central Park, and just as refreshing.
An unshakeable tolerance for high camp and lowbrow humour may be required to fully appreciate Almodóvar's broad, bawdy comedy - even for fans of his early, funny films.

Insightful, revelatory and profound, Moreh's Oscar-nominated documentary combines riveting interviews, archive footage and - yes - state-of-the-art photographic effects to offer a unique perspective on the Israel-Palestine issue.
Singer's tall tale is snatched from disaster by an all-hell-breaks-loose third act.
Like Parker's robberies, it isn't entirely successful, but Statham and Lopez make enticingly mismatched partners in crime.
Another shake-and-bake Stath special, boasting the requisite punchy-fighty action and some pleasing sleaziness from Franco and Bosworth, but it's ponderously handled by director Fleder.
Forget it, Jake, it's no Chinatown.
Plenty nasty but singularly lacking in clever new twists on a weary genre.
Prepare to be shocked, disturbed, awed... and, if you expected justice to prevail at last, ultimately devastated.
Beautifully performed and tough as nails, Vinterberg's social drama could not be any more timely.
It's hard to imagine that the prodigiously gifted Dolan is still in his early twenties. This is another work of marvellous maturity and assurance.
Pawlikowski has a photographer's eye for composition, and every crisp, monochrome frame could be a postcard from Poland's tragic, turbulent past.
Old age may not be a reality you wish to confront, but you must see this film.
With his fourth film as writer-director, Judd Apatow has arguably made his most personal film yet, without forgetting to make us laugh.
A documentary of two halves, Gibney's character study of Armstrong is tough and forensic.
An impressive debut by Castillo.
movie_title: De jueves a domingo (Thursday Till Sunday) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Even Oedipus would be left scratching his head by this bonkers but drily funny tale of one family's forlorn search for normality.
Reinforcing the very rom-com tropes it's sending up, this is a little too postmodern for its own good. Happily, Poehler and Rudd are as irresistible as ever.

It may be ageing provocateur Abel Ferrara's best film since King Of New York, but the film belongs to Depardieu. Like that painting of Kramer in Seinfeld, he is a loathsome, offensive brute, yet you can't look away.
If you only watch one Stefan Zweig-inspired film this year, watch The Grand Budapest Hotel. If you watch two, see The Grand Budapest Hotel twice. Awful.

An understated Nicolas Cage - there's a phrase you don't get to write too often these days - anchors a superbly realised film, which, like its eponymous hero, has a brittle outer shell concealing a surprisingly warm heart.
Palestinian filmmaker Annemarie Jacir's second film is slight yet significant - and, because of the situation in Syria, timely - story about a boy whose courage inspires hope among the hopeless.

Polanski's unavoidably stagy adaptation of David Ives' celebrated Broadway play is an enjoyably witty two-hander, confined to its theatre setting, yet with much to say about gender roles in the world beyond.
Got 2 hours to kill? Spend them elsewhere.
Too much muscle-headed action, too little parkour (Belle is getting on a bit) - this property is condemned.
Powerful, moving and melancholy. A low-key treat.
It could have felt like a facsimile of other films. Instead, it has enough individuality, imagination and idiosyncratic invention to identify it as a true original.
A clunky, clumsy handling of a book with (here untapped) depth.
Mediocre at best, this is a big Trej-no.
Intermittently funny but erratically structured, it's a rare disappointment from Shelton.
Aims for the gut but instead beans the viewer with a wildly unbelievable yarn.
Rat Race has swell stunts and special effects and enough laughs of all kinds to recover from its less successful episodes.
Valuable if only for its recording of a group of great and sadly unappreciated American musicians who have toiled far too long in relative obscurity.
Complex but often disengaging.
As for the action that greatly reimagines 17th century sword fighting, genre fans will be seeing nothing much new.
The bizarre result of another in a long line of westerns tailored for rising actors, who no one really takes seriously in such projects.
Another movie about relationships, but not an especially successful, original or involving one.
Neither one for the dogs nor the cat's pajamas.
A mostly unpretentious film that grows on one over time.
Energetically hilarious and embracing of out-of-the-mainstream folk.
Mostly tests one's patience with unseaworthy dialogue and performers drowning in oily cliches.
A crowd-pleasing return to form by producer Joel Silver.
Struggles to keep one amused as the premise tries to work in kooky supporting players with fitful success.
movie_title: What's the Worst That Could Happen? (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Unfolds as a quasigeneric chiller that degenerates into hokum.
Well-made and directed with finesse by old pro Keenen Ivory Wayans.
Gives only glimpses of the potential for dynamic storytelling many have longed for in an Imax film.
Jaded moviegoers will probably swat away this less-than-engrossing supernatural thriller.
In the final analysis, it's just too damn funny to take seriously.
Shrill and punishingly unfunny.

Slackers' jokey approach to college education is disappointingly simplistic -- the film's biggest problem -- and there are no unforgettably stupid stunts or uproariously rude lines of dialogue to remember it by.
A teen laugher that has no redeeming qualities -- not its filmmaking, performances or short running time.
Gooding is the energetic frontman, and it's hard to resist his enthusiasm, even if the filmmakers come up with nothing original in the way of slapstick sequences.
Not nearly as fun or profound as it might have been.
Teen is nothing more than the timelessly crude throwaway project it wants to be.
Another of what have become far too common lately: unintentional laughfests.
A worthy but somewhat less-than-satisfying follow-up to the Oscar-nominated Central Station.
So well-made and well-cast that one can have no reservations about the rest of Jackson's monumental creation.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Meeting the challenge is Barrymore, who portrays Beverly from ages 15-36 in her finest screen role.
A confusing mess where the characters' actions make little sense and the finale is particularly noxious.
A wobbly cinematic vehicle.
A cinematic marvel to behold.
Unpretentiously entertaining.
Lots of satirical hilarity and characters one grows fond of, and it ultimately touches on truths about the hucksterism at the heart of showbiz.
Another pleasant surprise.
Has all the makings of another big hit for Sandler.
A rewarding experience for those who relish gusts of Gallic gloom.
movie_title: The Town Is Quiet (La Ville est tranquille) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Classy and brassy, Jackie Chan and Chris Tucker are a funky, well-matched duo in New Line's winning Rush Hour.
Has unexciting characters overall, and it relies on routine car chases and shootouts that would be even sillier without the booming soundtrack and special effects.
Warner Bros.' outstanding The Iron Giant is a giant leap for the studio and robotkind!
A hybrid of sports movies and TV sitcoms with little originality and few surprises or memorably rough edges.
An uncannily timed movie phenomenon!
The season's most promising family draw.
The film never gets around to illuminating much about the lead character.
The real contest for audiences is weathering the tonal shifts and forgiving the screenplay's shallow depths and weak undercurrents.
This journey to unpleasantville is too often manipulative and strains to maintain tension.
A disappointing brew of slick commercial moviemaking and old-fashioned romantic fantasy!
The central conflicts are either creepingly unengaging, unpalatable or so muted as to be nonexistent.
A complex film that engages one's intelligence and chills one's bones.
Gets lost in a blizzard of cliches and uneven performances.
Both beautiful and distant.
The typical machinations of an event movie dictate multiple overblown climaxes that leave one less than bowled over.
Muddled, relentlessly derivative and uninvolving except as a visually superb image roll.
Robin Williams in his best film since Good Will Hunting!
Challenging and richly rewarding!
A muddy tale of sex, love, obsession, jealousy, cruelty and abandonment that can keep one at a distance.
The performers bring the bluesy story to life in a pleasing chemistry that could have just as easily not happened with other performers.
A bully follow-up to the 1999 international smash
A high-minded project that never lifts off as intended despite all the right elements seemingly coming together.
Utterly absorbing.
Eminently watchable.
An unusually annoying experience for viewers who might be expecting more fireworks in their satire.
Not going to find much surprising or fresh.
Often uproariously funny, blessedly short and never forgets it's a screwball romance for teen and adult moviegoers.
What it lacks in the screenplay ... is countered by buoyant performances all around.
There are mucho storytelling dodges and gaping plot holes that make Sugar barely watchable.
Deliriously funny!
A visual feast not to be passed up and bound to pack an emotional punch for many viewers!
With lots of laughs, lots of blood and the irrepressible Chan pushing the envelope in stunts and spectacularly choreographed group fights.
movie_title: The Legend of Drunken Master (Jui kuen II) (Drunken Fist II) (1994)

movie_review_blurb: General's Daughter strives to be a political nail-biter in the tradition of Fred Zinnemann, Alan J. Pakula and Oliver Stone, but there's really no comparison.
The film's realistic approach to storytelling and the strong performances mesh well with Winterbottom's stylistic flourishes.
A big meal of cliches that the talented cast generally chokes on.
A technologically stunning movie that furthers the genre and features crowd-pleasing performances to go with the frequent scenes of gunplay and violence.
Directed with goth pizzazz and brains by Michael Rymer.
There really is a nice core to the movie, and O'Connell and Anderson are equally adept at getting laughs by playing up the characters' manic drive to keep going.
Little more than the skin and bones and ear-flaying soundtrack of a dubiously fleshed-out premise that seemed dated 27 years ago.
Stealthily thought-provoking and brashly entertaining.
Several degrees shy of the gross-out contests one expects from current teen fare.
A cinematic flood of spectacular proportions.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Pleasingly, Soderbergh does not pander much to expectations and more than once evokes Stanley Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey.
A negligible thing at best and a determinedly unfunny thing at worst.
Nalin's film has excellent production values and thoroughly transports one to its far-flung world of clear skies, jagged mountains and passionate affairs of the mind and body.
Of interest only to male viewers who are addicts of Scorsese-meets -Tarantino gangster-life frolics.
Such a silly slugfest that no amount of surly attitude can hide its skeletal plot or stand in for satisfying characterizations.
Wears one down with a long running time and diminishing returns on its wicked premise.
Stevens' vibrant creative instincts are the difference between this and countless other flicks about guys and dolls.

Getting a lot of quality cinema out of a tight budget, Jacobs (Just One Night) takes some risks in the storytelling department that result in a film that encourages one to think long and hard about the subject of guns.
Miyazaki is one of world cinema's most wondrously gifted artists and storytellers.
Where it goes wrong is in the combination of poetic sensibilities and run-of-the-mill narrative cinema.

After one gets the feeling that the typical Hollywood disregard for historical truth and realism is at work here, it's a matter of finding entertainment in the experiences of Zishe and the fiery presence of Hanussen.
A dreary exercise in cheap shocks aimed at kids.
This boy-meets-girl movie is a chore to sit through.
movie_title: How to Lose a Guy in 10 Days (2003)

movie_review_blurb: [Robert] Rodriguez pushes the envelope but fails to make any lasting impression except revulsion at the spectacle of acclaimed independent filmmakers wasting their talents on such trash.
Stylistic but ultimately unsatisfying.
Engaging but decidedly less than earth-shattering.
movie_title: Stanley Kubrick: A Life in Pictures (2001)

movie_review_blurb: This is a documentary that could easily have been overly self-indulgent or fashionably irreverent but instead appeals to one's intelligence and provides glimpses of a dynamic country cruising peacefully toward the millennium.
Rather than being self-indulgent or pretentious, however, the film comes up with many believable details and changes in direction that enrich the bittersweet central relationship of the two leads.
The future is quieter, emotionally subdued and grayly mysterious, at least in the small hop forward imagined by filmmaker Michael Almereyda.
It's the stronger supporting players and script that make Knights a more palatable hybrid than Noon.
Goes down smoothly thanks to the trio of lead actors, whose enthusiasm and chemistry help make up for the routine filmmaking.
The sound effects and musical choices will underwhelm some, but those previously tuned in with the TV series will be happy to see the team of bounty hunters back in action.
movie_title: Cowboy Bebop: The Movie (Kaubôi Bibappu: Tengoku no Tobira) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: With a long running time that no amount of nonlinear construction can successfully quicken, Safety does have sequences and whole story lines that are fresh and thoughtfully entertaining.
It's a coming-out party of a project that is never less than engaging.
From the start Gods has a mighty wind of nostalgia and outright historical mythicizing that doesn't go down easily.
Not without moments of excitement, romance and rubber-burning redemption.
A gory good show for fans of R-rated horror mayhem.
A masterfully entertaining final installment.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The special effects and many scenes of weightlessness look as good or better than in the original, while the Oscar-winning sound and James Horner's rousing score make good use of the hefty audio system.
It's good to have the Next Generation crew back in action, and Patrick Stewart is still a commanding presence as Capt. Picard of the USS Enterprise.
Other than a mildly engaging central romance, Hospital is sickly entertainment at best and mind-destroying cinematic pollution at worst.
One just waits grimly for the next shock without developing much attachment to the characters.
May offend viewers not amused by the sick sense of humor.
Hawke achieves something special but less than industry-shaking.
Often shocking but ultimately worthwhile exploration of motherhood and desperate mothers.
movie_title: Alias Betty (Betty Fisher and Other Stories)(Betty Fisher et autres histoires) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: It's got more music, more drama, more of what made it a big winner with audiences and critics 18 years ago.
From spiritual rebirth to bruising defeat, Vincent's odyssey resonates in a profound way, comparable to the classic films of Jean Renoir.
Two-bit potboiler.
Steven Spielberg's masterful film has lost none of its power to sweep the viewer away in the most 'excellent' late-20th century boy's adventure one could hope for.
Sickening and utterly pointless, when it's not just outrageously tweaked for shock value, the film is soulless and caters to the darkest of human instincts.
Tedious when it should be tight and borderline silly when it should be freezing one's spine.
A generic bloodbath that often becomes laughably unbearable when it isn't merely offensive.
[F]rom the performances and the cinematography to the outstanding soundtrack and unconventional narrative, the film is blazingly alive and admirable on many levels.
Virtuoso cinema that mercilessly holds a light up to wasted lives but also comes down off its high to make us care about these lost souls.
An eminently airworthy sequel to one of the studio's most renowned creations, 1953's Peter Pan.
Amounts to minimal entertainment with nothing to recommend it.
Where Husband was light on its feet and congenial, Earnest never gets off the ground.
Davis directs the low-budget production with economy and a lack of surface flashiness that is pleasingly unpretentious.
Sayles and an excellent cast examine modern American lives, values, dreams and shortcomings with verve, honesty and a respect for the seemingly lost art of everyday conversation.
Why have a plot, characters, dialogue? Maybe the sequel will be called Simplistic: Bullets vs. Humans.
Seems destined to flop both in theaters and in ancillary manifestations.
The project's filmmakers forgot to include anything even halfway scary as they poorly rejigger Fatal Attraction into a high school setting.
Clunky plotting and an uninteresting character creep into a potentially funnier and more endearing scenario.
The leads are so unmemorable, despite several attempts at lengthy dialogue scenes, that one eventually resents having to inhale this gutter romancer's secondhand material.
A zinger-filled crowd-pleaser that open-minded Elvis fans (but by no means all) will have fun with.
Pitifully written, with flagrant disregard for reality in the fashion of a spoof.

When the film shows the awkwardness of the lead's caregiver relationship with his cranky father, De Villa finds material that's compelling, but such complications as the girlfriend's violent brother going ballistic and tragedy ensuing are rugged cliches.
The way Lilia loosens up and learns to dance enticingly for men in a timeless ritual that is empowering and not demeaning is Satin at its most engaging.
The acting, costumes, music, cinematography and sound are all astounding given the production's austere locales.

With a weak script that makes one think that the screenwriters never read the great war books of James Jones and Norman Mailer, the characters don't have near the dimensionality required to help the movie soar above the usual bloody Hollywood balderdash.
It's got all the familiar Bruckheimer elements, and Schumacher does probably as good a job as anyone at bringing off the Hopkins/Rock collision of acting styles and onscreen personas.
Led by Griffin's smartly nuanced performance and enthusiasm, the cast has a lot of fun with the material.
Vigorously directed by Phil Alden Robinson and tautly scripted by Paul Attanasio and Daniel Pyne.
From the performances and wry dialogue to the sets and cinematography, Looking is a film with a lot of things going for it.
An ensemble effort that recalls other great POW movies, Wars boasts many superb performances.
A Girl Walks Home Alone At Night may not be a great film, but where else are you going to see a dystopic Persian indie vampire romance?
movie_title: A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Exploring Día de los Muertos makes for a stunning aesthetic, but the rather bland characters in The Book Of Life rob the film of its sparkle.

Michael Winterbottom can't solve the murder of Meredith Kercher, but what he can do is reveal philosophical truths that go way beyond guilt and innocence, and it makes for some wonderfully smart stuff.
If it had managed to maintain its early energy, A Hard Day would have been a stone cold comedy classic. Instead, it's merely diverting.
With an incomprehensible plot and boring fight scenes there's not much to recommend when it comes to The White Haired Witch of Lunar Kingdom.
movie_title: The White Haired Witch of Lunar Kingdom (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Jauja may not be for everyone, but those who give it a chance will find a complex, beautiful film.
Get Santa is a tonally tin-eared Christmas experiment, but at least it's a unique one.
Is there a safer bet than an Aardman film? Shaun the Sheep Movie delivers on everything we've come to expect from the studio, giving us a delightful animated flick that's great fun for all audiences.
Don't get me wrong, Focus definitely has its moments, but it's far from essential viewing.
The Gunman is nothing more than Sean Penn's mid-life crisis vanity project, and it isn't worth the price of admission.
It doesn't break any new ground, but Run All Night is still a decent entry into the increasingly crowded "Liam Neeson in a leather jacket saving his kid from gangsters" genre.
The Keeping Room is beautiful, suspenseful and thoughtful. A true triumph!
Paddington is a marvellous (and politically brave) piece of cinema that never puts a paw wrong.
Electricity is a true cinematic treat and features a triumphant breakthrough performance from Agyness Deyn.

Like its title, The Hundred Year-Old Man Who Climbed Out the Window and Disappeared is shaggy and ramshackle, but there's enough playful imagination on display to easily make this a worthwhile recommendation.
movie_title: The 100-Year-Old Man Who Climbed Out the Window and Disappeared (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Charlie's Country is a more than worthy piece of cinema, firmly anchored by David Gulpilil's magnetic lead performance.
10,000 Km is a stunning debut that richly deserves every accolade it will receive. Marques-Marcet is a director to keep a very close eye on.
As the miners say, "We lost. But we were right." They were, and Still the Enemy Within elegantly and straightforwardly makes their case.
I can't quite believe that a film as cheesy-looking as What We Did On Our Holiday is this good, but it is. It really is.
movie_title: What We Did on Our Holiday (2015)

movie_review_blurb: In Order Of Disappearance is a wonderful slice of crime cinema; grimly hilarious, consistently beautiful and marvellously performed.
This political earnestness is rare in modern mainstream cinema, but Pride works from a rock-solid conviction that success lies in cooperation, understanding and empathy.
Herculesis a creaky bit of cheap-looking, inconsequentialfluff thatsquanders any potential and contains not a jot of passion, imagination or creativity. So, in summary, it's a Brett Ratner film.
If you threw a camera, boom mic and clapper board into the monkey enclosure at the zoo they'd have produced something more worthwhile than Walking On Sunshine.
Chinese Puzzle is smart, touching and pleasantly human - the epitome of a feel good romantic comedy.
t's been rumoured that Jimmy's Hall is Ken Loach's swan song, and if it is, it's definitely an inspiring note to go out on.

Pulp: A Film About Life, Death and Supermarkets is a magnificent documentary that fully understands its subject. The band are fascinating, the music is amazing and, at the centre of it all, the people of Sheffield make the city positively glow.
movie_title: Pulp: a Film About Life, Death & Supermarkets (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Benny & Jolene almost entirely succeeds on the shoulders of Craig Roberts and Charlotte Ritchie, as they have genuine chemistry which saves the film's bacon.
movie_title: Jolene: The Indie Folk Star Movie (Benny & Jolene) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Please don't go and see Blended. It's a quasi-racist, deeply boring waste of time, money and talent that makes the world an imperceptibly worse place merely by existing.
If you've got the stomach for nerve-shredding, ultra-experimental, monster-psychedelic, idiosyncratic-as-all-hell cinema, then boy oh boy, The Forbidden Room is the film for you!
Mr. Turner is gorgeous, touching, weird, interesting, funny and a thousand other superlatives.
Exotica, Erotica, Etc. is a grand visual achievement, but I just wish it was a bit more structurally coherent.
Son of Joseph is an unquestionably smart, good-looking film, but I appreciate it more than I enjoyed it.

movie_review_blurb: The spirit of Spielberg, transplanted to the east. Bliss.
A real step up for Apatow. His masterpiece? Quite possibly.
It's still a one-of-a-kind, we'll give it that. But its sense of fun is so relentless and excessive, it all ends up being extremely tedious and shallow.
Nothing to see here.
Reg Traviss's overlong thriller spews out clichés from the off.
Quote not available.
While the context of Matthew Vaughn's slick 'X-Men' origin story feels like it's been filched from the notepad of a GCSE History student, there's no shortage of breathtaking spectacle elsewhere.
Daylight Robbery...the exact expression that you're likely to utter if you pay for a ticket to see this utter garbage.
The film's moral, technological and psychological themes are glazed over, and the manner in which Ben finally conquers his personal demons is laughably overblown.
Ozon's film plays a difficult hand, never settling for all-out high kitsch or straight melodrama. One of the year's most charming failures.
Regrettably, the film's intended air of melancholy is all but annulled by Bertoglio's wan, haughty and utterly pretentious narration about how wonderful New York was at that time.

First-time director Esther Robinson proves that a dash of subjectivity in documentary isn't always a bad thing, showing a remarkable clarity of vision and thirst for knowledge in her superb 'A Walk Into the Sea: Danny Williams and the Warhol Factory'.
movie_title: A Walk Into the Sea: Danny Williams and the Warhol Factory (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Morgan Neville's 'The Cool School' is a slickly packaged document of the burgeoning modern art scene in LA during the late '50s and early '60s which sadly submerges its fascinating subject matter in technical clutter and contrived set-ups.
Another sloppily concocted and naggingly non-controversial pretext for Sandler to pelvic thrust his way though a succession of increasingly wacky fish-out-of-water situations.
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's a dull, if competently made, film, which is done no favours by its earnest tone, a soppy orchestral score and a slew of artificial performances by actors clinging far too tightly to their lines. It would be far better suited to daytime TV.
Crump's film colourfully depicts Wagstaff's complex inner mindset and rarefied eye for imagery by allowing the stunning prints to linger on the screen.
movie_title: Black White + Gray: A Portrait of Sam Wagstaff and Robert Mapplethorpe (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It is impressively made, but leaves a nasty taste in the mouth.
Blindsight is a great example of the emotional dividends that careful photography, sensitive editing and an atmospheric score can deliver.

Making the farcical tenor of the recent Indiana Jones film feel like a paragon of dramatic and archaeological integrity, this phoned-in action threequel doesn't even have the good grace to deliver on its title and feature any mummies
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Though the narrative is saggy and you feel there's nowhere left to go after the first hour, a much-needed dash of class from Jon S Baird's direction helps lift 'Cass' above its oft-reactionary genre brethren.
Overall an emotionally rich and tender film, beautifully played, with heart and head in massive abundance.
movie_title: El Baño del Papa (The Pope's Toilet) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Echoing Malick's 'Days of Heaven' in the way it captures the majesty of the American countryside, this is a small gem that's worth seeking out.
They say sarcasm is the lowest form of wit. Well 'they' obviously haven't seen 'The Love Guru', an overgrown dirt-patch of clunking juvenilia.
You could hardly call it a paragon of impartial filmmaking, but this is still a compelling and immersive glance into the nature of competitiveness and the corrupting aspects of fame.
movie_title: The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Light on both CGI and moral quandaries, [it posesses] neither the zip and sparkle of a Spider-Man nor the brooding existential subtexts of Batman Begins.
Simon DaVison's loopy labour of love succeeds where other offerings of pure homage (most recently 'Grindhouse') failed.
movie_title: Captain Eager and the Mark of Voth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A stark yet comforting reminder that cold, hard cash is no substitute for cold, hard talent. 'The Hottie and the Nottie' is an execrable Z-grade eugenics parable moonlighting as a sexy, disposable date movie.
An exceptional piece of filmmaking, intricate, elaborate and exuding warmth and wisdom from its every frame.
movie_title: Le Voyage du Ballon Rouge (The Flight of the Red Balloon) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: 'Semi-Pro' resorts to the bombast of brash 'infotainment' news and sports programming to mine its humour.
90 minutes of violence. No more, no less.
The magnitude of Gondry's visual ingenuity is consistently jaw-dropping.
Andrei Kravchuk's film is sensitive to the hilt and pleasingly attuned to the guileless outlook of its hero.

The one area where 'Walk Hard' does manage to hold its own against classics of the genre such as 'This is Spinal Tap' or 'Sweet and Lowdown' is the music, all of which is expertly written and performed.
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A slightly meandering build-up is saved by a second half that really cooks, with Vargas ratcheting up the tension by flirting with genre convention in order to deal with Plutarco's unconventional psychological stand-off with a malodorous Captain.
Passes the time, but undoutedly one for the little 'uns.
Do anything: rob a petrol station, superglue your eyelids together, chew on broken glass, just avoid at all costs.

This overreaching, Lynch-lite comic drama is the mediocre directorial debut of screenwriter John August ('Charlie's Angels', 'Big Fish') and, if nothing else, demonstrates why some writers should stick to their laptops.
This is cinema for people who slow down at car wrecks.
It makes for frustrating and unreasonably demanding viewing.
This playfulness, however, backfires massively in the second half when coincidence and unforeseen consequence conspire uneasily with bloody, messy results.
Superior animé caper comedy with wit, energy and mad invention to spare.
movie_title: The Girl Who Leapt Through Time (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It's a familiar tale, but one told with gusto, wit and visual flare...
The stylishly mounted first half zips along at a rate of knots while the gruesome make-up work will keep your gag reflex in violent spasm.

This brilliant, desperately sad Steinbeckian fable from American director Kelly Reichardt. It's Reichardt's third full-length feature ('Old Joy' was in cinemas last year), but only her first masterpiece.
It just about works as an exercise in empty style, but that doesn't compensate for the small matter of its near-total incomprehensibility.
Saying that a film has too much insight is hardly damning.

The insight-neutral scrag ends of what feels like ten decent documentaries on censorship, semantics, social policy and broadcasting coalesce in this painfully self-satisfied and poorly made 'shock-doc'.
Tense and teasingly ambiguous...
Parker's film feels clouded by his obvious posthumous adoration of the enigmatic Sid. His witnesses are less than credible and his argument feels fumbled.
An extremely impressive and intricate family drama from Japanese director Kiyoshi Kurosawa.
The ironies are always cruel and never comic in British writer-director Duane Hopkins's striking debut, an austere, though empathetic, insightful and technically crisp slice of social realism.
It's a comically inept and unfocused piece of filmmaking, with 'This Is England'-lite period detail attained by what looks like a bring-your-own-costume policy.
It's never enough to establish any sensitivity or social pertinence beyond the trifling tiffs which are playing out on screen.

While it's not animated with the breathless pizazz of a Pixar, 'Despereaux' is all the more affecting and dramatically successful for its contemplative pace and measured delivery of information. A lovely film.

De Sica's neo-realist lodestone may have retained its vitality over the decades, but whatever sense of anger it whipped up in the disgruntled masses of postwar Rome feels lost to the excessively syrupy score.
Paramount's first film in (lavender-hued) VistaVision was this pornographically soppy but, nonetheless, hearty and humorous 1954 festive romp.

The Man from London' lacks the grandiose 'cosmic' intimations of the director's past work, and though it contains many moments of sublime cinematic choreography, this is finally good Tarr, but not great Tarr.
movie_title: The Man From London (A Londoni Férfi) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It's a familiar tale, but one told with gusto, wit and visual flare.
For a film about upholding personal ideals, its glossy packaging and derivative 'will he get the girl?' narrative sell any credibility down the river in favour of affected screwball larks.
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A spunky, impassioned and resourceful doc on the cutthroat world of US college basketball made for a pittance by Adam Yauch.
It's possibly the Coens' least romantic film, which makes the cynical tone a tough pill to swallow, but chances are that you'll be too busy hooting and chuckling idiotically to notice.
For the most part, the affable, loose approach to filming works well in eliciting a genuine worldview from the film's (largely likeable) subjects.
At best, you'll be disappointed; at worst, you'll want to blow up a high school.
Enjoyable as it is to see Gervais trying (and often succeeding) to make something of the mediocre dialogue, it's not enough.

Pitt, toying with his death-wish like some private joke, is eminently watchable in a role with little developmental arc; while Affleck, as his unwitting nemesis, takes his own mysterious integrity right to the grave.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The finale, too, still feels as twisted, bizarre and down-right nightmarish as it did all those years ago.

This laconic artificially quirky debut from Japanese writer-director Fujita Yosuke settles for a rudimentary comic inspection of the dreary existence of a clutch of twentysomethings forced to reject their aspirations in order to face up to adult realities

'Choke' never manages to be as edgy, amusing, insightful or plain messy as you'd hope it would be, especially considering its 'naughty' promotional poster and the distribution of anal beads as a marketing device.
Slight but very pleasant to sit through.
movie_title: Dialogue avec mon jardinier (Conversations with My Gardener) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A film that feels every bit the product of its purportedly ruthless and artistically corrupting milieu.
This frisky if long-winded and derivative French policier never gets off the starting-blocks despite some charismatic performances and intriguingly executed set-pieces.
Sending a flying v-sign right at the splendid Robert Wise original from 1951, this daft and pointless sci-fi remake has very little to recommend it.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: While the genial comic tone and steady torrent of sharp one-liners and social faux pas are effortlessly carried forward from her past work, this is a more subtle, contemplative and mature film.
movie_title: Let it Rain (Parlez-moi de la pluie) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Depardon's palpable sense of respect for his subjects lends the film a geniality that would otherwise have been hard to fabricate.
movie_title: Profils Paysans: la Vie Moderne (Modern Life) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Opportunities to comment on the ethical grey areas of suicide are mostly squandered and, as the pointless digressions begin to pile up, your mind begins to drift from the action on screen.
A decent Parisian thriller that rides on the tails of a calling-card turn from Isabelle Carré as a lovelorn stalker-cum-social-menace who falls in love with her doctor.
There's little here for British eyes.
Nic Cage seems comfortable in the role of the flaming-skulled biker, but the plot holes are too deep even for his Herbie-like arachnid motorcycle to negotiate.
Lurches on a thin line between hyper-ornate space oddity and extended perfume advert.

It reserves singing and dancing for the stage until Jamie Foxx just randomly bursts into verse while strolling down the street. Dreamgirls wants to be Effie but ends up as Deena: thin, smooth, unburdened by a personality.
Essentially, it's a Koyanisquaasti for metal and meat fetishists, and that's no bad thing.
The film's whimsicality makes it a big step back for the director, who shows he has little handle over anything bar garish action set-pieces.

Take away a couple of neatly staged action sequences and you're left with a callously measured slab of US jingoism that deals with the most horrific human tragedies in the most lunk-headed and insulting way possible.
Clearly intended to be viewed through a haze of marijuana smoke, it'd be against the law for us to recommend this film.
movie_title: Tenacious D in The Pick of Destiny (2006)

movie_review_blurb: [A] sporadically hilarious assortment of weapons-grade idiocy.
... a film that never quite equals the sum of its many intriguing parts.

From its non-committal title downwards -- we're a bit worse than ankle deep, but not quite neck deep -- the film includes a final shot that is almost surreal in its implausibility. Waist Deep? More like Deep Waste.
Escapist dilettantes may find A Good Year light, breezy and charming but even the most rudimentary inspection will reveal the film's sickeningly rotten core.
The film says just as much about the state of American politics, the emergence of a mass media and the perceived sanctity of religion as it does about one of the world's lesser-known demagogues.
The film paints with swaggeringly broad strokes, the basic thesis being Lennon = good, government = bad.
Cuts a fine balance between the stylised and the austere.
movie_title: L' Amico di Famiglia (The Family Friend) (Friend of the Family) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: As a whole the film feels trite in the way it trivialises and sentimentalises what it is claiming to be an inherently flawed system.
For a band whose music is suffused with such delicate irony, you'd expect at the very least for there to be a few laughs along the way? There are none. Nothing. Zero.

Beerfest is a film that appears to have been conceived on the back of a beermat and its trashy direction, nonexistent plot and dismal comic mugging would seem to suggest that preparations progressed no further.
Very silly.
As 85-minute testosterone binges go, you could do a whole lot worse.
Favreau gratifyingly prevents the film from becoming a mere maelstrom of CG effects by pushing the brothers' amusing bickering to the fore...
[A] steely 1964 study in the cruel mechanics of illicit love.
One of the great musicals.
This is an undoubtedly modest yet wholly pleasurable tale about the difficulties that come with letting go of youth.
Thoroughly different from To Be or Not To Be but just as exhilarating, it's one of the few films truly justifying Lubitsch's reputation for a 'touch.'
The film is all the more interesting for remaining an eccentric one-of-a-kind that feels every bit the product of its writer-director's unique sensibility and worldview.

Mixing early-'80s nostalgia with mild social anthropology, the film successfully crystallises the optimism and vivacity of the early New York hip hop scene and suggests that film and TV portrayals of the Bronx as a savage and inhospitable hellhole were pe

At once a lament to the ravages of age and an examination of those tiny foibles which separate reality from dramatic artifice, it's a baffling and intricate film which, although light on conventional pleasures, still manages to provoke and beguile.

The numerous, unflinchingly filmed scenes of public and gang rape make this a visceral, if gruelling, experience, especially when juxtaposed with sprawling, beautifully photographed vistas of the Indian deserts and mountain ranges.
Incredibly rich and satisfying. Would easily stand up to multiple viewings.
Vapid, silly and about as scary as an Adam Sandler film.
The shaky camerawork and naturalistic performances mark the film's kinship with quasi-realist sitcoms like The Office and Curb Your Enthusiasm.

Director Mike Binder has twigged on to the fact that if you root Sandler's genially churlish moron act into a more sober foundation, a vulnerable, believable and even lovable character can begin to emerge.
A veritÃ (C) riff on the â~Police Academyâ(TM) series is the idea behind cult US sitcom â~Reno 911!â(TM), which, here, is stretched to breaking point for this puerile punt at cinematic glory.
The paper-thin characters make it feel less like a rounded feature and more like a TV pilot with the promise of more adventures to come.
A nuts-and-bolts document of the annual Air Guitar World Championships which take place in the rural outpost of Oulu in Finland.

With its themes of social displacement subtly and skilfully enmeshed within a pleasingly straightforward shaggy-dog narrative, this is one of those films that runs at you with open arms, and you'll find it very difficult not to succumb.

The photography is of the sort you'd find in any half decent nature documentary, with cloying emphasis placed firmly (and sometimes clumsily) on the idea that our neglectful, selfish and not to mention rampantly capitalist ways are destroying the planet.
Christopher Lee's Dracula is a menacing and complex presence who never lets his fangs and cape dominate.
Sure, the rage is palpable in every cell, but poise and rational thinking are sadly lacking.

The film's best moment by far comes from Eddie's under-the-thumb buddy Mac (Rob Corddry), who advises that the key to a healthy marriage is to 'plaster on a smile and wait patiently for the sweet embrace of death'.
It's a slow, sometimes grating process for an hour or so, but once everyone wises up to their shared heritage, a euphoric celebration of what it means to be a gypsy takes flight.
movie_title: When the Road Bends: Tales of a Gypsy Caravan (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Done no favours by its camera-phone aesthetic, Tough Enough doesn't have much of a sell-by date.
A waste of time. A waste of celluloid. A waste of talent.
An expertly crafted thriller which offers a pessimistic, though deeply rewarding, glimpse of a society being haunted by its own past.
Buckling under the weight of its own hubris, the potentially scandalous premise ends up feeling like a Dan Brown knock-off.
movie_title: A Few Days in September (Quelques jours en septembre) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The film's teary-eyed conclusion is clearly intended to have you punching the air in elation, but the message it delivers will actually leave you feeling quite cold.
movie_title: In the Hands of the Gods (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Despite its undeniable thematic richness, 'Legacy' marks a slight return for Georgian director Géla Babluani.

With its series of tonally awkward plot developments which seem to have been engineered specifically to meet Radcliffe's various portfolio needs, the best that could be said of this is that the actor's next move should be to talk to his agent.
An intriguing set-up spoiled by a clever-clever script, Christophe Beaucarne's migraine-inducing cinematography and performances which are decent, but never gel.
movie_title: A Few Days in September (Quelques jours en septembre) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Performances and script are both first-rate, but what really rivets is how scarily /familiar/ it all feels, from the listless rebound romances to the forced insularity of post-breakup bachelorhood. Superb stuff.
What a poorly developed and resiliently stupid piece of work this is.
Thematically, though, this is an improvement on its forebears, mainly due to the way it deals - much like Scorsese's best work - with the archaic nature of the criminal set.
This wannabe highbrow horror-thriller is a graceless, unfocused piece of work with a central narrative as tonally schizophrenic and wayward as its lead.
Even though the precisely layered, Jenga-tower narrative becomes tiresome towards the end, punches that could have easily been pulled in the final scenes make firm and full contact.
The Seventh Seal is an existentialist masterpiece packed with stunning symbolism and mordant humour. It's also far more accessible that you might think. Go see it. Or else.
Hardly a groundbreaking work, but still a worthy addition to the singular Ghibli canon.
A brave, thoughtful documentary.

French- Algerian director Tony Gatlif shows great skill in capturing local colour and texture, sourcing a rogues' gallery of memorable images from the fog-shrouded environs. He's less successful at giving any direction or meaning to his central pairing's

The direction from Polish New Waver Agnieszka Holland feels more like she's testing a new camera than attempting to capture the nuances of the artistic process, and if we're to believe the script, then all great art derives 'from the gut'.
A deadpan delight that offers further proof of Romania's cinematic ascendance.
movie_title: 12:08 East of Bucharest (A fost sau n-a fost?) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Feran favours intellectual showboating over subtlety, slathering this poorly paced and cripplingly long film in primitive symbolism, meaningful gazes and pensive longueurs.

Though the film falters in terms of its lack of a streamlined narrative, there is no denying that it is packed to the rafters with meaty ideas and characters who are charged with a satisfying moral ambivalence.
It's an admirable first feature from writer-director Niall Heery, but one that never really says anything broader about Irish society or the shackles of fame.
The direction smacks of sadism, especially the obvious glee Gilbey gets from filming violent scenes in close-up and, in the case of the bloody shotgun-to-the-face denouement, in triplicate.
A charismatic and charming film with lots of delightful turns of phrase but it also ends up feeling as frivolous and fleeting as its main protagonist.
The gauche humour of 'Mammuth' camouflages a sweet torch song to the struggles of the working class in the face of private- and public-sector indifference.
Over-extended but nonetheless thought provoking and humorous documentary.
This bruised and brilliant fairy tale is one of the year's true originals.
Beneath its light exterior is not only a neat, if unsubtle, political undercurrent but a rebellious streak about how the allure of firing an RPG outweighs the prospect of retirement.
The camera lingers on the soldiers' smiles and tears and shows the human face of military tactics which reduce people to chess pieces.

If someone laced Wallace and Gromit's stockpile of West Country cheeses with hallucinogens, they might start to show some of the free-associative abandon of the characters in this trippy debut feature...
movie_title: A Town Called Panic (Panique au village) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Reeves's direction lunges more resolutely for the mainstream jugular, but that's no bad thing.
Feels all but indistinguishable from the thousands of similar films that have blazed a trail before it.

Moving but never sentimental, ambient but rigorously focused, this is an assured, refreshingly simple film where the dramas and responsibilities of parenthood exist inside a bubble of blissed-out tropicalia.
The film is made up of half-formed sketches in which Phoenix comes across like a childish crank who's escaped from his soap box at Speakers' Corner.
If there's a problem with the film, it's the idea that two people would instinctively choose to immerse themselves in unbroken role play.
[A] snarling but predictable survival tale...
Again, it's worth the price of admission alone to spend time in the company of Sweden's premiere bisexual emo-sleuth...
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The focus here is less on creating a credible set of characters and motives than on manufacturing an excuse to have Jolie leapfrog between high-speed lorries.
Tati thought anything could be funny, and while Chomet runs with that idea as a director, he challenges it as a storyteller.
If you like watching men with no necks thumping each other, this could be your Citizen Kane.
Sly, understated and ruthlessly focused, the functional yet elegant photography by Sabine Lancelin enhances the film's ironic kick.
movie_title: Eccentricities of a Blonde-haired Girl (Singularidades de uma Rapariga Loura) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Assayas returns with a hulking, seething, intermittently sublime, five-and-a-half hour film in which he manages to draw together elements from both of these distinct styles.
Tetro is a movie filled with splashes of brilliance rather than being a plain brilliant movie.
It's cheeky and confident, maybe one of the director's finest, and its loopy final line is the cryptic cherry on this oddball gâteau.

Nothing feels like it's been properly thought through, highlighted by the fact that Nighy's 'super assassin' goes about his business by merely opening fire on a crowded market place (using a silencer, of course!).
The film's big strength is its unwillingness to dish out easy answers
movie_title: The Girl on the Train (La Fille du RER) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The one element that lifts this above utter tedium is the presence of Stephen Merchant as tooth-fairy administrator Tracy. That he manages to come away with his dignity intact is testament to his skill as a comedian.
Palestinian director Elia Suleiman's most eloquent and moving feature to date.

With its excessive levels of casual racism, sexism and homophobia, the film feels like nothing more than a rejected 'Derek and Clive' sketch that's been stripped of eloquence and irony and calibrated instead for cheap, leery laughs.
The movie has vim and spark in abundance and the filmmakers are canny enough to let the cast play to their strengths.
An astute study of amour fou and a cautionary tale about how the worship of false idols can lead to personal and national collapse.
Even those who shrug at his combative style of humour won't be able to deny that this is a model of detailed and distanced biographical filmmaking.
This latest from writer-director Jared Hess is another unsavoury stew of kitsch juvenilia that furthers the rot that set in between his first two films...
La Danse is an example of cinema at its most musical, an awe-inspiring celebration of body, mind and movement.
movie_title: La Danse -- Le Ballet de l'Opera de Paris (2009)

movie_review_blurb: More than ever, Bujalski comes across like the natural heir to someone like Eric Rohmer, an artist who creates intricate, perceptive and artful cinema that rejects unnecessary style and contrivance.
Deftly moderating her patented eye-rolling poseur shtick, Page delivers her most charismatic and least divisive performance to date as Bliss Cavendar, aka Babe Ruthless.
It blazed a bloody trail for the much-loved slasher cycle, but it also assured us that a B-movie could be A-grade in quality and innovation.
Imagine if you salvaged a grubby VHS tape off the roadside only to discover it contained outtakes from an amateur Jackass knock-off.

The vitriol and hurt coursing through this prickly, scandalous pre-code melodrama from 1932 may wrong-foot those who had director Frank Capra pegged as head cheerleader for good ol' American democracy and cheery, affirmative humanist values.

This cliché-ridden war story from Indonesian director Yadi Sugandi suggests that the Dutch occupation of Indonesia in the post-war period played out like a tawdry TV movie made with the help of a dressing-up box and lots of fake blood and fireworks.
There is a sweet chemistry between Depardieu and Casadesus, but their wry interactions are lost within a rambling, frothy non-story that aims squarely for the heart over the head.
movie_title: La tête en friche (My Afternoons with Margueritte) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Terrible orch-rock soundtrack aside, it makes for an engrossing if hollow romp.
You'll end up baffled that a film built on such shaky foundations can end up being so impossibly sweet.
The film is built as a long crescendo, opening at a level of considered, Zen-like reflection and ending with a prolonged cacophony of elaborate, town-wide annihilation.
Manages to say more about man's relationship with dogs in a single, lush frame than 'Marley and Me' would if it were to run on a loop until the end of time.
So-called 'slow cinema', if executed with delicacy, has the power to exert a trance-like hold over us, but this one falls flat at every dreary hurdle.
Loach has made a film uncluttered by an obvious director's stamp, peopled by sympathetic characters and driven by a desire to say something about the world without losing sight of human experience.
Delivering an absolute minimum of context, the film dares us to forge our own reasons for rooting for or despising this savage.
Offers a rousing reminder of the power (and eccentricities) of the pissed-off proletariat.
It's scatty and fast paced, and director Neil Burger employs some Gaspar Noé-style, bad-trip CG effects to heighten the mood.
A tougher and more genre-inspired work that we'd expect from social-realist doyen Loach.
There's plenty of ambiguous intellectual heft lurking behind the curtain of mediocrity - so it's a pity it feels like it was dashed off in a few hours one afternoon.
movie_title: You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger (2010)

movie_review_blurb: An absorbing, unhysterical thriller that largely rejects the clichés of the genre.

The usual string of hackneyed and largely laugh-free set-ups involving vulgar chat-up lines, hash brownies and a mad, jealous guy with a crowbar, all seemingly purpose-honed to appeal to devotees of 'The Hangover'.
The performances of the young cast attain an affecting blend of reticence and hope, but it's Tran's fastidious technique that nudges the film into the realms of greatness.

Nolfi began his career as a writer, which perhaps explains why he tries to keep the action character-driven: the sweet chemistry between Damon and Blunt does at least make their romantic, potentially existence-threatening bond credible.
With no culture-clash cliché left unplundered, Andy DeEmmony sets his camera to autopilot for a film which never decides who or what it's about.

It's a hilarious and informative movie, and in the pantheon of films about filmmaking, it strikes a neat balance between the operatic neuroses of '8 1/2' and the warm, pastel-hued nostalgia of 'Singin' in the Rain'.
Perfect hokum for those who don't mind having their heart strings strummed like a banjo.
Apichatpong doesn't use his camera to stress what we should be looking at, thinking or hearing. He uses long takes and subtle edits to generate moods, atmospheres and feelings.
movie_title: Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A more apt title would be 'The Girl Who Sat Quietly in a Dimly Lit Room'.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: For a film whose stock in trade are tongue-in-cheek reversals of comic-book cliché, it too often settles for trite audience-pleasing.
Its rambling structure, peppered with lyrical, magical-realist asides, may not be to all tastes, but there's a sense that Gondry wants this to be more than an eccentric personal portrait...
[A] workaday psychological thriller which, although decently crafted, lacks even a scintilla of subtlety or ambition.
The film's nostalgic design is subtle enough not to dampen the seriously sinister atmospherics.
A pleasant movie, but no more.
movie_title: It's Kind of a Funny Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: [Gondry] has done a stellar job of putting his wacky auteurial stamp on a comedy which is only semi-coherent but still very funny and impeccably fashioned.
The title is marketing 101: how to sell a schlocky, throwback genre picture on the back of the past glories of a director who once dealt solely in amped-up, literate and ballsy entertainment...
That the finale ends up being trite is a shame, but the long, gentle jaunt to arrive there is a pleasurable one.
Contrived, mawkish and mirthless, this feels like it was made by people who haven't had any meaningful human contact for years.
Small details are magnified by Philibert's long, quiet takes, and Nénette's mundane human characteristics make us consider our own lives and how we relate to the natural world.
Even if it doesn't quite gel, it's admirable that a film made of such weird ingredients is even vaguely palatable.
It's perhaps asking a bit much to read it as anything more than a claustrophobic portrait of sexual danger, but it still fulfils that highly specific brief with blood-splashed gusto.
Making no effort to be original, exciting, witty or even vaguely plausible, it may pass the time as sparkly fodder for 12-year-old boys with plenty of sugar in their bloodstream.
This is imbecilic hooey of the rarest breed.

If camp comedy capering (don't call it a social satire!) isn't your thing, it's worth the ticket to see Monroe's iconic and flawlessly choreographed performance of Diamonds Are a Girl's Best Friend (TM): a perfect four minutes of film.
Unlike its more lively predecessor, this is more interested in dissecting the criminal mindset.
The film has a lot to say about the effect of technology on teenage interaction, how schools repress individuality and how sexual awakening causes, rather than relieves, teenage angst.
A luminous musical about dreams, romance and destiny which lovingly reworks the classic Hollywood 'putting on a show' template into an essay on the emotional rollercoaster ride that is movie-going.
movie_title: The Young Girls of Rochefort (Les Demoiselles de Rochefort) (1968)

movie_review_blurb: Cassel injects a jolt of wild energy and ambiguity into what could easily have been another flatulent, apologist gangster epic.
movie_title: Mesrine: Part 1 (Killer Instinct) and Part 2 (Public Enemy #1) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This charming, affectionately crafted and gleefully unfashionable comic miniature from writing/directing troupe Abel, Gordon and Romy slips down a treat.
Any one of these stories, if properly fleshed out and shorn of contrivance, would have made for a perfectly serviceable film. Instead, we have lots of hysterical little bits of nothing much.
'Once Upon a Time...' now looks like an over-cooked mess of style, metaphor and reference.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in the West (1968)

movie_review_blurb: They may as well have called this one 'Mis-Matched Sham Wedding Comedy #57513' for all the effort it makes to shake new life out of a tattered genre.
Occasionally marred by contrivance and a crude internal logic that doesn't bear close scrutiny, 'Frozen River' works best as a knuckle-gnawing, blue-collar genre thriller.
With its hokey, flashback-heavy plotting, unadventurous camera use and a clutch of cloyingly earnest performances, it comes across like an irony-free, mid-season episode of 'Xena: Warrior Princess'.
Poignant, lightly philosophical and beautifully performed.
Jeffs makes a good fist of the direction and Blunt proves that she can do comedy, but it's Adams's comforting, charismatic central turn which really gives the film its lift.
It may tickle a type of hardened horror connoisseur, but most will want a shower after seeing it.
movie_title: Encarnação do Demônio (Devil's Reincarnation) (Embodiment of Evil) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Johnny Kervorkian sets up the film nicely, but by the end, your worst fears are realised when it climaxes in the most anodyne way possible.

As well-intentioned as it is deathly dull, this moody, London-set indie attempts to fuse a sprawling, right-on social agenda with a tenderly wrought mismatched romance and doesn't manage to say anything interesting about either.
The film is raw and confident, but it's a little shallow, too.
In 'Sugar', the pair skilfully dismantle the timeworn themes, characters and story patterns of the conventional sports movie and then reassemble them as a rich, socially astute realist drama.
Though not without its moments, this latest tale of wartime derring-do rarely dares to enter uncharted territory.

It's all given a much-needed shot of credibility by the strength of the writing and the subtlety of the directing. Losey is a talent to watch, and 'The Hide' makes for one hell of a Hollywood calling card.
This is as fully formed and unique a debut movie as you could ever hope to see.
The maths element of the film, which on the surface is its USP, feels like dressing on a taut but tawdry genre thriller.
A wild-eyed, everything-in-the-pot cross-processing of artistic, cinematic, political and personal concerns, where the story stutters, splinters and infuriates its way to an explosive finale.
movie_title: Pierrot le Fou (Pierrot Goes Wild) (Crazy Pete) (1969)

movie_review_blurb: Troell's film meshes scenes of high drama and silent contemplation while the milky, sepia-toned Super16 photography lends the images an exquisite, tactile quality.

movie_review_blurb: Awkward pauses and gestures and moments of self-examination give it a rich texture. It's a lovely work, sad and funny. A melancomedy, if you will.

While Cyrus's droll performance (Miley's not Billy Ray's) deserves better material, this is still amply entertaining.
It's a terrible film, so blithely wrong-headed in its execution that some scenes are quite entertaining in an 'is this really happening?' kind of way.

It's a small, well-rounded movie that you'd be hard pressed to find fault with, achieving its modest goals with subtle aplomb while whipping up humour and empathy from Antoine's rapport with his doddery clientele.
movie_title: Le fils de l'épicier (The Grocer's Son) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Writer-director-actor Jacques Nolot (below) delivers a bold, searching and open-hearted turn as the subject of this confessional study of life as an elderly gay gent in the French capital.

There's no denying that this is a single-note film, but it's a note of considerable emotional clout.
A politically naïve and protracted slice of dewy-eyed nostalgia.

Itâ(TM)s not enough to allow the film to rise above its guilty-until-proven-innocent conception of justice. Reprehensible, then, but what fun!

Shabbily filmed and poorly acted, its lone positive is a compellingly awful turn by Alfie (brother of Lily) Allen, whose bumbling, velour-tracksuited date-rapist is the sleaziest thing youâ(TM)ll see this year.

movie_review_blurb: With its unlovely DV aesthetic and cheesy midi-synth score, the film has clearly been put together on the cheap. Yet it's also severely lacking in the fundamentals.

movie_review_blurb: Bowers's play-it-straight attitude towards the material combined with the crisp, if unspectacular, animation doesn't allow 'Astro Boy' a moment to bob its head above the ever-swelling digimation pack.

Seeing the film ten years later - and in the mighty shadow of Pixar's recent masterpieces - the film feels a little chaotic, safe, tired on its feet.
A garish and poorly filmed chop-socky frolic that makes about as much sense as an Escher painting viewed through Vaseline-smudged Ray-Bans.

A work of dazzling formal discipline that riffs on the simple notion of repetition and variation.

CBeebies if Ronnie Corbett was artistic director; filmmaking by committee, if that committee were made up of the esteemed members of Coventry City Council and chaired by Lenny Henry.
