I guess a summer special effects blockbuster with plot development is too much to ask for. Maybe I should have my own wiring examined.
The most fun you'll have in theaters this summer
contradicts and betrays its previously positive messages about feminine independence by making Mia settle for a man she loves only for his looks
Not even a paddle can save this ship from sinking.
fails miserably to frighten, enlighten, or entertain
Unfortunately, Cellular fails fairly miserably as a thriller because we soon learn that any jam Ryan finds himself in will easily get resolved in his favor.
Too bad the real Wimbledon never looks this interesting.
Dizzying handheld camera shots make us part of every hard-hitting tackle
Despite opening to the tune of "It's the Most Wonderful Time of the Year," the timing of Surviving Christmas could not feel worse
highly entertaining while packing a giant emotional punch
takes the Wayans' brand of gross-out humor to a whole new low
Book a one-way flight on the original Phoenix instead.
McCall does a skillful job of reconstructing this hipster-centric game, though much of the proceedings still come off as one of those "you had to be there" affairs.
It's hard to go wrong with a movie about famed drag queen Divine, and director Jeffrey Schwarz certainly doesn't in "I Am Divine," a serious documentary about this gloriously trashy trailblazer.

"Laurence Anyways" is a formidable display of French Canadian director Xavier Dolan's prodigious talents, but also a case study of a young talent still finding his way to greatness.He'll get there one day, soon, but this film doesn't quite do it.
Orser, to his credit, never resorts to psychobabble, cheap sentiment or emotional shortcuts.
"Out in the Dark" isn't a political film by any stretch, but the intrigue and prejudices of the Arab-Israeli conflict certainly fuel the romance and thrills of this entertaining, taut movie.
A revenge-fantasy Western that wants to luxuriate in its B-movie roots but suffers from dull direction and an even duller central performance.
A film about grief and Christmas cheer that reveals a big heart without pulling its darkly comic punches.

This is a multilayered film that not only exposes a man's contradictions - a do-gooder narcissist; a thoughtful, delusional activist - but also speaks volumes about the fringes on both sides of the political spectrum.
Uses no narrators, talking heads or fancy graphics to tell its devastating story. It doesn't need to.
On paper, Chomsky and Gondry seem like an eternal mismatch, but these two very smart people share an odd but genuine chemistry ...
movie_title: Is the Man Who Is Tall Happy?: An Animated Conversation with Noam Chomsky (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Despite the solid performances from Washington and Richmond, we get a little bored and begin waiting to see what will happen (or, more precisely, how the filmmakers will handle the ending) ...
What makes this well-edited film compelling are the stories of the patients and the agonizing moral quandaries that the doctors express in doing their work.
a dramedy that keeps you guessing where the main character is going (emotionally and physically) as he drifts from one odd situation to the next.
Dupieux has to be applauded for creating a unique universe, but sometimes he seems stuck in it - to the point where we feel we're not always in on the joke.
From beginning to end, it's a very human story.

More of a tribute than a hard-hitting piece of American filmmaking, which is too bad, because the subject - the imprisonment of ex-Black Panther figure Mumia Abu-Jamal - deserves a thorough, serious examination.
This is a film way ahead of its time.

A tale of young, vapid, sexually insatiable Z-listers in Hollywood had the credentials to be deliciously awful fun but almost every time something tawdry (and potentially interesting) is about to happen, the film pulls its punches and leaves the action.

As you watch the film, you'll be amazed how the world of the Internet turns the recent into the ancient: In a matter of only a few years, a world-changing digital event like Napster has become so last century.
It not only delivers astonishing, suspenseful footage that makes it a legitimate thriller, but also serves up thoughtful meditations about using wild animals for our own entertainment.

"Big Star: Nothing Can Hurt Me" is no doubt going to please fans of the cult rock band, but the rest of us may feel like outsiders - not put off by the proceedings, really, but somewhat mystified as to what all the fuss is about.
movie_title: Big Star: Nothing Can Hurt Me (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Highly entertaining and informative look at the war on drugs, offers a tongue-in-cheek manual of how to become a cartel leader. But it's not just a glib exercise & confronts the implications of a drug policy that many would agree is a disaster.
movie_title: How To Make Money Selling Drugs (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The sadistic proceedings here are pointless, and not very scary.
"Somm," an inside look at wine stewards, attempts to unveil the secrecy of the master sommelier exam, and though the results aren't always vintage, there is some pleasant tasting to be had here.
A sometimes interesting, sometimes head-scratching movie that pays homage to the old ways of the sound mixing world and to the "giallo" genre of horror that was prominent in Italy during the 1970s.

American cinema has been churning out slacker movies for what seems like eons, so it's refreshing to report that Somebody Up There Likes Me enlivens the genre with a welcome breath of imagination, wit and charm.
The film's structural flaws appear to stem from the lack of access to oil industry titans and the other usual suspects. (To be fair, the filmmakers tried.)
At first, it appears that "G.B.F." is going to be a gay send-up of "Mean Girls." But this cleverly scripted, crowd-pleasing teen comedy proves to be more than that.
Perhaps most surprising, even the festival footage is ho-hum. We feel a distance, instead of being flies on the wall. (Or should we say, on the desert floor?)

This is not a film that will be remembered for its high drama, but it wouldn't be surprising to see it studied in future years by scholars trying to gain perspective on a calamity that almost brought the world to itsknees.
movie_title: Hank: Five Years From the Brink (2014)

movie_review_blurb: This film is bound to help boost Campbell's legacy as a performer and an artist, making classic tunes such as "Gentle on My Mind" and "Wichita Lineman" more indelible than ever.

Netzer crafts not only a chilling story of family dysfunction, but also an illuminating look into the corruption and decay of the Romanian bourgeoisie - without ever overplaying his hand. It all appears so effortless, when in fact it's so skillful.
"National Gallery," a meandering trip through the famed London art institution, has many sublime scenes - and some tedious ones, too.
"A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night" is a wildly inventive Iranian vampire movie that grabs you by the throat with its dark, moody style, pulsating soundtrack and offbeat love story.
movie_title: A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It's not a groundbreaking thesis, but we still get a fascinating tour of a town that may never be the same again.

At the end of the day, Rawal is trying to make a point more than telling a story. It's hard to blame him, because we've avoided this shameful problem for too long, and for a change, someone's actually offering a reasonable solution.
This is a brave film, a unique way of exploring a taboo topic.
This film is so bereft of conflict and seems so intent on celebrating commune life and the sisterhood and the joys of midwifery that it glosses over important issues.
movie_title: Birth Story: Ina May Gaskin and The Farm Midwives (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Ostlund has a keen eye for human behavior that exacerbates marital discord and dysfunction.
One need not be a jazz aficionado to enjoy this film. All that's required is a smile.
"Young Ones" is a futuristic look at a world with little water, but the most barren thing in this Western-sci-fi flick is the character development.
This threatens to get precious at times, but Morro is a great character, and for the most part, the film is animal friendly and environmentally serious.
Moss was basically a one-man production crew, which explains how he was able to film such intimate, painful conversations. His work is haunting - one of the best documentaries of the year.

The final 20 minutes are the strongest, when Harmon comes to some realizations about his behavior. Unless you're the biggest of fans, you may find yourself wishing that the film had reached this point earlier.
A film that works both for followers and for those interested in knowing what yoga is truly about. Hint: It's not about six-pack abs.
These women are living life to the fullest - and they are inviting us to do the same.

One thing is clear: This documentary is more of a coronation than a portrait of a divisive figure. It would have been nice to hear the voices of anti-Hill figures who were involved in the proceedings.

This a film that leaves many unanswered questions, but it's nonetheless satisfying, because it resonates emotionally and offers a ray of hope that the human spirit has the ability to trump entrenched political perspectives.
Most of these musical interludes are reasonably engaging, even if the storytelling threatens to become one-note.
Crass, vulgar, and brilliant.
The Man on Her Mind, a belabored, un-whimsical romantic comedy, is a case study of what can go wrong when adapting a stage play into a movie.
This story about a real-life scandal from the 1950s - one that would light up the Internet if it happened today - comes off as a tepid, polite exercise, a movie afraid of its own shadow.
This is a film blessed with excellent footage and plenty of nice moments.
Director Amat Escalante and his gifted cinematographer Lorenzo Hagerman have crafted a powerful film that feels and looks a lot like Steven Soderbergh's Oscar-winning Traffic.
This Italian romantic dramedy needs a little room service, because the romance, comedy and drama are sometimes in short supply.
Paranoia, a ho-hum thriller about corporate spying in the high-tech world, comes off as a lot more preposterous than paranoid, and it takes no more than a few frames for the eye rolling to commence.
It all feels very real.
Code Black... succeeds in its most important mission: taking us to ground zero of the health care mess.
The film not only canonizes its hero - who committed suicide amid a nasty federal indictment against him - but also brushes aside any big-picture concerns about national security and Internet piracy.
movie_title: The Internet's Own Boy: The Story of Aaron Swartz (2014)

movie_review_blurb: This is a creative, ambitious project that delivers, thanks in no small part to a director who knows about dance - and to a cast that can both dance and act.
The images of heaven somehow diminish the impact of the boy's experience, perhaps because heaven is just too profound for anyone to film.
"Interior. Leather Bar." is a Rubik's Cube of a movie, an intriguing, layered puzzle that isn't easily solved.
It's right up there with the best rock documentaries. That is, if you can call it a documentary.
Different - and chillingly effective.
Quote not available.
This is warts and all, with the emphasis on the warts.
This isn't exactly a popcorn movie. I'm not sure it's even a movie, as much as an edgy art installation.
As the old cliche goes, you will not have another moviegoing experience quite like this one all year.
"Shut Up, Little Man! An Audio Misadventure" has to rank right up there as one of the oddest films of the year. But odd in a very good way.
In writer-director Rashaad Ernesto Green's assured hands, "Gun Hill Road" manages somehow to be gritty, delicate, in your face and nuanced at the same time.
This emotionally affecting documentary will move you like few films this year, thanks to a luminous heroine and an unlikely but appealing trio who work tirelessly to release her from prison.
Ultimately, the film gets too clever and confusing for its own good, while the slow pacing zaps momentum from the story (and the story within the story).
Crayton Robey's documentary is a time capsule of the burgeoning gay rights era. It has poignant moments that sneak up on you. And sometimes, well, it's just trashy fun.
In a deceptively low-key manner, Danish filmmaker Michael Madsen has beautifully crafted one of the most provocative movies of the year.
A must-see movie that could have used a sharper edge.
It not only evocatively captures the Russian spirit and the yearnings of a generation, but it also masterfully chronicles the historic collapse of the Soviet Union and its complex aftermath.
Quote not available.
movie_title: Nightmares in Red, White and Blue (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Without giving away too much, I offer two words of advice: Brace yourself.
Although this always interesting film doesn't quite come together at the end - it couldn't decide exactly what it wanted to say - McCormick has done a lot of things right.
movie_title: Some Days Are Better Than Others (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Can best be described as a compelling mess.
One fascinating tribute.
movie_title: William S. Burroughs: A Man Within (2010)

movie_review_blurb: If you can weather some slow patches (and there are plenty), this boldly original, oddly affecting meditation on the afterlife will reward you with moments of profundity that will linger in your consciousness (or subconsciousness) for a lifetime...
movie_title: Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Soldini brings us vivid characters, and gets all the details right, from the humdrum rhythms of marriage to the unglamorous milieu of working-class Milan.
"Four Lions" is a daring, brilliantly conceptualized film, but like the bumbling bombers of the title, the execution tends to be hit-and-miss.
It is one of the best pictures of the year.
Doesn't rank as a great film, but it's difficult to take your eyes off it, as you wonder what impossibly bizarre thing might happen next.
Confirms two things that hardly need confirming: The Egyptian capital is a breathtaking metropolis, and Patricia Clarkson is one of the best actors in the world.
This is a poetic, romantic, emotionally complex film that sneaks up on you, particularly in its final scenes.
This purported whodunit thriller never solves its main mystery: How and why did this film get made in the first place?
One of the most observant -- and enigmatic -- movies of the year.
Without the director resorting to sentiment, we experience the growing bond between father and son. Their happiness is infectious.

It's not every day that you run into a street artist, petty thief, porn illustrator, lesbian fiction ghost writer, world traveler, graphic novelist, muralist, sex addict and born-again Christian, all rolled into one.
movie_title: Dirty Hands: The Art & Crimes of David Choe (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It may not be the greatest of cinematic exercises, and it often feels contrived, but this documentary somehow is enlightening, ridiculous, foreboding and funny at the same time.
An earnest crowd-pleaser that could have used an extra helping of dramatic tension -- but it succeeds by placing us in an interesting world with characters who are impossible not to root for.
The deft editing makes all this easy to follow, and the strong ensemble cast, not to mention the unpredictable story, keeps us engaged.
This evocative, deceptively rich slice of life has its own voice, and it never fails to be enjoyable for several reasons.
From its joyously rambunctious opening number to its bittersweet yet ultimately uplifting finale, a catchy song is never far away, but neither is a deep, universal thought to keep you on your toes.
It is mostly impressionistic - but, wow, some of those impressions really pack a punch.

Lu Chuan makes this feature film soar by telling the story both through the eyes of the Japanese occupiers and the defenseless Chinese civilians in the ancient capital. It makes the savagery all the more senseless.
On the surface, it sounds like a boring, esoteric day in law class, but in truth, it plays out like a riveting session in court ...
A charming, aimless film about the aimless. It plays like a nuanced MTV reality show (an oxymoron, perhaps, but you get the idea).
Director Sean Baker's fascinating, impossible-to-categorize film relies on handheld cameras, improvised dialogue, jump cuts and a very photogenic arena, the city's wholesale fashion district.
Plays like a metaphysical Moscow version of "Mad Men" - on acid.

It's a story that's been told countless times, but first-time director Bavo Defurne has such an assured hand and visual flair (much credit also belongs to cinematographer Anton Mertens) that everything seems fresh and new.
You will either laugh or cringe, depending on your enjoyment of comic melodrama (the kind view) or distaste for overindulged actors (the not-so-kind view).
A mean-spirited piece of mumblecore that tries to provoke you, but only succeeds in boring you.
We've all heard the arguments many times before. Here, it's between the lines that count.

This film doesn't provide a lot of bars or charts or fancy graphics. Just cue cards to give us perspective. And surprisingly beautifully shot scenes of an intimate family drama that takes place over a season of growing cotton.
Artfully - perhaps too artfully - illustrates the transformation of the Motor City from a middle-class utopia to an urban nightmare of blight, crime and fleeing residents.
A play-it-safe, by-the-numbers kind of documentary - yet somehow it gets under your skin.
A harsh yet delicate tale of two New Yorkers whose co-dependent relationship is fueled by sex, drugs and complex longings for companionship.
The namesake of the wacky, yet substantial documentary "Cane Toads: The Conquest" is not a creature to be taken lightly, even if the film (and the audience) has plenty of fun at his expense.
Though the movie isn't wildly original, its time-tested, artistic mantra of "just go out there and do it" is hard to resist.
"Yossi" offers genuine pleasures (even some of Fox's trademark musical numbers).
Your view of the film may hinge on whether you can accept the ethics of his fakery.
A lot of tension and buildup leads us to ... well, it's hard to say.

Both old-fashioned and modern, both funny and melancholic, the witty, heartfelt "Celeste and Jesse Forever" is populated by moments that at first appear all too familiar, then turn out to surprise you.
Pretty much like the man himself: solid, sometimes flawed and seriously unflashy.

It charges out of the gate in Indiana Jones style, employing so many plot twists that you may need a scorecard. Then after an hour or so, it settles into an intimate, character-driven drama, before its low-key yet thought-provoking finale.
[It] doesn't offer up a ton of narrative surprises, but there is plenty going on the screen to keep you engaged - and visually stimulated.

An absorbing, educational, sad, humorous and ultimately uplifting film that is easily accessible and entertaining even for those not familiar with the grunge rock scene, or with the considerable role that Schemel played in that milieu.
It tackles existential struggles that many of us grapple with - and the film industry virtually ignores - while doing so in an entertaining way.
It's claustrophobic, tense, ultraviolent -- and fun.
Rarely do films offer such intimate insights into the inner workings of a true artist.
movie_title: The Ballad of Genesis and Lady Jaye (2012)

movie_review_blurb: [Dalle] commands the screen from the first frame, when she hosts a late-night, outdoor drinking fest and babbles on about how mathematics - and not words - create order.
This is a very intelligent, well-plotted story - and my hunch is that we have not seen the last of our heroes.
movie_title: Fullmetal Alchemist: The Sacred Star of Milos (2012)

movie_review_blurb: An astonishing, haunting, sensual, lyrical, bleak and ultimately beautiful road-trip movie.
As fascinating - and at times oblique - as the famous couple themselves.
movie_title: Eames: The Architect And The Painter (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The filmmakers deserve credit for delving into a topic that has received scant attention in the movies, but a lot of it is old news (except, perhaps, for younger viewers).
A strange story. A strange world. And strange characters doing even stranger things.
Barker-Froyland has more than romance on her mind, and she crafts a nuanced ending to the story that feels right. We just wish we could have gotten to know these folks a little better along the way.
Watching this film will leave you with some dispiriting questions about America and its values.
Sandel's film has heart, some good laughs and a decent message. In this age of cyberbullying, that's nothing to scoff at.
One of those films where the whole is not quite as good as the parts. There are plenty of laughs and fun characters to keep us engaged, but they don't add up to an emotionally satisfying story.
Often dazzling, yet somehow distant.
Mastretta gets considerable mileage out of her bilingual concept, but it's never forced, and we enjoy being in both of Clara's worlds.

A cringe-inducing, bloated story about a bratty tennis star in search of her long-lost father ... painful to watch, because it feels like a passion project in which everyone is trying to serve aces, yet all we get are double faults.
"Monster Trucks" feels less like an ordeal than a well-intentioned misfire made by intelligent people.

The character development and plot in "Evolution" are minimal, and its bold themes aren't fully explored, but as an exercise in creepy atmospherics, this is one of the most accomplished films of the year.
We feel the bewilderment of the parochial yet decent residents, the helplessness of the well-intentioned yet overwhelmed rescuers, and the anguish and disorientation of the refugees.

Perrin and Cluzaud struggle to find a footing in their vast cinematic terrain. We never quite know why we are seeing a particular animal at any given point, and none of the creatures - or the humans, for that matter - has any impact on us.
Director James Watkins keeps things reasonably interesting, but his characters are not well drawn, which hinders the buddy dynamic between Mason and Briar.
We get too many slapstick set pieces and extraneous subplots that bog down the proceedings.
This is a film more about the sacredness of our memories than the evil ways of gentrification, but skilled director Kleber Mendonca Filho is clearly interested in both.

Chess is not the most visual of games, but Nair makes these competitions come alive. She also gets the most out of her mostly nonprofessional African cast, not to mention her two stars, Oyelowo and Nyong'o.
We keep waiting for the film to wash over us, and it never quite does.
The exquisitely shot "Demon" is not gory or particularly scary, but it has its fair share of chills.
Working in the film's favor is that the JT saga remains relevant today, in this age of Internet alter egos, blurred-reality shows and our continued obsession with fame and celebrity.
This is a movie that doesn't quite come together, on both thematic and tonal levels, even though most individual scenes are competently acted and engaging.
"Ixcanul" provides a window into a culture that we rarely see. But it's not just an anthropological study - it has a powerful story to tell, too.
It's mostly engaging, even if the proceedings get a tad burdened with awkward tonal shifts and subplots.
Takes a tough subject and amiably rides it out into the Outback sunset. It's a wry film that remains upbeat without betraying its rough-around-the-edges cast of characters.
At the end of the day, "Wiener-Dog" seems to be saying that life is mundane, then you die. It's not the stuff of Hallmark cards, but Solondz has a way of making it palatable.
It critiques our obsession with models and beauty and style, even as it obsesses about those very same things. There is a lot of flash, but little substance.

It's John Ford's "The Searchers," French style, but director Thomas Bidegain has given the premise a unique flavor, crafting a fine, timely screenplay that skips over some years of the story but allows us to fill in the blanks.
It's a testament to Traitel's performance that he makes such a vivid impression, because the script offers the actors little in the way of character development.
Though the narrative is threadbare, the concept of the story - girls at the rec center are inexplicably suffering from strange seizures - keeps us engaged.
The aerial cinematography is breathtaking: We can feel the fragility of the planet, but also its power to heal - if only we give it a chance.
There's no arguing that there's a clever concept that anchors the "Now You See Me" franchise - expect more sequels - but razzle-dazzle and the art of misdirection can take you only so far.
All in all, it's a mess, but in some weird way, it keeps you watching.
"Ma Ma" clearly wants to be tearjerker, but there's no need to have tissues handy for this one.
Out of the war rubble emerges one of the most irresistible movies of the year.
An education about Israel's surprisingly diverse cultures, and an exploration of how social, demographic and economic forces have propelled the country's food scene from the bland to the exciting.
Like the Masters Tournament and Masterpiece Theater rolled into one: beautiful fairways, polite gentlemen, and a little drama every now and then.
Drag queens from around the world will eagerly await their chance to play these roles in the near future, whether on stage or at midnight movie screenings.
This is a movie that derives most of its suspense on whether a piece of paper will be signed, not a strong basis for dramatic tension.
An engaging, revelatory slice of life, In Between follows three Palestinian women in Tel Aviv - kind of a Sex and the City and Girls for the Arab set.
The ending has a feeling of inevitability but is nonetheless shocking, a tragedy resulting from an original sin that haunts, and will continue to haunt.
In the end, it's left to Shaye to carry the film, and she does so with aplomb. The "Insidious" franchise may be running out of places to go, but Shaye appears to be just getting started.
The quietly stirring, exquisitely photographed Columbus is an art house gem that beautifully illuminates not only the architecture of a small Indiana town, but also the characters who inhabit it.
The camerawork and editing often leave something to be desired. Most of the time, this doesn't matter, because we are drawn into the mystery.
This is a movie that has lots of magic, in more ways than one.
This is not a movie about coming out and the collateral damage that ensues. It's a universal tale about giving yourself over to love, even when you seem hopelessly broken.
This is a film that manages to be simple yet thought-provoking, sad yet comforting, and anguished yet tranquil. In short, a work of art.
The best thing about "All I See Is You" is that it's not afraid to experiment. But it's an experiment that went wrong, a film in which ambiguity trumps complexity.
None of the subjects - or themes - end up making much of an impression.

Weiwei doesn't break any new ground in covering the global refugee crisis, but he vividly illustraes - in straightforward yet artistic terms - the scale of the problem without compromising the dignity or humanity of the survivors.
It's a rousing, feel-good story about overcoming barriers, even when the challenges - poverty, lack of medical access - are inherently bleak.

"Take Every Wave: The Life of Laird Hamilton" doesn't exactly wade deep into the psyche of the legendary surfer, but his spectacularly filmed exploits on the water are awfully fun to watch, even for those not immersed in the sport.
movie_title: Take Every Wave: The Life of Laird Hamilton (2017)

movie_review_blurb: ... filmmakers Jennifer Kroot and Bill Weber have captured that zest with a joyous filmmaking style of their own: breezy editing, fun '70s graphics and the use of great archival footage from the city's past. It's all great fun, from beginning to end.
movie_title: The Untold Tales of Armistead Maupin (2017)

movie_review_blurb: "Francofonia," a powerful cinematic essay on how art and war are irrevocably intertwined, has an ideal canvas and time peg for its philosophical musings: the Louvre Museum during the Nazi occupation of France.
For all its breathless action, mind-boggling gadgets and stylized fight sequences, nothing much happens in the comic-book spy caper "Kingsman: The Golden Circle."
As the carnage mercilessly piles up, we begin to feel nothing. Perhaps that's the point, but it's hard not to want more.

What makes the astoundingly edited "Let It Fall" so powerful is that it's an oral history, told through many angles: residents, police officers, victims, families of the victims, witnesses, jurors and a host of others.
In the end, the whole enterprise comes off as too clever for its own good, a social satire without a clear target. It's a movie that you admire more than you like.
Revealing moments in this glorified infomercial are few and far between. Most of the time, the film is a story waiting to be told.
movie_title: Hare Krishna! The Mantra, The Movement And The Swami Who Started It All (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's a serviceable thriller: nothing more, nothing less.

City of Ghosts, a harrowing documentary about ISIS atrocities in Syria, is both timely and terrifying, but it will be remembered most for putting a human face on the citizen journalists who - at great risk - exposed the terrorist group's horrors in Raqqa.
Even if the construct seems a tad forced, the winning performances make the excursion worthwhile.

In the end ... the movie's superior craftsmanship can't overcome its aura of joylessness. It feels like a set-up to yet another sequel - which is no doubt on the drawing board - not a film that stands confidently on its own.
Fukada never resorts to melodramatics, and instead allows the carefully calibrated performances to give the movie its disquieting power.
This flick is a summer diversion, pure and simple, so don't expect a deep message. Except, that is, when you go on vacation next, leave your scuba diving equipment at home.
"Slack Bay" is devoid of any emotional satisfaction, and laughs come few and far between, perhaps because the humor is so French-centric.
It's impossible to resist a film that has such rich characters, and makes a complicated subject both enlightening and entertaining.
We want additional time with these characters, and that's a credit to this film: Like Hamid, we yearn for even more.
These folks are neither dour nor sappy; they are just talented journalists who want to do right by the people who left their mark on the world.
Jolie has crafted an intimate epic about a tough war subject that probably would have gone unmade without her humanitarian influence and star power.
It sounds like a fun story, with strong culture-clash potential, but the execution gets botched.
Angelou's epic journey - from a mute girl in segregated Arkansas to an icon of civil rights, literature and entertainment - could easily be a 10-part miniseries.
movie_title: Maya Angelou: And Still I Rise (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The puzzle pieces of Hauck's brain-teaser don't always come together perfectly, but there's no denying it's infectious fun.
This is a challenging film that's not for everyone. Yet there's no denying its brilliant concept and its raw cinematic power.
Weitz, in a script clearly written for Tomlin, has given her the best role of her career - and she runs with it.
Sometimes implausible and always engrossing, "Phoenix" takes us to postwar Berlin, a shell of a city where concentration camp survivor Nelly is a shell of herself.
The film is likely to attract new readers to the book - and remind longtime fans why they were attracted to the writings in the first place.

Strouse's film is about the changes that occur in all relationships and about letting go when it's time. It will probably not change your worldview about any people, places or things, but it's a pleasant way to spend a couple hours.
"Dark Places" isn't a disaster of a film. Instead, it's the definition of average, and we wish it could have taken us to some more interesting places.
The straightforward, well-edited trial scenes speak volumes, not only about the defendant, but also about the racism that still haunts our country.
Unusually delicate, sometimes funny, often dramatic, and ultimately profound.
We can't help but wish that Thorpe had acted more like an emcee than a subject.
All in all, "Amina" is an enterprising movie that makes this Internet story cinematically engaging.
movie_title: A Gay Girl in Damascus: The Amina Profile (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This is sublime filmmaking, a textbook example of how indies can tell groundbreaking stories in a way that Hollywood simply can't match.
At least we get Pacino and Hunter. We may not understand why this story appealed to them, except for the fact that it gave them a chance to work together.
A jaw-dropping documentary about two vigilante groups, on opposite sides of the U.S.-Mexico border, trying to stave off Mexican drug cartels.
We can feel the bond that these two men had for each other - and it makes for a genuine love story.
movie_title: Dying To Know: Ram Dass & Timothy Leary (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It's memorable in the sense that it has an unsettling and disorienting and even educational effect, yet as a work of drama, it's often an exercise in drudgery.
The fun possibilities get squandered, and we are treated to a head-scratching ending that is more befitting of "All My Children" than a feature film.

We get ready for the sparks to fly, but the scenes between Winslet and Schoenaerts fall flat. In fact, we pay more attention to the beautiful costumes and art direction than to any exchange between the two romantic leads.
All in all, this film is refreshingly original, an existential, boy-meets-survivalist romantic comedy.
There is no need to be a country music buff to enjoy this charming slice of Americana, though you may need a scorecard to keep track of all of the relatives who are involved in this story.
Though the themes about war and peace will be familiar, this is good, old-fashioned storytelling - with a high level of craftsmanship.
For the most part ... this is a pretty safe discussion about a very unsafe art form. We can only imagine what's in the outtakes.
Director Patrik-Ian Polk makes the ending a little too pat, but he makes us root for these characters to be happy, and for their world to be a better place.
This is a needlessly dull movie that should have gone back to the drawing board.

The engaging but perfunctory Woman in Gold isn't exactly an exercise in subtlety, but this eager-to-please film proves that the formidable Helen Mirren can provide interesting nuances even in a story where few exist.
Mitchell conjures up plenty of eerie atmospherics - the camerawork and "Halloween"-esque score are excellent - but the film never reaches terrifying heights.

This is a film that attempts to portray Shepard as an ordinary young man who happened to become a lightning-rod figure. But most of all, it gives its characters - and its audience - a chance to reflect.
movie_title: Matt Shepard is a Friend of Mine (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Aïnouz ends his film with a poetic flair that feels right. You have to just let it wash over you, like the waters of a familiar beach.
When (and before) the end credits roll, you will probably feel a sense of outrage - and helplessness.
For the most part, good food and good cheer are the order of the day here, and the chatty, old-school Ziggy serves as a reliable - and touching - tour guide.

Elkabetz commands the screen whether she's quietly seething or lashing out at the judges and their pointed questions. Her plight provides a painful argument that marriage - and divorce - are better served in the civil sphere.
movie_title: GETT: The Trial of Viviane Amsalem (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This film easily could have been 30 minutes shorter.
Zombie film tropes start to dominate, and the story logic falters as the action leaves the school grounds.

Perhaps most of the humor just doesn't translate (the film was a smash hit in Sweden). Whatever the case, the script needed to mine more comedy from the characters, not the clownish plot machinations.
movie_title: The 100-Year-Old Man Who Climbed Out the Window and Disappeared (2015)

movie_review_blurb: All in all, a highly entertaining and provocative movie.
We enjoy Ravi's search for suitable mates, and we like his family. In the end, they just want each other to be happy - and that's all that matters.

"The Boss'' provides the talented Melissa McCarthy plenty of scenery to comically chew on - she is very funny at times - but the story is paper-thin, and the script gives much of the supporting cast the proverbial pink slip.
Sobel is clearly trying to hit on something more original than a family-secrets drama, but in doing so, he pulls most of his punches.
[An] assured, breezy romantic comedy.
Though Hawke and Ejogo both have easygoing screen presences, they are boring together, because Ejogo basically has nothing to do.
To be sure, Greenaway's sensibilities may not be for everyone, but in the years to come, this is an artist whose work will be studied. It's a pleasure seeing him come out to play.

Like Antonioni, Dickinson is less interested in narrative structure and character development, but there's a problem here: He has nothing new to say about technology, alienation and the lost art of romance.

The emotional and spiritual core of this movie doesn't rest solely with the big miracle. The most important theme is rooted in the premise that everyday miracles surround us, if only we pay attention. That's an appealing message to people of all faiths.
You've seen everything on the screen before - many, many times. For every bullet, and you will lose count, there is a cliche.
It's clear that this beautifully made film wants to root its horror in the less-is-more approach. But in this case, less is often just less.
The only choice is to make sure a barf bag is nearby.
This briskly edited film never fails to be entertaining, and appealing to all audiences.

Partridge has a strong screen presence, but the potential power of his storytelling approach is negated when emotions get mushy in the third act. That's when we figure out that this film doesn't know exactly what it wants to say.
It may be difficult to fully comprehend all the cacophony, but the vibrant hues and collection of characters still make for an interesting sensory experience.

The impressive film not only underscores the clash between traditional and modern values, but also provides inspiration for deciding your own fate, even when the world seemingly doesn't give you a choice.
It's like we're seeing a home movie, except this home movie is taking us on a whirlwind tour through the late 1960s and early 1970s.
Along the way, the execution of the narrative gets muddled, but there's no denying that this risk-taking film has a pulse. A strong pulse.
We can only imagine with glee what these comic geniuses could have done with some of today's political and cultural figures.
movie_title: Drunk Stoned Brilliant Dead: The Story of the National Lampoon (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Hooper's strategy of keeping it safe is bound to bring in folks who might otherwise avoid such material. For the rest of us, we must settle for a film that is solid, but never quite soars.
Kim makes it all look so effortless and natural, and his film's bittersweet climax will stay with you.
movie_title: How to Win at Checkers (Every Time) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Murray does his best to hold up the movie, but there's only so much he can do. Ultimately, his latest fish out of water never makes it back upstream.
Overall, this is an assured effort: informative, bittersweet and appealing for both the young and the not so young.
movie_title: All Things Must Pass: The Rise and Fall of Tower Records (2015)

movie_review_blurb: An easy-to-digest history lesson that still reverberates on today's geopolitical landscape. As they say in hockey, Polsky pulls off a hat trick.
It's a journey that directors Helen Cohen and Mark Lipman chart in an unflinching yet sensitive way.
A perplexing but all-too-human psychological drama ...

Almost all of the action takes place in the bedroom. There is certainly nothing wrong with that, but a little more character dimension would have made these between-the-sheet sessions a lot more charged.
A cautionary tale about survival - and keeping one's enemies in their place.

This material is probably more suited for a TV miniseries. There is a lot of ground to cover here: 33 miners, lots of family members, a host of government officials and the media-sensation disaster itself.
Enjoying this film will depend on your state of mind. Indeed, "The Forbidden Room" is a state of mind unto itself.
This is a movie that you will admire both for its courage and creativity.

Forsaking the overload of special effects and high adventure that marked his previous successes to focus instead on a small story propelled by heart and imagination, Spielberg has made a film that will touch audiences for years to come.
The characters and their emotions are painted with a big, sloppy brush. Texas-sized.
What Soul in the Hole shows, with much joy and warmth and humor, is that the last thing basketball is, is a game.
A surprisingly effective piece of work.
Surprisingly candid, comprehensive and, most of all, emotional exposé of the wrestling business.
Doesn't even have the little spark of life that actors with a certain measure of lunacy and chemistry can deliver.
Never transcending the cliches and predictability of its genre, but also maintaining a level of excitement with its likeable, engaging characters.
When a movie's trailer is more entertaining than the movie, due to its increased lucidity and more relaxed pace, that should be enough to tip off any filmmaker that he's on the wrong track.
Never quite gets off the ground either, since none of its characters, human or simulated, is all that soulful to begin with.
Might be the first serial-killer movie that adds up to little more than a series of pretty pictures.
The whole film feels superimposed, while the story underneath remains frozen and lifeless.
A weak little piece of junk romantic comedy, mercilessly and lazily and literally using nostalgia as a method of manipulation.
Levitch is a subject compelling enough to remind us of the ecstatic joy that can come from the simple act of walking through a door.
This is the type of movie so desperate for fun it tries to bully you into it.
It's nothing more than unadulterated slapstick, and slapstick is pretty much critic-proof.

If Beloved, for all its individual moments of power and grace, does not ultimately add up to much, it's because Demme and the screenwriters can never find the means to get underneath the skin of the story's dread.
There are no signs of interesting life within Red Planet.
Barely thought-out jumble of Hollywood conventions dashed together in the pursuit of the almighty quick buck.

In place of Mary's endearingly timid Ben Stiller and luminous Cameron Diaz, Lost & Found gives us the irritatingly pompous Spade and a glamorously beautiful black hole of a personality in Sophie Marceau.
With so many satirical targets and such a mad, busy stage, getting through this shrill, tiresome film is another story altogether.
What turns out to be the scariest thing about Bride of Chucky is its shockingly large box-office take so far, proving just how critic-proof and taste-proof some movies can be.
Grounding all the mayhem in emotional priority is the little pig that could.
It's a shame that Figgis has so little purpose for all this painterly loveliness.
After a very funny first half-hour into Analyze This, it becomes painfully apparent that it's really just a skit masquerading as a feature film.
Certainly a mark above Allen's most recent works--it's refreshing to see an artist spreading his wings this wide.
As soon as the script turns serious, the film slows to a languid crawl, and ends up as a slight retread of all-too-familiar elements.
There isn't a single believable second in this film with the structure and tone of a sincere romantic comedy is a problem even Captain Kirk would have trouble solving.
The film, in spite of any plot, is one sketch after another, some of which fall flat, some of which fall flatter.
Takes a comically cockeyed path in its attempt to provide a hopeful view of humanity, but its true success is more modest. It shows that there just may be hope for Kevin Smith.
This is a film desperately in need of winks to the audience.
So slavishly formulaic, so deprived of an any inspiration of any kind, that it very well could have been written by a monkey.

Like its main character, Payback is entertainingly true to itself, and in the absence of any real imagination or ingenuity, for an audience tired of movies that trip over themselves trying to please, that goes a long way.
A convoluted, senseless mess.
Idiot comedy 101.
A smart, lean, star-powered, character-driven melodrama.
Plods along on the winds of unpleasantness and mindlessness towards its climax, where a completely arbitrary, soapy plot twist is thrown into the mix.
As midnight movies go, this one is pretty mediocre, and most of its weakness derives from a certain lack of comic inspiration.
A loony bouillabaisse of genres and cliches.
Another extended episode played out with a decided lack of conviction, with nothing ever really at stake, and lazy humor that's aimed strictly at the disciples.
The thin, underplotted story takes a long time to reach nothing more than one dopey, utterly inconsequential revisionist history lesson.
One of the more self-assuredly casual Hollywood films to come around in quite awhile.
The talents of the actors are pretty much ignored, in favor of warmed-over bits reminiscent of Robin Williams' genie character, sans energy.
The densely boisterous, richly colorful, organically amazing world created here is a relentless joy to behold.
A snail-paced, airless bore.
A contradiction in terms, a big-budget action/science-fiction epic that's also riveting, ambitious and intelligent.
There isn't a single visible seam in his remarkable work here.

It's unpretentious almost to the point of indifference, and thus never quite wrangles enough passion or conflict to fuel the story forward.
Emotional subtlety and narrative logic were never quite in the cards for this movie to begin with.
Well before the 80 minutes are up, most parents will probably tune out, but the little kids will surely feel like they are inside one fantastic candy store.
Despite its fine cast, this first feature by British writer-director Ben Hopkins is more clumsily realized than many a misfire in recent memory.
The characters in Final Fantasy are truly artificial in more ways than one.

Feels all too much like a tiring run.
A moviegoer looking for an empty-headed waste of time could do worse.
Non-Stop ends in a flurry of ill-defined thugs pointing guns at one another in flimsily established face-offs, and none of it supports the story the film wants to tell.

There's a built-in staleness to American Pimp that the Hughes Brothers are never able to overcome.
What the three stories do share are solid ideas all dressed up with nowhere to go.
A surprisingly entertaining and compelling courtroom drama that finds its real strength outside the court.
Never quite manages to be its own film.
It's the eternal question.
Too shallow to enthrall, and it lacks the visceral energy to sustain itself as a genre piece.
It is abundantly clear that Parker and Stone desperately want to be, or at least appear to be, subversive, but for the most part, this is kiddie subversion.
Shaft 2000 wants to criticize a bad practice of the white establishment and then practices it at the same time, and there's no way it can get close to having that one both ways.
SLC Punk cannot quite reach the richer depths it grasps for, because it doesn't have the material to support the large dramatic distance Stevo has to travel.
A film that treats its human audience with as much respect as its less-evolved subjects.
The second half of the film plays out a weak-kneed chase yarn that's staged and structured so halfheartedly you wonder why the filmmakers bothered at all.
From its barren junkyard landscapes to Kurt Russell's thimbleful of spoken lines to the title itself, Soldier is so sparse it barely exists.
A terrific entertainment, staged with a degree of conviction that often approaches the giddy.
It's difficult to imagine how such a high level of talent was rounded up for this nonsense.
A collection of elements rather than a distinct story, the film takes what should have been a fresh perspective on the genre and paints by numbers.
An insufferably dull retracing of romantic comedy's steps, with none of the relationship insight or genuine humanness that can make the formula such a joyful one to follow.
Half-hearted dishonesty, which the film barely attempts to conceal, turns out to be The Corruptor's true corruption.
Little more than a series of innocuous adventures that just happen to be inhabited by the same character.

Far messier and more corrupt than the society it attempts to portray.

For the first time in a Shelton sports romp, everybody loses.
This is the rare film that displays a perfect sense of star power, and how it plays to an audience.
Wonder of wonders, Thomas and her colleagues have turned this mother lode of 1970s kitsch into a pretty tasty little comedy.

Very silly but highly enthusiastic.
movie_title: Scouts Guide to the Zombie Apocalypse (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Alison Brie and Jason Sudeikis [offer] performances that manage to be funny, sweet, rude, silly and uncomfortably painful, often all at once.
Yes, it's all seriously goofy and improbable, but there's still enough audience-pleasing 'Date Movie' cuteness here anyway.
n American remake was inevitable, and writer/director Billy Ray's shot is watchable and well-played but lacks the power -- and the sting -- of the original.
Is this truly the end of the Paranormal Activitys??? Well, let's hope so.
Like Gravity, this actually offers the greatest story of them all: one person's fight to stay alive.
This is marginally better than the first Mockingjay installment simply as there isn't all the endless stage-setting and self-important yakking.
You could certainly do worse and should be entertained enough, despite its many faults.
While forgiving Python diehards will probably enjoy Jones irksome outing, others are advised to keep away unless there's absolutely nothing else worth watching.

The least interesting offering from co-writer/director Jonathan Levine, this is sheer nonsense but, well, it is just a Christmas movie, and really only intended to be a bunch of heart-warming comedic fluff as we approach the holidays.
The film's unconvincing cinematography and special effects happily condemn this one to the depths of Davy Jones' Locker.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Irksomely epic in its dreariness and cheesiness, this is nevertheless a film that will appeal to the converted.
Tougher than Frears' recent credits, The Program shows off some excellent work from its international cast.
Suffocatingly silly stuff.
Lacking the lame humour of Mirror Mirror and the ultra-violence of Immortals, this opts instead for glossy, pretentious dullness, with a shameless script that's very much a Hollywood factory second.
If ever there was a 'shut up and dance movie', this is it, as Mike and his awful friends simply don't get their gear off and hoof enough.
The main reason to catch this, the Zellners' most above-ground effort, is Kikuchi.
Gordon-Levitt is terrific as Petit, a wonderfully stubborn, obsessed, passionate and showboating figure, and he holds the film together and provides much heart amid the digital wizardry.
A star of the low/no-budget scene, Hollyman delivers a subtle, sometimes funny and often uncomfortably melancholy performance.
Angelina's biggest fans will surely enjoy it anyway, especially as she's very strong at times and, it must be said, several key dramatic highlights take place while she's in the bath.
This is naturally sober and careful but nevertheless most enjoyable, with Hanks (allowing himself to look his age) offering a wonderfully restrained performance in his fourth film for Spielberg.

Perhaps the low-ish budget shows here and there, but Ayres' filming of Blake Ayshford's script has a fittingly lived-in '70s look, a cool soundtrack, strong work from the leads (and the supporting cast) and, at times, a sense of real foreboding.
Lightly Miniony fun throughout, this Minionish comedy should please fans of general Minionishness who don't mind the goofiest Mininionesque gags.
Overlong, overcooked, overextended and over-everythinged but never amusing.
This has moderate work from the youthful stars and rather more scary stuff than Part 1, and yet it all feels unfocused, protracted and somewhat less than exciting.

While convincingly '50s in look and style, and with good work from Pattinson (who we almost wind up liking!) and DeHaan (whose JD isn't quite as much of a narcissistic creep as the real thing), Corbijn's latest still irritates.
With a name cast and some haunting images, this is also memorable for its amazing 3D imagery, and for sequences where the players look to be in real danger.
This has nice work from the kids (both of whom, incidentally, are from Melbourne) and broader, wackier playing from Dunagan and McRobbie, plus a fair helping of freaky, even WTF-type moments.
It's hard not to enjoy this amiable heartwarmer.
Why do the whole Cinderella thing again anyway?
Strikingly evoking a sense of dread in the most every-day and well-lit places, Kent's accomplished effort is built around Davis' tremendous turn.

Villeneuve's bloody drama doesn't need to make perfect plot sense or answer all your questions, as the picture it paints of the cartels is so complex that, it seems, you could never understand [them], let alone stop them.
[Powley] offers a bold performance that mixes rabid hormones, spiritual agonising, scary self-debasement and extreme teenage drama-queening.
movie_title: The Diary Of A Teenage Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Waititi and Clement's collaboration is irresistibly amusing.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: There have been films about the notorious crime-lord Kray twins of '60s London's East End before, but Legend, Brian Helgeland's take on the factual tale is the one to see.
Is it Damon's best performance? Just about, and Scott's film needed a star of that magnitude to play Mark, so you'll be glad that it's Matt's face on Mars.
[A] deliciously nasty anthology.
Hammering home its simplistic political messages as only Disney (and co-writer Damon Lindelof) can, director Bird's film has its moments, but mostly feels so yesterday.
This spectacularly entertaining epic takes several risks and yet, nevertheless, pays off splendidly.
Marvelously brooding and spirited.
A deeply frustrating head-scratcher.
We're also not invited to find Depp's subhuman-looking Jimmy cool and funny (like Martin Scorsese's Goodfellas), and we leave fully convinced that the guy was a psychopathic scumbag.
Director Isabel Coixet's films have, of late, been a dark and sometimes dreary bunch... so it's a relief that her latest Learning To Drive is wryer, sweeter and far less pretentious.

It is strange seeing De Niro playing a nice, normal old dude and not insane, edgy, enraged and/or emotionally constipated, and you also can't help but think that Meyers' movie would have worked better if he had shot someone.
Sorry, but I've got something in my eye...
Director Albert Maysles' Iris is a light yet fondly-felt chronicling of the life of 90ish New York fashion icon Iris Apfel, who peers into the camera often with her porthole-like spectacles.

Gustave Flaubert's endlessly filmed novel Madame Bovary is hauled out yet again for another go here by director Sophie Barthes, and the result is a handsome, considerably simplified and oh-so-melodramatic costume epic.
While the final salute to Paul is sweet, there's so much here that's tiresome -- not least the fact that almost nothing here involving cars is real.
Calculatedly audience-pleasing, there's nevertheless plenty here to enjoy for forgiving punters, especially Gadon's lovely performance.
Much as you might try to dislike or even loathe it, there's an elaborate, honey-hued romanticism that sweeps you up in the goofiness of it all.
While the ransom paid was the largest ever, the stakes never seem as high as they should be.
Made for the smallscreen (but don't hold that against it), this is an enjoyable romp through Staten Island, the Lower East Side, inner Manhattan and beyond, and is essential for any Banksy devotee.
With fine technical credentials on a low budget and impressive playing all round from Winter Matthews' movie is certainly worth seeking out.
There's much here that's a little iffy and contrived and yet, nevertheless, Helen Mirren is so fine it mostly works anyway.

The small, slightly fragile and sometimes awfully uncomfortable shot-in-SA psychodrama from writer/director Christopher Houghton has its flaws, and yet the committed performances make it well worth seeking out and persevering with.
Prolific documentarian Alex Gibney wrote, directed, produced and narrated the sometimes astonishing HBO production, Going Clear.
movie_title: Going Clear: Scientology and the Prison of Belief (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Cowell makes his feature film début as writer/director/producer, bringing it to the screen with Patrick Brammall in terrific, tormented form as our titular 'hero'.
Viggo Mortensen stars in Far From Men, and he's the main reason to catch it, as he delivers an understated performance of subtle power without ever beating you over the head with it.
Jumping around in time just a shade too much in the midsection, Hirschbiegel's film nevertheless proves a compelling historical drama.

Although cast members other than Larson and Tremblay do eventually appear, this is nevertheless built entirely upon their characterisations, and both are quite brilliant in deeply challenging roles.
This is mostly lame and grating stuff that almost dares you to laugh.
A more violent affair than the Hunger Games, Divergent or Maze Runner movies, but also bloodless and even wimpy so as to make sure that its teen audience isn't too scared.

While Cate Blanchett has been nabbing all the praise, the actual protagonist of the piece, played by Rooney Mara, manages to match the top-billed star with a performance every bit as committed, subtle, moving and intense.

Wonderfully played (although our heroes are far from noble) and directed with great energy, this is dreadfully enjoyable film.
At times as lumbering as the mantis, director Rob Letterman's semi-family-flick has a few giggles but ultimately feels strained.
While many Quentin haters will see nothing but post-post-post-generic trash here, it's nevertheless worth pointing out that this is one of this filmmaker's most daring efforts yet.

Helped considerably by Vikander's strong playing and a lovely turn by Belgian actor Matthias Schoenaerts (late of the remake of Far From The Madding Crowd) as Einar's old friend Hans Axgil, this nevertheless hangs upon Redmayne.

Anomalisa works far better than Synecdoche, as its mysteries feel less forced and more movingly mind-bending.

Ludicrously derivative of The Hunger Games.
There's much here that's impressive and affecting, with Vikander portraying Vera as a complex mixture of fiery individualist, swoony romantic and crushed innocent.
None of it is frightening for a second.
While there are nagging flaws here and much scope for silliness, it works mostly as [Cameron Crowe] so loves his cast and characters.

This is watchably silly stuff, and yet as the third part of what should be a tired and dragged-out series, it actually works pretty well, with a few moderate scares and a nice sense of in-jokey humour.

[Brand] manages to make the information accessible and understandable to everyone. And everyone should be horrified.
