If you are able to lay aside any reservations about the script and vocal aspects, the film does provide enjoyable enough entertainment.

The Halmacs are a scrappy, lively bunch, fueled by the antic energy of its youngest members, and Mihal's lens lingers lovingly on them. Perhaps too much. The film would greatly benefit from tighter editing...
The cliched conventions of the futuristic sci-fi genre are all present and accounted for in this particularly arid and harrowingly slow example of the form.

The Little Bedroom is intelligent and sensitive and yet leaves one rather cold. The very tastefulness with which these women have framed this story keeps the viewer at arm's length, as does the rather antiseptic look of the film...
A sort of modern Chekhovian study of family tensions over a country weekend, this indie drama is very pretty to look at and at times disarming, but needed more punch.
Gorgeously photographed, edited with a crackle, lavishly populated and designed, this is a sheer non-mind-taxing crowd-pleaser
It's all way too much, for in his desire to be comprehensive, Harris plumb forgets that less would have been more.
movie_title: Through a Lens Darkly: Black Photographers and the Emergence of a People (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Bernardo Bertolucci's most negligible effort to date, in which he takes a familiar - for him - premise and does very little with it.
Utterly delightful, almost uncanny in its perfect period confidence and brio, this is a reminder once more of why we love French films.
Literally dedicated to "all the old people of today, and of tomorrow," this animated look at aging is deeply humanistic, immensely moving, often hilarious and quite, quite wonderful.
As captivating as it is important, Mary Mazzio's seemingly modest tract about immigration achievement grabs you by the heart, as it grows and grows into something big and vital.
Incredibly moving and powerful documentary about combatting Alzheimer's with music. Without the use of a single CGI effect, you see literal miracles happening here.
"Classic" is a word all too casually bandied about, but for Daniel Auteuil's screen adaptation of this beloved French trilogy it is completely apropos.
A personal project which should have stayed personal, this turgid yet flat Ibsen adaptation is third-time unlucky for Wallace Shawn and Andre Gregory.
Literally beset by goblins, this strained animated effort should have concentrated on the human elements of its story rather than the supernatural.
As generic as its title, this comedy aimed squarely at "mature" audiences may find itself roundly rejected by seniors, if they have any taste.
Excessive violence and off-the-wall plotting undermine an intriguing game-based premise.
Infuriatingly slow, enervating and basically empty contemplation of war's impact, and a waste of the formidable talent of a gallant Catherine Keener.
This study of teens trying to make it in a very depressed and depressing heartland would have benefitted from more hard info and less pictorial meandering.
This callow but pretentious reunion of college buddies would have better been kept a strictly private affair.
Initially gripping, in a Hitchcock/Ozon way, this atmospheric thriller turns banal and unconvincing in its second half.
Family drama set in upstate New York and revolving around a devastating secret which ultimately rings as hollow as the film itself.
An intriguing, often highly poetic documentary that is almost the equal of its turbulent genius of a subject.

Writer-director Jeff Baena maintains a tongue-in-cheek attitude throughout that it so ironic it undermines audience engagement. He might have been able to carry it off had the movie been in any way funny, but it isn't.
We've seen it all before, too many times, in Paris, in black-and-white or color: This entry adds nothing to an already overstocked genre.
Steve Coogan and Rob Brydon work hard to be funny in this ultimate piece of luxuriant fluff requiring a surfeit of viewer indulgence.
A basic cheapness, both of intent and execution, pervades this thriller queasily centered around a child's kidnapping and murder.
A huge box-office success overseas, this epic-in-every-way impresses through its sheer mass and volume.
The kaleidoscopic life of the Enterprise's chauffeur - an Asian and gay showbiz pioneer - is explored in this entertaining but diffuse documentary.
Dabis has concocted a fairly engaging family dramedy, which would have been a lot better if her own character weren't such a paragon.
There won't be a smarter or funnier screenplay this year (or more striking feature directorial debut), and that is just the basis for this surprising , wonderful and quite definitive college film.
As charming as it is delicate, this unusually low-key, if a tad overlong, animated feature brings yet more prestige to the famed Ghibli output.
movie_title: The Tale of the Princess Kaguya (2014)

movie_review_blurb: George S. Kaufman said, "Satire is what closes on Saturday night." This piece of utter cluelessness will be lucky to last that long.
Alzheimer's is given an unforgettably human face here, and that face belongs to a music legend.
This film, in the ocean of Holocaust-themed works, does really put you in searing human contact with this greatest of tragedies and horrors.
We're not exactly talking high art here but, even as fun, trashy entertainment, The Boy Next Door falls short of the mark.
Startlingly original, compellingly watchable character study that is simultaneously hilarious, appalling and sad.
The latest classical-music legend to have his life trashed-again-by a cheaply sensationalistic movie, this famed fiddler deserved way better.
The film soon grows predictable and rather soft, with one too many tiresome, elegiac evocations of 9/11 and its devastating aftermath.
This transgender tale is one near-constant and winning surprise.
The lead character here, quite deeply disturbed, is actually presented as a worthy romantic hero.
The heartbreaking but ultimately inspiring short life of a modern martyr is uncovered in this at-times naïve but powerful documentary.
movie_title: Matt Shepard is a Friend of Mine (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Awash with sentiment, nostalgia and a good deal of charm, this evocation of Korea's folk-music heyday-Did you know it had one?-is a pleasant diversion.
This skeletal, near-sung-through study of a broken marriage is so mishandled and basically unengaging that it will do little to advance the case of movie musicals.
This fourth collaboration between Hugh Grant and writer-director Marc Lawrence is their best.
An important, always absorbing topic goes awry in this curious, sometimes suspect hodge-podge of a documentary.
Impressively staged and non-judgmental study of the love between a john and a young hustler is compelling but a tad too cold.
Rude, crude but often delightful and fresh business farce.
Where [writer/director Joel] Potrykus goes awry is in the undeveloped nature of his own script, which becomes very slack in the film's second half.
A vivid spotlight is shone on one particularly bizarre and compelling lifer of a jailbird.
movie_title: The Life And Mind Of Mark Defriest (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Interesting, accessible documentary about the boxing world is revealing but stymied by its own slickness.
[The Lovers] strives mightily to be a new Titanic for the Millennium [...]but resoundingly fails at every turn.
So sober and seemingly passionless that some may resist, but it's undeniably hard to shake off.
Pretentious, stuffy and slow. There's some beautiful scenery here but oh, what you must put up with to earn it!
BFFs who shouldn't be is the subject of this basically aimless, strangely unsympathetic indie.
Well-meaning but execrably executed diatribe against high-school bullying that is so bad, the result is just a pure exploitation "Mean Girls" flick.
As unflinchingly raw, honest and often ugly as this millennial time in which we live.
movie_title: A Wolf at the Door (O Lobo atrás da Porta) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Wafer-thin concept about desperate actors trying to write and get laid in the country is a vanity project that goes nowhere, slowly and tiresomely.
Excessive, chaotic, cartoonish and far too noisily salacious.
[Director JK] Youn proves himself a truly versatile and accomplished filmmaker.
The film has its interest, but maybe because of its association with Illy, it also has a somewhat removed, self-congratulatory corporate quality; it should have gone deeper.
movie_title: A Small Section Of The World (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A mostly diverting black comedy which has a strong vein of teasing, titillating waggishness until it goes completely south in its final moments.
Grim, humorless psychological thriller which goes from scrupulously set up, clenched tension to violently haywire, senselessly brutal action.
Little more than a ramblingly extended PSA.
An odor of condescension and, eventually, exploitation inescapably emanates.
A quietly affecting little film with characters who ingratiate themselves into your heart.
Strained sex farce which has the tacky nerve to try and go all warm and fuzzy.
Original, unbridled and very funny.
Uninspired, airless treatment and flat writing evaporate all the good will of anyone wanting to see a mature senior love story.
Killer entertainment on the highest level of audience satisfaction.
As much as one would like to feel for these characters, the limited story and almost clinically detached direction keep you oddly distanced.
Very strong, historically intriguing and important gay document is marred by intrusive real-life interview footage, which seriously breaks up the dramatic momentum.
Enthralling and uplifting documentary about a man of the world turned monk, but one who effects real, inspiring change.
[Food Chains] should literally be seen by every American who unquestioningly lifts fork to mouth for their three squares a day.
Small-scale but impressively engaging.
Writer-director Liz Tuccillo takes a fairly thin, somewhat inane premise and manages to craft an agreeable, very small-scale rom-com out of it.
Claustrophobic, basically unexciting and heavy-handed.
[Top Five is] indeed funny in spots, but often thin and underdeveloped as well as improbable.
One minute a tense police procedural, the next a wacky Almodóvarian sex farce, this schizophrenic enterprise is more wearying than entertaining.
The so-called geriatric set at which this sad, grating piffle is aimed has better taste and should save themselves a trip to the mall.
movie_title: Six Dance Lessons In Six Weeks (2014)

movie_review_blurb: [The Captive] is undone by one too many ill-timed flashbacks and some garish melodrama which reduces the human element.
"Sagrada is a vividly informative documentary."
Amidst a lot of competition, we now have officially found the absolute worst film of 2014 (or any other year, really).
movie_title: Life Of An Actress The Musical (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Over-scaled, too dark and only intermittently charming.
A wonderful, literate yet humanly engaging portrait of a famous, rumored ménage a trois which makes the entire era come thrillingly to life.
How bad do the moviemakers want us to feel about a recently dead "artiste" in this contrived, annoying and pretentious bore? Very bad.
Many will [...] praise [Toni] Collette's unflinching lack of vanity and honesty in this portrayal, but I found her performance predictable.
Forget any label of rom-com or chick flick, this is just one helluva good comedy.
One of the very best documentaries ever made about movies.
movie_title: Harold And Lillian: A Hollywood Love Story (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Immensely diverting.
Absurdly self-indulgent, sophomoric look at an American youth trying to save his tortured soul in the Third World.
Maria Schrader's boldly understated look at a great, forgotten 20th-century writer is one impressive achievement, all the more admirable for its understated subtlety.
More frustrating than enlightening.
This ambitiously named doc reaffirms that it was its subject's sharp elbows, as well as her photographs, which were the making of her.
A perfect antidote to the surfeit of noisy summer releases, this period mystery is stunningly well done.
This smart, biting and touching movie could well capture its own canny, receptive audience starved for an American film with real substance.
This tale of a lesbian's frantic search for love of any kind is very stale stuff, and made worse by one of those from-indie-hell, bad singer-songwriter music soundtracks.
At once over-the-top camp and an invaluable artifact of a vanished gay age.
This Korean period spectacle is enlivened by the presence of a new kind of dynamic duo-a crime-fighting detective king and his genius, if clumsy, secret weapon.
A wonderfully trenchant and moving doc about three souls in search of a diploma.
The music prodigy in this doc is an inspiration, but this limited, gushy film is not.
The little-known strata of gay men who love and regularly play sports is the focus of this amiable, if less than incisive, documentary.
Three hours and 20 minutes fly by.
movie_title: My Journey Through French Cinema (Voyage À Travers Le Cinéma Français) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A decidedly one-sided cinematic paean to a rare good guy among the one percent that goes down easily, making you feel better in the knowledge that someone like him exists.
An octogenarian pioneer of instamatic photography as art is glowingly featured in this likeable doc.
movie_title: The B-Side: Elsa Dorfman's Portrait Photography (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This affecting story of one lad's personal and artistic growth is one of the very best acting-school films.
[A] striking directorial debut.
Performer Okwui Okpokwasili wants us to feel her pain in the worst way.
[A] madly flitting butterfly of a film.
movie_title: That Most Important Thing: Love (L'important c'est d'aimer) (1975)

movie_review_blurb: The Catherines Deneueve and Frot have a nice rapport, but that's about all that can be said of this slight soap opera.
Irish adolescent coming-of-age tale is undone by a basic lack of freshness and haphazard direction and script.
An engaging look at the preservation of a creature that, with the single exception of pandas, has probably brought more joy to us than any other living creature.
The talented, intelligent and tasteful Katell Quillévéré proves herself a master of the medium with this ensemble drama. One of the year's best films.
Pretentious, windy and largely empty bromance between two of the greatest figures of French culture in the 19th century.
This bland, uninspired LA-set comedy features a hero who won't go east to a dazzling college future. Hard to muster sympathy for that, but harder still to find any laughs.
Lovers of big-band music especially-but everyone, really-will enjoy this loving look at a man and his nostalgic mission.
movie_title: Vince Giordano: There's a Future in the Past (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Those terrific dancers who Vogued their way to brief stardom backing up Madonna are front and center in [this] warm and absorbing doc.
It's almost guaranteed that this overbaked, underwhelming confection will give you cinematic indigestion.
movie_title: Bakery in Brooklyn (My Bakery in Brooklyn) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This adrenaline-filled cop caper, featuring an unlikely Mutt-and-Jeff pair from two Koreas, delivers solid entertainment and lovable characters.
[A] heartbreaking but ultimately radiant doc about the aftermath of an unthinkable tragedy.
She is her own dream come true-a vision of manmade loveliness-but is that all there is, to warrant a Barbara Kopple doc?
The utter realness of this story and the way it has been handled is the resonating strength of Jamal Joseph's gripping, affecting study of survival in today's Harlem.
Listless, highly predictable study of a call girl in trouble and her stalwart, if punk-like, hero.
Discretion is the better part of boredom here.
Not as much fun as you'd expect, but an honest, if heavy-spirited, take on today's house scene.
Strictly recommended for hard-core cineastes only.
Emo Groundhog Day, strictly recommended for the more morose millennial set.
This viewer has never really gotten modern-day burlesque, and I'm afraid this doc does little to change my mind.
movie_title: Burlesque: Heart Of The Glitter Tribe (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Joyous and surprisingly insightful.
Involving, deeply stirring doc about a modern crusader who helped change the face of a nation.
The chance, especially in these newly troubled days, to address an important, disturbing subject-sexual-conversion therapy-is completely blown by bad writing and direction.
[Sir Ben Kingsley's] suffocatingly bad histrionic choices of late have led me to wonder if Oscars can be rescinded.
If you liked the original, the overdue sequel to Sordid Lives will both delight you and warm your ever-lovin' heart.
Here comes Nathan Morlando's Mean Dreams to remind us all that things are bad in the heartland of this here good ole U.S. of A.
If you want any real answers to questions about this cryptic, creative filmmaker, you're advised to seek other sources for information.
As slow and stately as this royal depiction of death is, it nonetheless achieves a gripping "you are there" immediacy that is never less than mesmerizing.
movie_title: The Death of Louis XIV (La mort de Louis XIV) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Humnabadkar, Bhilawadikar and the actors build up enough goodwill that you're inclined to forgive the production's shortcomings and even get a little goosebump-y.
A loose, informal portrait of a man still on the hustle.
Another French examination of l'amour fou, this one verging on risibility with its excessive devotion to the excessiveness of its heroine.
movie_title: From the Land of the Moon (Mal de pierres) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Although its plot could have been trimmed and more clearly focused, this rousing wartime saga is truly epic, in every sense of the word.
How could a French sex farce fueled by Grindr be so dull and, well, unsexy?

On the Beach at Night Alone noodles along quirky slight and rather charming until its midsection when, during a raucously funny, very drunk and true dinner party among friends, it springs to vivid, hilarious life and truly builds from there into something
movie_title: On the Beach at Night Alone (Bamui haebyun-eoseo honja) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This beautiful and powerful Afghan-themed story of survival and one little girl's determination is surely the best animated feature of 2017.
Completely absorbing and well-researched documentary.
The work and mind of an architect come thrillingly to life in this smooth, intelligent doc about a certified modern genius.
Music artists Azealia Banks and RZA both find their footing in film, with this portrait of a young, gifted and black wannabe female rapper.
Affecting doc about one teacher's handling of a classroom filled with immigrant children, probingly filmed but with a graceful tact.
In many ways, this is the most dramatically satisfying of any Agatha Christie film adaptation-plus it's a real treat to look at.
The title is better than the film.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Dancer Marcelo Gomes' professional and personal stories make for a terrifically involving terpsichorean doc.
movie_title: Anatomy of a Male Ballet Dancer (2018)

movie_review_blurb: An unwieldy, unfocused work that just gets lost in its own ambitious striving for objectivity and scope.
Great musician; dull, hollow film.
Keeps things likeably frothy and delivers nicely on both entertainment and emotional fronts.
This at times diffuse doc offers some glowing revelations about this most influential of artists.
Fans of Harry Potter-and there sure are enough of them-will love this magical broomstick ride from a gifted bunch of Studio Ghibli artists.
Preacher struggles with his sexuality-have we seen it before? Yes. Does this make you want to see it again? Not really.
One more of this planet's seemingly endless and frightful ecological dilemmas, presented with compassion and intelligence.

The filmmakers turn these historical events into a satisfying, fast-paced, gripping and smart thriller, focusing on a myriad of characters all united by their activism and disgust for the men in charge.
Marvelous Taiwanese study of down-and-outers' survival strategies defines "bittersweet," while managing to be effin' hilarious along the way.
Director Liu Jian's fierce determination to out-Tarantino Tarantino results in a heartlessly clever, blood-spattered cartoon noir portrait of a modern China ruled by avarice.
movie_title: Have a Nice Day (Hao Ji Le) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Big subject, trite treatment.
[D]espite its thinness, has much to recommend it: some catchy music, believable passion and a highly likeable performance by Lena Hall in a rather prickly role.
A fast-paced, Jason Bourne-like Korean thriller, given depth by its theme of friendship.
This depiction of a dictator's life is one very long, intermittently rewarding haul.
Just what we need right now: a comedy about a stalker! Thank you, Jake Goldberger, an auteur for our times.
Students on the brink of disaster are the subject of this admirably heartfelt and uncondescending documentary.
Low-key treatment of a relationship between a gay man and a Communist woman will reward the patient.
[Rose Marie] tells her story with salty, unaffected ease, and there is also some affectionate narration by her longtime friend Peter Marshall.
Cho, who's been a quiet, authentic and always appealing asset of American cinema for two decades now, [gives] a beautifully understated performance.
A film for grownups in every way, this disarming romantic triangle has a rare and quite deep literacy.
movie_title: The Only Living Boy in New York (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Elementally simple storytelling, possessing one helluva wallop.
The unquestioned eye-candy feast of 2017.
Marjorie Prime's greatest value ... is in Smith's performance.
Clichés abound in this dance film about a leery ballerina, keeping it resolutely earthbound.
Fated-to-be-mated Mexican couple eventually win each other, as well as audience hearts, in this breezy summer idyll.
movie_title: Tales Of An Immoral Couple (La Vida Inmoral De La Pareja Ideal) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: An unjustly neglected heroine of our time finally gets her due in this smart, spirited doc.
Sean Baker once again pulls us into a world we never thought we could fall in love with.
Beautifully respectful and often plain beautiful.
Travels a bumpy road indeed.
movie_title: Napping Princess (Hirune-hime: Shiranai watashi no monogatari) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This tinselly doc about an eminent shoe designer is a very shiny object lacking a substantive core.
movie_title: Manolo, The Boy Who Made Shoes For Lizards (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Tired, unfunny bacholor party/revenge comedy.
An important Native American figure has her story told in this handsomely produced but rather wan vision of her life.
Dysfunctional-family mysteries are unearthed in this delicately rendered but rather pallid adaptation of a novel.
[A] rambunctious, obvious but nonetheless quite entertaining romp.
Extraordinary cinematography makes this doc on Earth's wonders a must-see.
The title refers to your heart rate, which should increase as you experience this moving and powerful portrait of a tragic yet inspired era.
movie_title: BPM (Beats Per Minute) (120 battements par minute) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The recreation of a historic moment in Korea's constantly embattled past becomes a rather enervating epic in the too diaogue-driven hands of director Hwang Dong-hyuk.
Dour in the extreme but also pretty damn sexy, this rural gay romance will certainly have its specialized audience appeal, without the big crossover of the great Moonlight.
That renaissance wild man Dennis Hopper, once chosen as one of Andy Warhol's "Most Beautiful," is featured in a very personal memoir.
The problem here is Milewski's perceived agenda.
A wonderful and surprising intimate portrait of maybe the loudest and most foul-mouthed comedian who ever lived. You will laugh your ass off and maybe even cry your eyes out.
A sensational Korean trial makes for a fairly riveting cinematic ride, with its very own touches of that infamous gangnam style.

As sad as its finale was, the life of film critic Roger Ebert had as much incident, drama and joy as any ten movies he ever reviewed, and this completely absorbing doc tells his deeply human story with rare truth and beauty.
That portentously pretentious title is just a hint of how bad this ode to living on the youthful edge in Colombia really is.
Call it cornball for the way this ostensible black comedy morphs into a family tearjerker, but I defy you not to be moved by its literal bromance.
The nonstop wit and graceful evocation of Manhattan's Hurricane Sandy aftermath stamp this absolute charmer as an instant classic.
Starts well but literally goes nowhere.
New movies set in Cuba suffer the risk of getting too caught up in heavy, drama-eroding nostalgia, and this one is no exception.
Although undoubtedly based on fact, this too-contrived study of one kid's drug addiction has a distancing, synthetic feel to it, staying its potential power.
Just in time for Mother's Day, a film you should take Mom to...if you hate her.
The unearthly beauty of Hawaii provides the sole reason to even think of looking at this absolute mess of a psychological thriller.
Bad gay movies never take very long to announce themselves as such, and Beautiful Something is no exception.
It's no pleasure to report that this Scottish adaptation of a long-beloved novel gets it wrong in so many ways. Strictly recommended to ardent fans of the morose.
Queen Mimi sometimes becomes aimless in its attempt to make Mimi a more compelling figure than she is.
This study of an impoverished student and a stripper teaming up to bilk his rich classmates feels like a Risky Business rip-off, which doesn't make it any less lousy.
May make a strong plea for gender equality, but this viewer is afraid that Transfixed also proves that the transgendered can be as boring as anyone of any sex.
A Ukrainian priest proves himself a hero among heroes, literally saving children, and his story is richly compelling and totally inspiring.
Entertainment value positively surges through this highly capable Korean thriller.
movie_title: Phantom Detective (Tamjung Hong Gil-dong: Sarajin Ma-eul) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: An artist and bohemian in the truest sense of those words is celebrated in this inspiring doc about his work and gloriously independent life.
It's basically thin stuff, but there's no denying that this sendup of all things pop music is quite often an uproarious barrelful of laughs.
Recommended only to the very patient, this study of a relationship between two highly disparate men feels slow and parched.
This directorial debut proves to be one quite delightful surprise: funny, touching and real.
The greatest language known to mankind is front and center in this ebullient doc, charting a band formed by that eternal wunderkind, Yo-Yo Ma.
movie_title: The Music of Strangers: Yo-Yo Ma and the Silk Road Ensemble (2016)

movie_review_blurb: There's music and dance galore, but the Argentinian cognoscenti will best appreciate this doc, while others may be less diverted.
There's a rather pushy aggressiveness in the tone that, in everything that follows, seems more designed to shock and appall rather than engage on any human level.
Anything but fun, Tickled is a real bait-and-switch, but a highly effective and watchable one.
Drawn way too broadly in its indefatigable search for cheap laughs; an opportunity to explore cultural differences gets blown here.
We're on death watch with Penélope Cruz here-which, unfortunately, is little more than a synonym for "vanity project."
Ernest Hemingway may not be spinning in his grave over the abysmalness that is [this film], but we can see him cursing a blue streak and perhaps waving a gun around.

Randall Wright's documentary Hockney is as warm as the artist's chosen place of residence, laced with loving interviews by intimates of Hockney's which go back to his early youth in gray, drab Bradford, England.
Has its undeniable value, but a much tougher, less sentimental visual sensibility would have been helpful.
[Writer/director Paul] Dalio goes overboard with his incessant promotion of the time-worn notion that in madness lies genius.
They walk and they talk. And then they walk and talk some. Which is to say that this is a total pedestrian affair.
That veritable New York Valhalla of so-called aspirational emporiums, Tiffany & Co., is featured in a quite splendiferous new doc by Matthew Miele.
[A] very likeable, if a bit too superficial, documentary.
The latest film by Apichatpong Weerasethakul will inspire both rapture in his avidly devoted claque and boredom in the less patient.
Yasujiro Ozu's early domestic masterwork has been given a gorgeous restoration which makes it even more treasurable-if possible-than ever.
Even if you feel like you don't need therapy, this inspiriting doc about an exceptional shrink may have you thinking otherwise...if only one could get somebody like Irvin Yalom.
The central heroine is so unceasingly caustic that any audience member would have to be a veritable saint to root for her.
The cheap use of the hot-button issue of pedophilia coupled with negatively minded ignorance regarding homosexuality is not only offensive but-far worse-completely uninvolving
The simple making of a bite-sized pancake lies at the heart of this graceful and moving film.
WARNING: if you love the very special beverage called saké, your mouth will be watering throughout this doc's mesmerizing 94-minute running time.
A chance to truly depict Asian-Americans today devolves into a shallow series of sub-"Entourage" macho frat-rat antics.
[A] shallow and profoundly unexciting "true-life account" of one student's brief reign as a campus drug lord.
Aims to go deep but is as shallow as a puddle would be in the almost laughably literal Death Valley locale.
This unique, super-smart and berserkly imaginative French animated entry is a real achievement in the world of animation.
movie_title: April and the Extraordinary World (Avril et le monde truqué) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Autism and the challenges it presents for its romantically inclined leading lady are the basis for this well-intentioned but very spotty film.
Another remarkable senior gets the spotlight in this wonderful, inspiriting doc about a legend of the cycling world.
movie_title: Marinoni: The Fire in the Frame (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The rom-com blight continues with this white-bread-in-every-way contemplation of modern relationships.
As in love with dance as The Red Shoes, this spinning, leaping and quite fun dervish of a film should prove an audience pleaser.
One of the most important and essential documents ever made about the dying process.
movie_title: Be Here Now (The Andy Whitfield Story) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: One of the better fashion docs is this juicy insider, in-depth survey of what goes into the industry's biggest night of the year.
This tepid stew has all of the faults inherent in anthology film-a wayward, stultifying aimlessness, adding up to a big nothing-with none of the virtues.
movie_title: Rio, I Love You (Rio, Eu Te Amo) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Susan Sarandon has a field day playing one very controlling mama, but the film itself isn't up to its star.
Warm and winning doc
This doc offers a wealth of important information, but sometimes couches it in a too loaded and sometimes inappropriate style.
Despite a plethora of tear-jerking clichés, bathos is neatly avoided through the first half of this drama...but oh, that second half!
[The] film unfolds slowly but remains gripping, its overall seriousness lightened by shrewdly observed humanity expressing itself in the characters' interaction with attendant humor and surprise.
Essentially trite presentation of a facsimile space mission that never gets off the ground, in more ways than one.
What happens when a gang of merrie men split up in the interests of gaining maturity forms the basis of this generally sprightly comedy.
That pretentious title kinda says it all about this well-meaning but rather narcissistic doc about a kidnapping victim's experiences in Syria.
Get this: Our grown adult of a hero has never had an orgasm! Also get this: It ain't funny!
This overheated Southern-fried crime thriller was maybe left out in the sun too long to cool off.
One of the most glowing tributes to an actress ever made.
This fetching little oddball of a movie sneaks its way into your affection by virtue of its sheer originality and keen human observation.
How can something so politically right be so aesthetically wrong?
The Handmaiden, while a visually dazzling feast for the senses, seems to be on a mission to tell its already elaborate story in the most intricate fashion imaginable.
Nothing very original here, but it's well played and shot, capturing one summer's hectic span for four kids about to enter college.
Though it is, indeed, at times hard to take, it should be seen by everyone.
A movie about gay porn without a visible penis in it is like a Western without a horse. And that's just the beginning of what's wrong with this cheap piece of exploitation.
A glowingly rewarding investigation into the life of a great Russian writer who met a most untimely and tragic end.
Dead Man Talking here, and horrific as his crimes are, through the power of the film and the most basic kind of love, you are made to feel for him.
Highly engaging doc about a different kind of Fabulous Four, who use their Asperger's Syndrome to make comedy.
Maybe the laziest and shoddiest family holiday fare on film ever perpetrated. No glowing memories to be found here at all.
This daring re-enactment of one man's going blind is not only successful, but deeply moving and enlightening.
The rarefied world of chess at its highest level is revealed in this absorbing doc centered around the so-called greatest player in history.
Original, demanding and disarmingly rewarding, this women's film is a significant achievement for director Feng Xiaogang.
The greatest Japanese actor is beautifully celebrated in a much-needed, long-overdue biographical tribute by Steven Okazaki.
The best film about being blind this critic has ever seen, particularly fortuitous in its "star," a quirky, heart-melting gamine you will never forget.
Despite its juvenile, portentous title, and its framing sometimes tackily smacking of "TMZ," this study of the big boys who protect the big stars offers surprising insight.
movie_title: Bodyguards: Secret Lives from the Watchtower (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Katie Holmes makes her directorial debut with this soapy mess-and should probably stick to her day job.
One of those colorful non-famous characters whom "everyone" knows gets his due in this lively doc celebrating both him and the music scene in which he thrived.
If ever there was a photographer's photographer, it is Harry Benson, and this doc does full justice to him and his mind-boggling longevity and body of work.

The determined eccentricity of the entire conceit-liberally laced with moments of hallucinatory surrealism-weighs the movie down, creating an airless ambiance at odds with any youthful verve which might appeal to the viewer.
The politically incorrect jokes, while often funny, wear a bit thin as director Sophie Goodhart lays them on with naughty glee.
As invigorating, profane and downright honest as the subject herself, this doc follows an iconic performer on her dubious, rather divine, campaign trail.
While this documentary profile of TV groundbreaker Norman Lear is always interesting and affectionate in attitude, so much more might have been made of his life and career.
movie_title: Norman Lear: Just Another Version of You (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Too stylized and downright ugly character renderings are an enormous liability in this ambitious follow-up to A Cat in Paris.
One Night Only has a bracingly youthful visual verve to it, and Matt Wu is a born storyteller, drawing us in through all the violent underworld shenanigans, straight to the oftimes embattled romance.
This doc is largely an unquestioning love letter to this towering, burly, rough-spoken choirmaster.
movie_title: Tony Robbins: I Am Not Your Guru (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The big-screen revival of the decadent Brit comedy series has amusing moments, but largely coasts on fans' goodwill.
Father and son boff the same babe-and a baby girl results. From this queasy premise, an onscreen abortion is wrought.
A splashily diverting documentary which will be catnip to Golden Age Hollywood fans and deeply informative to the general public.
Intimate without digging too deeply, but still a highly satisfying portrait of a resilient soul singer.
Hardly world-shaking, but a nice, very smoothly executed summer refreshment.
This genial, sometimes literally obscene mess is strictly recommended to hard-core John Waters fans.
Highly recommended to anti-fashionistas for its unblinking look at the stench beneath the couture.
It doesn't get much crazier than this portrait of one particularly crazy love, which, for all the operatic thrashing about, fails to amount to all that much.
An instant classic of Asian-American, gay...oh hell, just cinema. This ethnic and sexual immersion is as richly rewarding as it is quietly and impressively achieved.
Feels haphazardly put together, like a high-school student collating all of his notes on a subject into one hopefully cogent and comprehensible treatise.
movie_title: Kampai! For the Love of Sake (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Very square and rather uninspired, but its underdog hero as played by star-in-the-ascendant Edgar Ramírez is just about irresistible.
This self-congratulatory, unconvincing contemplation of maternal death, life's messiness and Cinema with a capital C is itself a pretentious mess.
This kiddie crime caper promises fun, but delivers clueless disappointment instead.
Most disaster epics, even the silliest, manage to entertain, as does this one, but with intelligence and a compassionate focus on the feelings of the people most affected.
Uninspired and unfunny script and direction are the undoing of this labored farce. And then there's Bobby Moynihan...
[A] deeply inspiring doc about how trouble for a real-life river city was transformed into triumph.
[A] very indie indie which tries hard to be simultaneously winsome and rueful.
Clever and funny, technically excellent caper film, with an amazingly moving emotional payoff at the end.
What should play out as a jaw-dropping tale of espionage and the human price paid for it is rendered plodding and all too bland by its uninspired treatment here.

Unfortunately, Mehta does not retain a firm grip on his storyline and the film, perhaps too enraptured by the bustlingly colorful locales of India, which are featured in lengthy, dialogue-less passages, becomes rather meandering.
One of the best gay films ever made.
movie_title: Paris 05:59: Théo & Hugo (Théo et Hugo dans le même bateau) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Melancholy and elegiac in the most evocative of ways, Jalil Lespert's biopic has brought the life of fashion genius Yves Saint Laurent to the screen in a way that manages to be ever-tasteful as well as piquantly provocative.
Marvelously candid documentary depicting the creation of a massive, seemingly foolhardy pipe dream of a production. One of a handful of truly fine movies about opera.
Desperately ambitious yet emptily windy, unconvincing two-hander which purports to say something serious about modern-day romantic anomie.
Terrific, engrossing and intelligent epidemic thriller from Korea, which shows up American product like Contagion and Outbreak for their shallowness and commercialism.
Some raunchy laughs here, but this is mostly a strained heist film marred by the director's decision to cast himself in a major, cringe-worthy role.
Scruffy documentary, in need of more focus, about the travails of ever-aspiring singers has rewarding moments among the randomness.
Under Kim Dong-won's ebullient direction, the movie, for all its genre derivativeness and predictability, is pretty swell entertainment.
Mike Birbiglia's wonderfully deft "opening up" of his stand-up routine is a rare achievement in this genre and a supremely self-deprecating delight.
Perfect late-summer film fare: an uproarious and seriously romantic car romp which has something for the girls as well as the boys.
Talkin' dirty proves just the ticket in this rather eccentrically anachronistic but also rather winning little female-fueled comedy.

As toxic as a Drano cocktail, this would-be Bridesmaids, at times as outrageous but also foul-mouthed and lacking any discernible heart, is strictly recommended for those who confuse incessant nasty snark for wit.
Often funny and emotionally observant study of contrasting sisters has good performances, especially by Tammy Blanchard and, in a tiny but telling role, the transcendent Patti LuPone.
This documentary about a Chinese mother-daughter relationship veers uncertainly from family drama to an overall survey of Communism's rise and devastating human effect.
This irredeemably silly tropical screwball comedy, made in 2009, is only now getting a release-and that's no surprise.
movie_title: You May Not Kiss the Bride (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Long before the eighth fraught reunion between this self-serious drama's ultimately mismatched (and uninteresting) gay lovers, you may find yourself tuning out.
Sweet and engaging documentary about perhaps the last surviving silent-era actor.
movie_title: Baby Peggy: The Elephant in the Room (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Numbing, uninvolving portrait of an ex-con as an animal-loving zombie.
If you've scrupulously avoided high-school reunions, don't let this ho-hum film change your mindset.
Marvelously diverting and detailed documentary about a legendary fashion smackdown, with the ultimate royal setting.
Exceedingly well-done film, based on a real news story, which addresses a growing international youth dilemma.
This amazingly well-done, admirably dry-eyed documentary about a true human victory over what was once a universal death sentence might well be the year's finest.
Mediocre drama centered a young woman's introduction to the porn industry.
An entertaining and visually apt, if less than deeply probing, portrait of an imperishable fashion icon.
movie_title: Diana Vreeland: The Eye Has To Travel (2012)

movie_review_blurb: An affectless approach muffles any interest one might have in this failed rom-com.
Tale of a Seattle race for city council is strident and ultimately tiresome.
An impossibly lavish historical tapestry comes to breathtakingly vivid life in Benoît Jacquot's ultra-intimate account of the most famous French queen of them all.
In his debut auteurial flourish, writer-director-writer Martin Donovan proves himself a triple-threat bore.
Edgar Allan Poe, serial-killer hunter. That's the lamebrain concept of the eerie writer's mysterious final days in Baltimore as posited in this misdirected effort.
Coming-of-age tale has a lot of appealing elements which help counteract its weaknesses.
Fascinating and frighteningly revelatory documentary about a P.O.W. that happens to be a painting.
Highly agreeable, funny and bright study of a pregnant woman all at sea in a world where wireless options seem to outweigh human ones in her life.
"I've known her ten hours and I know her better than you," the hero tells his romantic rival in this contrived bore, by which time you'll also feel like ten hours have passed.
Give a young auteur some indie pull and look what happens: Strictly recommended to anyone who needs to see a schizophrenic single mother robbing a bank in a gorilla mask and housedress.
Affecting portrait of a small, rather desolate Texas town, and the people who form its still staunchly beating heart.
Mighty bad.
Worthy if at times heavy-handed doc about the first country-music star to publicly say, "I'm gay."
Very atmospheric animated policier should deliver the goods for older as well as younger audiences.
How do you make something essentially dreary of the sexy progress of an unscrupulous roué in Belle Epoque Paris? Bel Ami is your answer.
Caffeinate yourself--severely--before this one.
movie_title: Historias que so existem quando lembradas (Found Memories) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Terrific, big-hearted flick about a table-tennis tournament that brought a country back together.
Portrait of the Loser as a Young Chub should be the subtitle of Todd Solondz's latest attack against normalcy.
Derivative, white-bread rom-com about a dumped girl seeking happiness in NYC.
Stirringly in-your-face documentary about the Arab Spring revolution is a priceless historical, human document.
Interesting documentary about a wonderful group of idealists with cameras.
movie_title: Ordinary Miracles: The Photo League's New York (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A bogus guru sends a message about the nature of spiritual leadership today in this "Is it for real?" documentary.
Exhilaratingly entertaining Korean rom-com, with sparkling performances and some very original writing.
Well-meaning and well-done for what it is: overly familiar material lacking in viewer allure.
Shoulda been big fun, but a deadly combination of no script and a strange lack of sexiness renders this male-stripper tale an aimless, although very commercially calculated, bore.
Fun, revealing doc about one pop sensation who has truly earned her place in the sun, although the 3D is wholly unnecessary.
Those Wall Street occupiers could learn something from this superbly informative and moving documentary about a movement that really got the job done.
movie_title: United in Anger: A History of ACT UP (2012)

movie_review_blurb: After seeing this doc, the average sinning moviegoer may feel less apprehensive and less in need of an asbestos jumpsuit for the afterlife.
A very mixed bag of short films, but Lily Tomlin, Jesse Tyler Ferguson, Judi Dench and Penny Ryder make it worth catching.
The quality of the material may not be the highest, but the energy and execution of it certainly is in this appealingly sprightly investigation of the world of a capella.
Lavishly entertaining Korean period spectacle works on every level from an ancient but still effective source.
A superb, visually enthralling technical achievement, if somewhat parched dramatically.
A lack of focus and a meandering approach afflict this study of an artist at work.
movie_title: Gottfried Helnwein and the Dreaming Child (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The hectic, wild life of the greatest rock 'n' roll drummer of them all is exposed in this absorbing documentary, which succeeds almost in spite of itself.
There is matchless beauty here in both the actors and the setting, but this study of family and race needed a surer auteurial hand.
Say and film what you like about her, even in this somewhat wrongheaded if worshipful film portrait, Marilyn Monroe still triumphs just by being herself.
My nominee for the saddest film of the year.
One of the cleverest, funniest and most appallingly true films of the year.
More rom-dram than com, this well-written and acted film rises above the usual genre expectations thanks to the talent on display.
We'll take this warmly directed, deeply affecting supernatural romance over the entire synthetic Twilight series any day.
Even without its central subject actually weighing in, this likeably scruffy documentary tells you a lot about the impetus behind shredding and being gnarly.
Strictly recommended for the besotted Anglophile set who revel in watching endless versions of the privileged set enjoying their privileges.
Moving documentary about a campaign to bring World War II veterans to Washington.
Beautifully made, deeply inspirational documentary about one history-making couple.
Highly entertaining and informative exploration of the great, if undeniably difficult, composer Richard Wagner.
This gay custody-battle drama beautifully delivers on every level, especially emotionally.
There are survivor tales, and then there is Jason Becker's, utterly jaw-dropping in its inspiration.
The most creative film of the year: a striking, one-of-a-kind, hilarious dystopian epic of animated weirdness.
La Streisand is better than she's been in a while, but that's not enough to recommend this too thinly scripted, facilely titled would-be audience pleaser.

Some nice comic points are scored against all those awful, over-indulgent parents turning out new generations of impossible brats, but not enough to compensate for the commercial family slop in which they float.
Intelligent, sincere diatribe against venal corporate interests is highly watchable, only marred by an unconvincingly slick denouement.
The carriage trade will line up for debut helmer Dustin Hoffman's endearing treatise on aging and music, which is far more delicate than The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel.
"Glee" favorite Chris Colfer wrote and stars in this particularly self-serving vehicle, the narcissism of which impedes the fun.
For those who like their cinematic rides fast, furious and unencumbered by too much brain matter, this would-be Tarantino-esque redneck piece of rowdiness may entertain.
The keening, otherworldly sound of Antony and The Johnsons provides the aural backdrop for this exploration of femininity in its myriad forms.
A bountiful feast for dance lovers, as well as a thrilling story of artistic endeavor for everyone to savor.
Christopher Plummer works hard to give us his idea of John Barrymore in this record of a theatrical tour-de-force, which is more dramatically florid than biographically enlightening.
Ozwald Boateng may be the only designer who is more compellingly attractive than any of his models, and this less-than-deep documentary fully captures his undeniable charisma.
The actors work overtime to make this would-be sensitive study of troubled youth work, but are undone by the windy triteness of the script.
movie_title: Someday This Pain Will Be Useful to You (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Exhilarating, dazzlingly colorful portrait of an artist with the ability to literally transform the world around him.
Highly original animated divertissement, filled with surprising depth and humor.
Labored anti-right-wing comedy begins with a ridiculous premise and arbitrarily piles up the outrageousness to a numbing degree.
Glossy tribute from a son to his eminent guru of a papa is not so different, even with all that spirituality, from recent film portraits of Katy Perry and Justin Bieber.
Your enjoyment of this baby-obsessed queer farce will depend largely upon your tolerance for seeing yet another group of gay urbanites incessantly sniping about it all.
This entry in the returning-vet genre should probably have gone straight to the Lifetime channel.
Kevin James delivers solid entertainment with a surprisingly wide-ranging appeal in this unlikely mash-up of high-school education and ultimate fighting.
This film noir homage should have been fun, but it's cheaply shot and indifferently conceived
This documentary about an imperishable pop icon of the 1980s, although not the deepest, is every bit as irresistibly likeable as its subject.
Sincere, moving entry about the battle for same-sex marriage.
Witty French import centered on a group of young female slackers.
Self-indulgent drama in which braying actors spout utter twaddle about the Thea-tah.
This warm, witty, sensuous and quite wonderful study of a disabled artist terrifically avoids any "triumph of the human spirit" sentimentality.
This comedy about two teens losing their virginity aims for hilarity but instead achieves ho-hum status.
Cornball adjectives like "inspiring" and "uplifting" are for once entirely accurate in describing this engaging documentary.
movie_title: Long Shot The Kevin Laue Story (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Ingratiating, if too short, record of a Hollywood institution anyone would be happy to attend.
The characters here are swamped not only in huge surf, but in the unmitigated corn of a hopelessly mawkish screenplay.
Reverent if none-too-probing portrait of a master of the micro-managed tableau.
Undoubtedly stirring documentary, marred by that seemingly inescapable, audience-non-trusting bane: the re-enactment.
A small but quite lovely and wonderful film, gorgeous to look at, which tackles an age-old subject with radiant freshness.
It's a Weinstein release, but I don't foresee any big Oscar push for this wacky misfire.
Sparked by a nutty but quite wonderful, can't-take-your-eyes-off-him performance by Sean Penn, this unpredictable film carries you along on a wave of surprise and visual beauty.

Isabelle Huppert has an inviting, steady glow in Hong Sang-soo's loosey-goosey, humorously light celebration of the French star, cinema's possibilities, and his colorful, endlessly combative homeland.
There are exploitation films and then some, but this Korean twin-tower disaster epic takes the cake for callously evocative imagery and sentimental schlock.
Ah, James Franco: actor, director, writer, conceptual artist, soap opera star! What can't he do? Answer: Make a cohesive, coherent film about a great American writer.
How could the tale of Toronto's most flamboyant bank robber be turned into such a blah, seen-it-all-before film?
Unrewarding retread of too many films we've seen before,
Cop corruption exposé attempts to be hard-hitting, but is obvious and wholly unconvincing.
One of the most enduringly fascinating actresses in cinema is intriguingly revealed in this admiring documentary, happily laced with tons of movie talk.
Well-intentioned but clumsily wrought, draggy historical tale of a same-religion culture clash.
Ultimately worthwhile tale of a gay custody battle: important, rewarding viewing, but marred by directorial indulgence and excessive length.
Unsettlingly graphic but important exposé of the abuse of hearing-impaired children in Korea stirs the emotions in the most elemental way.

Tired conformists or still staunch rebels, whatever you may think of these punk rockers turned parents, this lively, affecting documentary is a highly worthwhile, often hilarious investigation into the ultimate contradiction.
Bare-budget drama of gay male couple whose "accepted" existence in a small Connecticut town gets overturned when the teacher half is accused of impropriety.
Very entertaining, poignant documentary about a largely forgotten but truly groundbreaking bunch of entertainers.
Classical musicians considered Jascha Heifetz to be God himself, and this rewarding documentary provides ample evidence of that-but this particular God was also kind of cruel.
A prime contender for 2011's biggest cinematic embarrassment.
The beginning may have you wanting to bolt, but stick around, like its heroine does, and you'll be surprised by and drawn into this director's sick but quite relatable vision.
Magnificent achievement by the late Edward Yang pushes him even higher in the pantheon of great directors.
There's so much plot and so many locations in this international finance-steeped thriller that it's one very exhausting but ultimately satisfying rollercoaster.
Affecting but frustratingly terse documentary about horses and the boys who ride them.
Nixon and Reagan would have loved this movie.
Informative but less than thrilling profile of a prominent environmentalist.
movie_title: Force of Nature: The David Suzuki Movie (2011)

movie_review_blurb: An overlong bunch of intertwining stories, none of which is worth the viewer's time.
Brrrr. This study of a young girl's descent into a most rarefied form of whoring is as coldly clinical as it is annoyingly pretentious.
Evil psycho kids can often be a guilty cinematic pleasure, but here, the pretentious, self-conscious, slow direction drains all of the fun.
movie_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin (2012)

movie_review_blurb: This slice of Brooklyn "realism" is a triple threat: badly written, directed and acted.
Unaffecting central performance is a severe liability in this study of the Lower Depths descent of a New York actor.
A triumphantly entertaining examination of the ultimate movie icon, miraculously embodied by Michelle Williams.
Intensely watchable and informative documentary about visionary New York intellectual Paul Goodman.
This distaff basketball tale dribbles away any chance for excitement through a mountainous accumulation of blinding clichés.
Hilarious, sexy and intoxicatingly entertaining Hunter S. Thompson romp.
The script is a chaotic morass of mixed intentions, often forsaking what would really appeal to a young child in favor of cynical attempts to keep their parents awake.
Wonderfully incisive portrait of a thrilling, fraught era in which the fight for right inspired not only Americans, but those living abroad as well.

Entertaining but sometimes sophomoric coming-of-age drama about a gaggle of nice and not-so-nice rich girls at a boarding school, boasting star Rooney Mara before her Social Network/Dragon Tattoo coups.

Despite the development of life-preserving drugs, the AIDS epidemic is sadly still very much in the world. This trenchant documentary reminds us of its roots in a terrifying time which was nonetheless marked by a singular, beautiful humanity.

This lyrical study of love and death may not be everyone's cup of tea, but Gus Van Sant's superb control of and sensitivity to the material make it one of his very best, and one of those rare fiction films which can truly be described as inspiring.
Provocative portrait of a budding ménage-a-trois, done with searching intelligence and potent sensuality.
Well-done, briskly paced and compelling drama with a vital message.
One of the best gay films ever made, although that pigeonholes it unfairly, as this is a finely observed, bracingly intelligent and human work, with an appeal that crosses sexual categorization.
Darkly fascinating documentary reveals the high price to be paid for providing and having fun in a pre-Disneyfied Big Apple.
The Caspian Sea probably has fewer red herrings than this fishy stew of a political thriller.
Warmly uplifting documentary about an inspiring teacher and the funky, funky music he made with generations of happy kids.
Quirky screwball romance has many original points of interest, but is marred by fatal miscasting of a lead.
This Taylor Lautner starrer has a good shot at being the year's most entertaining bad film.
Terrific, uplifting and heartbreaking study of what it's like to teach in America today should inspire intense admiration and even more intense anger over what is revealed.
It's all about the essential mystery of casting here, turning what so easily could have been a ho-hum rom-com into breezy, unchallenging fun.
There are some hearty, mordant laughs to be had in this uneven "cancer comedy," but the best reason to see it is the admirably self-effacing and deeply affecting performance of Joseph Gordon-Levitt.
Totally engaging road movie, lit by ingratiating performances. An impressive directorial debut by Abe Sylvia.
A bad, rather misleading title for a likeably scruffy if somewhat inconsequential study mostly about gay socializing and some politics in Nawlins.
Terrific, deeply affecting rock documentary that captures the unlikely assemblage of a bunch of L.A. black guys playing the kind of music no one had ever really heard before.
movie_title: Everyday Sunshine: The Story of Fishbone (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Utterly unnecessary, ham-fisted remake of a supposed 1980s "classic."

One could surmise that this is some kind of sneaky put-on by Pedro Almodóvar, but his grandiose handling of a very unappetizing tale, rife with weird misogyny, makes it pretentious pulp and nothing more.

Julia Roberts plays ultra-sensitive artiste Ryan Reynolds' noble mother-and that should basically tell you all you need to know about this misguided soapy bunch of bollocks which somehow made its way off the shelf into theatres.

There's enough boxing footage, of course, to satisfy avid fans of the sport, but the brothers' personal history is the real attraction here, with its fascinating revelations about their homeland and culture.
Shameless, would-be holiday heartwarmer...a commercial conglomerate of star-ridden sound bytes
Writer-director Chris Brown obviously loathes Christmas, and that's just fine with us, especially as that hostility has resulted in such a dark and funny film.
A surprising delight from start to finish, this is one rom-com with serious, and very funny, nerve.
Vastly diverting documentary about cinema's foremost purveyor of commercial crap, sparked by colorful interviews and a certain element of surprise.
movie_title: Corman's World: Exploits Of A Hollywood Rebel (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Two friends, surrounded by parenting pals, decide to do it platonically and you can see the ending coming a mile away in this forced farce, with intermittent moments of hilarity and truth.
Shoulda, coulda, woulda been fun. But it ain't.
Wonderfully intelligent coming-of-age story, filled with resonant questions of faith and done with a rare subtlety which honors the audience.
This study of the interactive lives of a bunch of dreamers-although the cynical might dismiss them as mere losers-is sensitive to a fault, but not much fun to watch.
Indie pap, populated by determinedly eccentric characters you don't give a toss about.
Would-be 'triumph of the human spirit' saga set among wheelchair-bound dancers blows it through shallow concept and characterizations.
A great play made into a dreary, over-indulgent movie.
Little fun for the entire family.
Bashed heads and shattered teeth on ice may not seem the likeliest premise for comedy, but real, consistent laughs are nonetheless generated in this fresh sports raunch-fest.
Fluffy footwear documentary plays mostly like a luxe shopping promo.
Likeable documentary about a Beat Generation hotspot that makes you want to pack up your laptop and write away in some cheap garret with a shared toilet.
One more bummer supernatural thriller, all too easy to figure out and with an arty overlay that mitigates pulpy enjoyment.
An important documentary about little-known, vital Japanese-American efforts to win World War II succeeds in imparting the story, although marred by some clumsily obvious directorial choices.
Initially promising teen comedy-drama, featuring African-American kids not in the ghetto for once, soon undermines itself in a welter of clichés and empty gloss.
Hardcore investigation of ghetto life is undoubtedly powerful but proves perplexing, intent-wise.
School days have never been wilder onscreen than in this vividly entertaining and funny clash between a young Christian's sensibilities and the ultimate radicalization into which he is seduced.
A case involving the murder of a black youth gets solved here, but absolutely nothing could help this numbingly awful, undoubtedly well-intentioned but who-cares-it's-so-bad farrago.
This would-be serious exposé of elder abuse is so mishandled it merely becomes an endless, clumsy and finally patronizing litany of woe, offering no real insights or solutions.
Everything you ever wanted to know about marijuana, but were too buzzed, lethargic or just plain hungry to ask.
This French study of young amour (with a terrible, obvious English title) is so sensitive it hurts, as well as overlong, self-indulgent and none too compelling.
movie_title: Un amour de jeunesse (Goodbye First Love) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A young Hollywood hopeful resorts to porn, and his lowered expectations match yours as you trudge through this latest gay--but really grim--offering by tireless auteur Casper Andreas.
A clumsily titled but winsome romantic comedy that quietly sneaks its way into your affection.
Three real-life horror stories are linked by the theme of debt in this informative but sometimes wandering doc.
A completely unique portrait of the ultimate nonconformist.
movie_title: The Ballad of Genesis and Lady Jaye (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A compassionate study that admirably refrains from pumping up the sentimentality.
With its generic title and underdeveloped mash-up of genre clichés and trademark Joel Silver flame-ups, this desperately conceived party feels tired.
A living horror show, rocker Bobby Liebling's sad, appalling tale is told in a film that will have some niche appeal but little else.
Strictly recommended for those dying to watch crystal meth addicts being, well, crystal meth addicts, with every attendant horror. Anyone?
Highly satisfying and smart thriller, which should quiet all the naysayers who might have thought this much-anticipated zeitgeist remake project wholly unnecessary.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Facilely obvious, cartoon-like "fun" for the entire family might well have worked better in a truly animated version.
An understandable hit in its country, this Korean rom-com/horror film charmingly sneaks its way under your skin.
Dee Rees' funny, deep and tender film about black lesbians definitely earns a place in screen history: a first in many ways, so rich and so beautifully done.
"Loosies" are what you call single cigarettes you can buy in New York bodegas, and that is about all you'll really learn from this strenuously rambunctious effort.
The best way to consider this wayward mess is as an unintentional genre spoof.
For all of its commercial clichés, this joyously populated new gospel musical lives up to its title: It's rousing fun and, in the person of Jeremy Jordan, a true star is born.

As presented here, the epic, inspiring life of miraculously tireless star and activist Harry Belafonte is enough to make any of us feel like lazy bums, and should be screened at Occupy events the world over.

Perhaps hypnotized by all the nubile flesh on view, this documentary about Paris' Crazy Horse cabaret starts off slowly but, although overlong for what it is, manages to gain some interest in its focus on the backstage energy.
Enjoyable, endearing portrait of a true Broadway icon.
Deeply impressive and disturbing exposé of what went terribly wrong with one hopeful post-War American housing experience.
movie_title: The Pruitt-igoe Myth: An Urban History (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Madonna has fashioned quite an entertainingly fancy bauble of an ultimate chick flick, especially in her striking, glamorous evocation of the legendary Windsor romance.
The unimaginative approach of both director and screenwriter make this attempt at classy horror singularly uninvolving and lacking in the essential element of surprise.
A strong candidate for the most nauseating film of the year, in every sense.
Get a bunch of male hotties reciting Shakespeare's most immortal love poetry to one another and you have a hot movie, right? Wrong!
It's the ultimate date movie, due to Channing Tatum and the real-thing chemistry he shares with Rachel McAdams.
One man's address of worldwide poverty makes for compelling viewing in Holly Mosher's deeply humane and inspiring, if somewhat simplistic, documentary.
movie_title: Bonsai People: The Vision of Muhammad Yunus (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Director Jill Sprecher and her co-writer sister Karen have surprisingly created a very convincing macho world of men, with all their varied quirks and obsessions, that is a product of some keen and efficacious observation.
A long running time, too many characters and too much whimsy and corn make this romantic romp more of a slog than a soufflé.
It's far from perfect, but this genially satiric take on yuppies thrown into the scarily holistic, vegan universe is determined to give the audience a good time and largely delivers.

Intentionally bad is the basic ambition of sketch comics Tim Heidecker and Eric Wareheim and, if that's enough, then all true movie masochists should adore this steaming pile of the very stuff that inspires so much of their humor.
movie_title: Tim and Eric's Billion Dollar Movie (2012)

movie_review_blurb: New Zealand coming-of-age story has moments of beauty and warmth, but is ultimately too twee by half.
The entire history of politically inspired printmaking unfolds in Manfred Kirchheimer's admirably serious, hands-on documentary.
A dramatically challenging sequel, given warmly effective heart and soul by lead actor Ohad Knoller.
Rarely have actors worked so hard to pull off such thin material, despite Roman Polanski expertly doing everything expected of him in the driver's seat.
Loving doc about a legendary recording studio is one of the very best-and quite essential-movies about rock music ever made.

[The director's]non-judgmental, unmelodramatic, deadpan approach is beautifully gauged, somehow creating in the viewer a grudging admiration for this unsinkable, if always wrong, valiant little warrior.
Fetchingly produced, highly diverting inside look at the making of Mary Poppins nonetheless suffers from paucity in the script department.
Gachot has been following Richner since 1996, and his film is a loving, straightforward portrait of the man.

Forget Liz and Dick or Brangelina, for true art-house fans -- who could be called the Criterion Set today -- Bergman and Ullman are the couple we want to know about, and this doc really delivers the goods.

For pure genre lovers, all of this will be pure catnip, and for others, once you accept all the derivativeness and noisome clichés, it may deliver real, if somewhat primitive, migraine-inducing entertainment.
Singularly brilliant concept makes for a highly intriguing viewing experience until it begins to peter out towards the end.
An exhaustingly long but ultimately worthwhile doc with a great, deserving subject at its center: one of the world's great museums, undergoing an overhaul.

Enigmatically titled but thrillingly direct, heart-shattering portrait of two boys' hardscrabble lives earns an easy comparison with some of the greatest Italian neo-realist works about kids in perilous poverty.

Perhaps the most visually beautiful film this year, Ralph Fiennes' triumphant second time at bat as a director is an intelligent and deeply moving account of a little-known but vital part of Charles Dickens' life.
A truly one-of-a-kind film from James Franco & Co. seriously, intelligently and movingly addresses sexuality in film
There's a wealth of talent, most of it poorly used, in this disappointingly misconceived holiday offering.
Documentary portrait of a great photographer is hampered by the taciturn nature of its subject.
movie_title: In No Great Hurry: 13 Lessons in Life with Saul Leiter (2013)

movie_review_blurb: This elaborately constructed, visually appealing, well-cast adventure film should have worked, but is sunk by a singularly unmusical script and perfunctory handling.
movie_title: The Adventurer: The Curse of the Midas Box (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Set in a weirdly sterile and unconvincing yuppie utopia, this would-be serious study of heterosexual commingling has an empty, synthetic quality from its very first scenes.
Ah, mumblecore, mumblecore, when will you end?
Well-intentioned but weirdly uninvolving account of one very important aspect of our contemporary urban blight.
Rodrigo H. Vila's documentary...is a deeply loving portrait, with a leisurely pace that proves quite rewarding, as it encourages a rich immersion in the music and persona of its great subject.
movie_title: Mercedes Sosa: The Voice of Latin America (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The existential loneliness...and the evanescent nature of deeper human interaction in a world where sexual compulsion takes top priority are evoked with a powerfully dry yet keen observation that is heartbreaking.

Writer-director Hwang Dong Hyuk has fashioned an abrasively funny farce, filled with droll, observant details about Korean pop culture...and the always farcically fertile, highly combative family unit.
Forced and unfunny in the extreme.
For a documentary which literally concerns itself with drama, Peter Brook: The Tightrope is surprisingly devoid of it.

Kieran Turner's Jobriath A.D. is an admirable attempt to rescue the singer from the junk heap of failed pop culture & it was obviously made with a lot of love & care. However...only a sketchy impression of the artist's real personality comes through
What begins as a rather sweet gay romance and intriguing character study unfortunately degenerates into a luridly over-the-top farrago
Only the most diehard fans of holiday pablum will be able to swallow this Bible-banging hunk of whimsy.
This deeply affectionate and comprehensive bio-doc will be a boon to Bettie Page enthusiasts -- and who isn't one, really?

Set in a seaside town, there are quite lovely images of the ocean and fields... When a flock of geese is captured gliding through the sky, the camera seems to positively lust after them, because so little else is happening.

Dealing with an important subject, this doc has moments of genuine enlightenment but is nearly undone by aggressively sophomoric handling which is in itself a strangely unintended insult to its audience's intelligence.
Despite the filmmakers' good intentions and some agreeable urban atmosphere, this is an unmemorable portrait of a young virgin.
Yes, it's a total cliché, but how kind of wonderful that the French are upholding this sort of corny but sweetly human traditional stuff even in the new millennium.
"Forget the words, follow your heart" is this film's oft-repeated Hallmark card sentiment. You may just want to forget the movie and follow the aisle to the exit.
The filmmakers' big achievement here is the way they deal with [the story], never once resorting to the mawkishness or ugly rabble-rousing hype which all too often accompanies this subject.
Screenwriter Galley Molina based the film on his own experience, going from drug pusher to minister, but, for all that, this cliche-besotted film feels somehow synthetic in the extreme.
movie_title: I'm In Love With A Church Girl (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Some laughs and nice performances, but Diablo Cody's directorial debut -- affecting in spots -- too often reveals its shaky, obvious underpinnings.
There have been other docs about John Waters and his coterie, and a lot of this may be familiar ground to some, but Schwartz's comprehensive focus pays off and fresh information is imparted.
For its intelligence, sensual daring and fecund human empathy, this film won the Palme d'Or at Cannes, and you can certainly see why.
There is widespread concern for human rights and animal rights of every stripe, but after seeing Musicwood, I am now a firm believer in plant rights.
Franco's visual sense and skill with atmosphere are strongly evident here, but, unfortunately, not enough happens in the movie.
Tough, riveting documentary about kids lost and found in Pakistan that contains some wrenchingly emotional scenes you will never forget.
A royal bore.
Delicious insider tales of the making of some of your favorite films enrich this wonderfully informative and entertaining doc about casting directors.

Using a motley mix of often charming animation and live action which includes actual home footage of Jung as a child, as well as the present time...Approved for Adoption strives for a narrative and emotional complexity it sometimes achieves.
movie_title: Couleur de peau: Miel (Approved for Adoption) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Overloaded plotting undoes this initially absorbing crime story.

Simply not enough happens, and the screenwriters might have been wise to add a subsidiary relationship plotline to the mix, focus more on Sam's attempts at more serious writing, or just give those hungry, generous and funny actor pals more to do.
Writer-director Xue Xiaolu manages a good balance between the tartly comic...and heartwarming sentimentality, never going too overboard, thankfully, with the latter.
movie_title: Bei Jing yu shang Xi Ya Tu (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Granted terrifically complete access, Wallach's camera captures the Kabakovs, a truly engaging couple, with an invigorating, inviting intimacy.
movie_title: Ilya and Emilia Kabakov: Enter Here (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A ton of bonhomie and abrasive laughs easily carry this holiday entrée over its more heavy-handed sentimental portions, delivering solid, audience-pleasing entertainment.
"Well-meaning" is about the best one can say about The Geography Club.
Promising comedic premise is undone by sloppy scripting and way-too-easy, ultra-bland choices in its execution.
The subject is the cultural cannibalization of one of the world's most ancient and beautiful cities, and however one-sided the argument is here, the problem is undeniably moving and true.

Unfortunately, despite the subject's import, rookie director Yang shows his inexperience with a needlessly confusing and fractured flashback-filled technique...which keeps one at arm's length from the dramatic involvement.
Another entry in the "Why Should We Care?" department, The Secret Lives of Dorks feels like something we have all been through too many times before.
Andy Cochran's script for Adult World, by turns literate and quirky, and sharply observant throughout, provides the amiable fuel for this funny, endearing study of youthful aspiration.

Not even a minimal intellectual regard for what the filmmakers have callously deemed a brain-dead and bloodthirsty international audience has been granted; the resulting movie is little more than a violent killing machine.
You really care about these people, and given the truly foreign and basically grim nature of their story, that is no small achievement indeed.
What might have been a great, fascinating real-life medical detective story suffers from a serious plot imbalance and one-sided character focus.
Director Gia Coppola makes a very impressive debut.
Although more than a tad hokey, sentimental and wish-fulfilling...Chef is a thorough crowd-pleaser which should have that elusive fun-for-all-ages kind of road-movie appeal.
Direly lacking the innocence and charm so necessary to this brand of fantasy, this Oz has a few good moments but is more likely to engender viewer indigestion rather than delight.
...Broken is a thoroughly dark and nasty enterprise.
Incredible stories of bravery are revealed here, but a taste-challenged approach and a poor, ubiquitous music score dull the impact of the oft-told message.
movie_title: The Rescuers: Heroes Of The Holocaust (2014)

movie_review_blurb: This twee yet gory musical-horror mash-up is just a horror.
The beautiful locales of Cambodia provide a rich background for this sensitive documentary about children impressively overcoming personal tragedy through performance.

Writer-director Michael Maren takes on a subject that is affecting baby-boomers all over the world...and he does so with a certain necessary seriousness and sensitivity. The problem here is that his film is neither very deep nor particularly moving.
Richly rewarding, if maybe too brief, portrait of a great violinist.
movie_title: Speak The Music: Robert Mann And The Mysteries Of Chamber Music (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Life can begin at 90 -- something which this appealing doc demonstrates with admirable humanity.
Lavish, long and impressive, but this epic torn from the pages of Korean history would have benefited from a more straightforward expositional style.
