The Grand Seduction is a bit on the preciously twee side - there's a surfeit of boozy old codgers here - and lacks the whimsical enchantment which lit similar conceits... but overall it's entertaining enough.
This stiff saga of gays in the military, with its manly men being manly together, evokes that tale of repression Brokeback Mountain, while somehow being much less homoerotic than Top Gun.
The result is one huge cinematic morass of gloom, largely unleavened by any redeeming humor -- however black -- or true empathy.
1980s nostalgia again, served up family-style, but all too wanly.
...not a whole hell of a lot happens in writer-director Chris Mason Johnson's Test, which looks particularly thin after the recent HBO debut of Larry Kramer's AIDS-themed The Normal Heart.
What could easily have been a yawn-inducing assemblage of dry legalities is instead a profoundly moving, radiantly smart documentary about the fight for gay marriage.
Don't be daunted by its length -- this historically rooted poetical thriller based on the events of the Prague Spring has a rare intelligence and drive that make the hours fairly fly by.
Smart, brisk political satire, so smoothly done and performed that it overrides certain weaknesses and a climactic sentimental face change.

Towne's premise is, to say the least, a bit trying, and she does not help matters by presenting it in such a grimly purposeful manner, devoid of any relieving black humor one would think inherent in her material.
The accouterments are incessantly elegant but do not disguise the hollowness at the heart of this labored family study.

Ralph Steadman is one of the greatest, most underappreciated living artists, so it's wonderful that this celebratory documentary has arrived. It also happens to be one of the finest docs ever made about an artist.

Writer-director Francois Ozon continues in the absolutely riveting, ultra-voyeuristic vein he carried off with such consummate confidence in In the House with this equally mesmerizing study of yet one more adolescent with a deeply secret life.
...a film experience that might be best described as semi-absorbing.
[Barefoot], constructed of shards of other movies and a surfeit of bad ideas, is lacking in originality and positively perspires in its flailingly failed attempt to deliver quirky entertainment.
Effectively economical adaptation of Zola's Thérèse Raquin results in a handsomely produced, highly satisfying psychological thriller.
Utterly suspense-less, noxious missing-person would-be thriller, overflowing with tired clichés and off-putting revelations.
It all goes down pretty easily but is pretty forgettable withal...

What could have made this clanking contraption of a film work would have been charismatically involving performances from its more-than-able leads. But Posen's insecure style of shooting...robs the actors of any fluid rhythm or potent connection.
...testosterone-overloaded, very generic and very violent genre piece.
...a good-natured movie that feels like one elaborate, protracted TV episode.
The whole affair is so slickly mechanical, devoid of any real thrill or authentic human feeling, that it begs the question: Don't even genre movies need some kind of a soul, too?
Doc about practitioners of the "New Burlesque" salutes their admirable courage and staunch individuality, but their fully uncensored, fully unfettered exhibitionism may not be for the squeamish.
The plot of McCanick, sketchy to begin with, is made even more so by Daniel Noah's woozy, fragmented script, and direction by Josh C. Waller for which "clumsy" is almost too kind a description.
Director Raymond De Felitta, working from a strong, vivid script by Jonathan Fernandez, finds the perfect mordant comic tone with which to tell this improbable but true story.
This is Franco's second directorial collaboration with the artiste who goes by the name of Carter, and hopefully they won't push their luck further.
Completely engrossing, rich and humane documentary about the life of a too-little known pioneer in life and art.
It's a pity so much deadly serious effort has gone into something that isn't very original or exciting in the first place.
Completely captivating doc about the most undiscovered of real artists
So abysmal, so unintentionally funny.
Fascinating documentary about the human history of the Galapagos Islands which is, as is so often the case, more dramatic than any kind of cooked-up tropical fiction.
movie_title: The Galapagos Affair: Satan Came To Eden (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Marvelously moving and quite inspirational documentary about the potent, peace-making power of dance.

Informative, absorbing, but as obvious as its title and a bit too glib for its own good, this French import will appeal mainly to religious addicts fascinated by the feverishly agenda-ridden internal workings of the Catholic Church.
Deeply loving, if too slight

The plot is completely shallow and endlessly derivative, but the performers manage somehow to pierce through the cliché-ridden morass and offer some charm...Make Your Move delivers a reliably good time.
Writer-director John Stockwell finds the perfect loose yet manic tone for his ode to weed, filling his script with mordantly pungent lines
Handsomely filmed but wan period romance.
A question of sheer ballsy attitude over true comic substance, this raunchy remake does the job. Sort of.
Writer-director Christina Yoo has fashioned a film that can only be described as somewhat bizarre in its mash-up of American and Korean rom-com tropes.
As lifeless as its heroine, whose fate is so baldly spelled out in that title, this period confection strives for high romance but achieves mere ennui.

As the end credits finally rolled, the best review was uttered by a woman in the row behind me: "This is the kind of movie they'll show on Starz in a couple months and you'll watch when you're really bored."
Tackling the most lurid of subjects, this schlocky shocker proves that sometimes female directors can be as exploitative as men.
Engrossing, compassionate documentary about the fight over medical marijuana in Montana.
The rich life and world of a true theatre artist, seen through the eyes of an adoring wife.
movie_title: André Gregory: Before and After Dinner (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Absolutely smashing, revealing documentary about one of the great photographers of our time.
This ultra-slight, minimalist and arty affair brims over with indie ennui.
Wish-fulfillment black comedy engages through its winsome (if violent) premise and highly attractive leads, but shows some strain towards the end.
Vitally important theme unstrung by shaky direction, writing and acting and a major flaw in subtitling.
Prize-winning documentary paints an affecting tale of young GDR rebels on wheels, but is marred by a busy, self-conscious aesthetic approach.
With its borderline NC-17 sex and not a little wit, this indie rom-com from Canada puts a refreshing new spin on the boy meets bad-girl trope.
Baseball, little kids and religion could be a queasy formula for the movie blues but, happily, this one slides down pretty easily.
Chock-a-block with creativity and cleverness, but ultimately too much of muchness.
Handsomely produced but indifferently scripted account of one of the most legendary sea voyages.
Stirring, beautifully filmed and highly personal history of India does right by Salman Rushdie's celebrated novel.
Fashionistas will kvell over this paean to the Mecca of Materialism.
Wonderfully droll horror comedy with a memorably weird cast of characters.
The dreariest party ever filmed. Don't bother to RSVP.
Bloody awful.
Low-key, low-budget but highly likeable comedy about magicians in all their trickery.
A single, plotless day in New York in the company of Keanu Reeves feels like a life sentence.
Anything-goes, loopily autobiographical romp about the travails of a desperate actress it would be a nightmare to encounter in real life. But haven't we all, on some level?
movie_title: He's Way More Famous Than You (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The perfect macho date movie for that Type A juicehead in your life, marked by Mickey Rourke's ever-accelerating descent into Lon Chaney-esque grotesqueness.
Worshipful documentary about rocker turned guru Krishna Das will basically appeal to the already-and very, very happily so-converted.
movie_title: One Track Heart: The Story of Krishna Das (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Dreary animated civics lesson with even drearier imagery.
Forced and unfunny portrait of a Young Woman as a Loser.
This theatre-centric frolic has a clever, pleasing start, but sadly degenerates into bland formula stuff.
The very slight charms of this picaresque, quite extended two-character stroll through Paris may well elude all but the most committed Jacques Rivette devotees.
Totally bogus anti-war film, set in a 1969 that bears no resemblance to any actual period.
Loving documentary about one of the greatest, and still wonderfully extant, poetic and political forces of our time.
Breezily charming film is more heart-on-the-sleeve warm and visually generous.
movie_title: A Glimpse Inside the Mind of Charles Swan III (2013)

movie_review_blurb: This ultra-nasty conceit should satisfy many a genre fan's inner sadist.
The entire enterprise feels as phony as a fake Yule tree
Couples could do a lot worse on Valentine's Day than seeing this romantic drama which, although springing from the same author, is far less bathetic than the popular The Notebook.
The plot may be a challenge to figure out, but this crisply directed spy thriller from Korea holds your attention through its overall smooth professionalism.
Talk is cheap, but never more so than in this tiresome bore about yuppies in love, filmed in an annoyingly self-conscious manner.
This international thriller-sparked by a nice, unexpected Marisa Tomei performance-starts off promisingly but trails off into cheap melodrama.
Comprehensive yet lighthearted dissection of one very popular song is a pretty surefire audience winner.
Its blandly generic title is all too disappointingly germane to this loving but far from incisive documentary covering a vital time in music history.
movie_title: Greenwich Village: Music That Defined a Generation (2013)

movie_review_blurb: If you like psychological/supernatural thrillers that are relentlessly grim and creepy, this is recommended. Others who like their horror to be at least a little on the fun side may find this just numbing.
Very DIY project covers the scary gentrification of a beloved New York neighborhood, but ends up being more a whine-fest than truly powerful.
The approach may have a distracting, overly fancy, diluting quality to it, but attention must nevertheless be paid to this film's basic theme.
The rom-com genre keeps scraping bottom, and this particular annoyance is about as low as you can get.
Admiring if less than revealing documentary about one of the great writers of our time.
Commercial wannabe that still suffers from the art-house pretensions and severe limitations of its auteur.
There's no reason in the world why this father's loving tribute to his own two kids should be as uncannily riveting or delightful as it is.
Alice Englert gives the standout performance as one of the titular characters in this perhaps too-smart-for-its-own-good study of troubled adolescence.
An anti-rom-com in the best sense, Joan Carr-Wiggin's film joyously revives the screwball tradition with real wit, as well as making one fabulously tart female buddy movie.
Winsome, winning entry from Studio Ghibli, with a nostalgia-suffused, unstressed ambiance that packs a potent if subtle appeal.
This glowingly effective and intelligently low-key documentary manages to be both a stirring family drama and a valuable depiction of gay life and history in Paraguay.
One of the best comedies in a while, this bracingly smart, affecting romp is that rare Hollywood screen farce which doesn't insult your intelligence and should find wide appeal.
Reverse-engineered from several gangster classics, New World is like the knockoff shades and counterfeit wristwatches its antihero complains about: flashy but ultimately cheap.
Loving, truly inspirational documentary which captures the lion-sized spirit of a very special artist.
movie_title: You Don't Need Feet to Dance (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The "oh-so-innocent waif and big old baddie" odd-couple formula dates back to D.W. Griffith, but this muddled effort does nothing to merit its questionable revival.
You don't even need to be high to enjoy this gratifyingly candid, funny and moving portrait of the Grand Master Toker.

Foster is a fascinating subject, but his achievement should be scrutinised much more rigorously than this.
movie_title: How Much Does Your Building Weigh, Mr. Foster? (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Veers too close to hagiography, although it's visually arresting enough to carry you through sagging in the narrative.
movie_title: How Much Does Your Building Weigh, Mr. Foster? (2012)

movie_review_blurb: While this is informative, accessible and engaging, it tends to be frustrating and flawed as well.
movie_title: Genius Within: The Inner Life of Glenn Gould (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This is potent, passionate and provocative stuff. But it's also irresistibly poetic and unexpectedly playful.
It's Grau's social commentary and insights into the adolescent psyche, rather than the gore, that make this so compelling.
Keiller's follow up to his cine-essays London and Robinson In Space is another intelligent, thought-provoking piece of filmmaking.
Whether muttering threats and tips about tea-making under his breath or stalking Howman, Winstone looks decidedly uncomfortable.
Keiller finds melancholic magic in the discarded domestic and industrial edifices of a landscape that has much to tell us -- if only we're prepared to look and listen.
A movie that's impeccably played and chillingly compelling.
The pacing is sometimes overly languid, the script often ponderous and the performances decidedly mixed. But this knowing drama is undoubtedly a laudable effort.
Amalric's second stab at feature direction marks him out as a talent to watch.
The subject is fascinating, but the approach is flawed.
Hampered by over-scripted dialogue and an uncomfortable mid-film shift into thriller mode.
Slickly funny and polished romantic-comedy.
Luna makes fine use of production designer Brigitte Broch's shabbily cosy interiors to prevent the film from turning into a twee shantytown fairy tale...
Punchily played and cannily directed, this may be a touch contrived and overpopulated with minor characters, but it's still highly entertaining.
While this isn't always an easy film to watch, it does make important and seemingly incontrovertible connections between Washington and big business that should alarm us all.
A beautiful, sensous ode to love, life and Lisbon.
While it's not comprehensive - even at the height of his fame Gould was an enigma and remains so - Genius Within is an engaging and intriguing bio-doc.
movie_title: Genius Within: The Inner Life of Glenn Gould (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Drags in places and deosn't even try for a true-to-life portrait of the great theatre entrepeneur but it's shiny and big spectacle with impressive choreography.
The methodology employed by Thet and co-director Rob Lemkin is occasionally manipulative and the truth often remains elusive. But this is absolutely compelling, nonetheless.

Mercilessly ribbing the James Bond movies and Graham Greene's espionage entertainments, the ninth Carry On saw Barbara Windsor make her series debut as the most resourceful of a hamstrung quartet of agents sent to Vienna to recover a secret formula.
Using the Bard as a route to examining British identity and the role of young people in society makes for interesting, occasionally insightful viewing.
A mediocre sitcom with too many preachy subplots.
More gripping than a Michael Vaughan foxtrot, this is the perfect docu-thriller for the Strictly aficionado.
A violent Korean anime with real teeth.
Enjoyable but slight.
Candid and compassionate. Loud, too.
It's Koreeda's subtly elliptical storytelling and measured control of character, locale and pace that makes this so engaging.
Awkward, spartan storytelling from Korean director So Yong Kim that captures the tender heart of family bonds.
[A] harrowing exposé of child abuse within the Roman Catholic Church, which reveals the extent the Vatican has been actively involved in covering up crimes committed by priests.
movie_title: Mea Maxima Culpa: Silence In The House Of God (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Deliciously blending Sacha Guitry's The Pearls of the Crown and Ophüls's own La Ronde, this is just about as polished as European cinema gets.
movie_title: The Earrings of Madame De... (Madame de...) (1954)

movie_review_blurb: Angry, impassionate filmmaking that demands - and deserves - serious answers.

Writer/director Viv Fongenie works hard to assess the impact of schizophrenia on sufferers and those around them, but any claims that this movie is Donnie Darko meets Billy Liar are well wide of the mark.
A timely doc that seeks to amuse and inform as much as alarm.
Assarat's freeform film is sometimes tantalising if noodle-baking stuff. If you can divine its meaning, take the rest of the year off.
Gold for folk fans.
Mizoguchi regular Isuzu Yamada contributes a superb display of abused decency, but it's the director's astute visual sense that gives the picture its power.

Gance's use of subjective camera was almost recklessly ambitious in its bid to give the spectator the most visceral viewing sensation, while his skill in blending and multiplying images was unprecedented.
Asquith's subterranean melodrama is a fascinating journey back in time.
A masterclass in satirically nostalgic New Wave modernism.
Bleak and compelling.
It's sobering stuff but the film's impact is somewhat diminished by Orlowski's reverential profile of Balog, who continues to crusade despite the toll his endeavours have taken on his body.
A touching and revelatory piece of film-making about the plights of real people living in an uncertain world.
The cast works hard, but not even the climactic tempest can whip up much excitement.
It's compelling stuff, and the climactic reunion performance of In My Chair will have toes tapping and stiff upper lips quivering.
As angry and unflinching a piece of documentary filmmaking as you'll see this year.
At three hours long and deliberately paced throughout, this edgy drama return by Cristi Puiu demands patience.
This is a rousing portrait of East End punks the Cockney Rejects and the Canning Town that spawned them.
A fascinating narrative set in modern-day Indian and full of insights into a class-riven country.
A carefully constructed survivor's tale.
An intense, emotional ride. Uplifting and inspiring.
Rivals Julian Schnabel's 2007 film The Diving-Bell and the Butterfly in its portrayal of human courage and fortitude.
Good, old-fashioned family fun.
movie_title: When Santa Fell to Earth (Als Der Weihnachtsmann Vom Himmel Fiel) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Writer/director Barrett delivers a promising debut that pitches four believable characters into the euphoria and dismay of post-uni life.
Lustrous photography and a fine cast make this dark drama a compelling one.
Still good enough to eat.
This chillingly acted thriller is convoluted but compelling.
While it's easy to look at these often beautiful moving postcards, Fricke presents locations without identifying them, so most viewers will quickly find themselves lost and overwhelmed.
Bresson's masterpiece is still a pinnacle in French cinema.
movie_title: Un condamné à mort s'est échappé ou Le vent souffle où il veut (A Man Escaped) (1957)

movie_review_blurb: A marvel of poise and circumspect emotion from French auteur Robert Bresson.
Compelling morality tale that works on multiple layers.
Like Come And See in neighbouring Belarus, it's a stark vision of humanity in a hellish world. Tough and thought-provoking.
Funny and freewheeling, it's a joy.
While not exacty up to contemporary standards of social realism this domestic saga was ground-breaking in its day and still captivates.
Director Fred Schepisi strives effectively to mine the gold in Patrick White's social study. Top notch performances from the stellar cast help him nail the book's citric tone.
Visually immaculate and thought-provoking stuff.
movie_title: Village At The End Of The World (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Dynamically played and superbly handled.
Elliott Nugent directs with some atmospheric touches, but can't counter screenwriter Richard Maibaum's verbosity.
Rosenblum even suggested the use of New Orleans jazz on the soundtrack, which became a staple of future Allen projects.
Rapid-fire gags and some inspired one-liners qualify this as an early classic from Allen.
A potent black comedy with the gentle touch of a razor blade.
An exceptional performance by Emilie Dequenne dominates this powerful drama inspired by the harrowing case of Brussels mother of five Geneviève Lhermitte.
This is so awful it can't be missed.
It's Rob Lowe's wildly unbelievable performance as the mentally disabled Rory (which seems to belong to another film altogether) that you'll be discussing once the movie's over.
Authentic in its depiction of both the filmic and domestic milieux, this is delicate, incisive, touching and trenchant.
movie_title: The Father of My Children (Le pere de mes enfants) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This forgettable comedy western is quite dreadful.
There's a lot to think about - sacrifice, faith, poverty and much more - but it all feels too crammed into its running time, and is delivered in an uninspiring fashion.
A interesting curio that veers from saucy to serious in disorientating fashion.
Despite Sewell's laconic ruthlessness, Stephens's steely taciturnity and Byrne's world-weary arrogance, there's an all-round lack of conviction.
Constantly engaging.
Bresson's cinematographic tour de force is still incredibly impressive and affecting.
movie_title: Diary of a Country Priest (Journal d'un curé de campagne) (1954)

movie_review_blurb: Views of the Northumberland coast are sublime but, for all its sincerity, this is self-consciously arty and a little stultifying.
Often fascinating and impassioned, Loach's doc lapses into polemic towards the end, an understandable side-effect of his granite-strong convictions.
A bruising psychodrama from the Palme d'Or winner that taps into the dark heart of central European superstition.

It's a microcosmic melodrama that uses a bustling symbol of progress to analyse a state divided not just by social injustice, but also by cultural and religious chasms that are widened by external forces.
movie_title: Bab el hadid (Cairo Station) (The Iron Gate) (1958)

movie_review_blurb: Harold Lloyd manages to make the characters sympathetic enough to carry the audience's concern on his journey of crazy stunts and mishaps. One of the best of this era.
Put it this way, it's the birth of the Bollywood blockbuster. It should be on every cineaste's must-see list.
The performances are admirable and the intentions unimpeachable.
A hugely impressive debut feature from Kleber Mendonça Filho.
Despite the film's distinctive look and the best efforts of the willing cast, this amusing, morbid and mildly misanthropic mélange always seems to be straining for effect.
Essentially a two-hander, with Fox admirable as a latter-day Sebastian Flyte and Bogarde (finally nailing his matinée reputation) chilling as the mercenary valet.
A compelling look at the lingering devastation of war.
The farce is forced, the gags grate and the standard of playing varies wildly.
A measured, painterly debut.
Whichever of the various interpretations you ascribe to this socio-political parody, the quality is undeniable.
A tough, compelling thriller touching on race, prejudice and contemporary Britain. Not Blitz, in other words.
Garrone's critique of Italy's current cultural vapidity is too indulgently affectionate and lacks both originality and bite.
A tough but deeply rewarding watch. Search it out.
It was the performance of Harvey Stephens as the young Damien that invested the film with the chill of genuine credibility.

If Cassavetes' hipster cine-language has lost a little of its age and the innovative improv style won't be for everyone, the themes he tackles, riffed by a masterful group of actors, remain enthralling.
Still an expert mix of sentiment, comedy, patriotism and anarchy.
Glossy rather than gripping, it's nonetheless an interesting insight into one of the planet's most bustling corners.
A controversial exploration of different faiths. Newcomer Julie Sokolowski shows her mettle.
It's relatively effective as a thriller, but rarely welcomes the viewer into its world of legalities and despair.
With Shigeru Umebayashi's score and Amit Trivedi's songs proving as atmospheric as the ravishing cinematography, this is never less than compelling.
There's few sharp edges or dirt digging, but it's no less engaging for that.
Complex and sophisticated, this genre-defying crime story is spellbinding viewing.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Anatolia (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The performances are as impeccable as Gokhan Tiryaki's cinematography, but it's Ceylan's mastery of composition and pacing that makes this so visually striking and dramatically compelling.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Anatolia (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Some sparkling moments but this rare Hitchcock comedy farce is hit and miss.
Quietly compelling, the cerebral slice of social realism is well worth hunting down.
Much-maligned it may be, but the so-called mumblecore movement continues to turn out gems.

Shenk draws on archive material to chronicle Nasheed's courageous battle against longtime dictator Maumoon Abdul Gayoom, but it's the unprecedented access he has to his subject that makes this movie so revealing and compelling.
Lena Dunham demonstrates a keen eye for detail, a sharp ear for dialogue and a nice line in deadpan playing in this, her debut feature.
This effective chiller bears more than a passing resemblance to The Baby's Room, Alex de la Iglesia's contribution to the 2006 Spanish TV series Films to Keep You Awake.
A charming, visually sparkling Parisian fantasy with a dark edge.
Mae West is at her inimitable best, in this risque tale that shot her to stardom.
Tender and touching, this gay coming-of-ages story is underpinned by a terrific, subtle turn from newcomer Florizoone.
Tense and slick, this early thriller remains a true masterpiece.
Marlene Dietrich tries not to give anything away as usual while Agatha Christie's whodunit plot whirs tidily about her expressionless beauty.
Shocking in both its grim authenticity and explosive stylisation.
Less a study of the desire to die than the terrifying realisation that there is no reason left to live.

It's splendidly played with an understated intensity that deftly captures the shifting emotional tone of the relationship.
Charming but uneven, director Améris's film doesn't know whether to make us laugh or cry, and ends up doing neither. Still, a smart script offers plenty to keep incurable romantics happy.
Infectious and uplifting, it's an hour very well spent.
Occasionally lacking in context but never less than intriguing, Jarreth Merz's polished film is a handy document to a rarely visited democracy.
Gory and close to exploitative in its depiction of sexual violence, Ching-Po's thriller packs some serious shocks. Not for the faint-hearted.
movie_title: Revenge: A Love Story (Fuk sau che chi sei) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Storytelling of breathtaking scale and grandeur, even if the complex plotting may twist your synapses along the way.
A beautiful representation of innocence and naivety.
Utterly irresistible.
Spoken word, music and imagery come together to create moments of transcendent beauty. Wise and rather wonderful.
A lengthy, visually impressive period piece with little in the way of new material or fresh spins on history to distinguish it.
D.H. Lawrence has always proved a tricky test for filmmakers, but this is certainly one fo the better translations, thanks in no small part to the cinematography.
A very thin story stretched out for over two hours, this is a melange of the wonderful and the pompous.
Iridescent and teaming with vitality, Garbo glows in her penultimate film.

It's anything but subtle but the magnetism of the cast and sheer exuberance of the storytelling make this fairly irresistible.
movie_title: Crna macka, beli macor (Black Cat, White Cat) (1999)

movie_review_blurb: An expertly forged alt.history with a refreshingly tough female lead. Good tunes, too.
Not for everyone, but still well worth exploring.
A mix of the fascinating and the frustrating...
Sawhney's score brings contemporary melodies to Hitch's silent delight.
movie_title: The Lodger: A Story of the London Fog (1928)

Satirical Samurai action of the highest order.
Humanist film-making at its best.
A truly creepy cast adds to the suspense.
movie_title: The Lodger: A Story of the London Fog (1928)

movie_review_blurb: Maudlin but moving, Yves Caumon's character study speaks softly but with wisdom.

Not Garbo's greatest but it has a curious charm.
A poignant portrait of marriage and a dramatic chronicle of hardships and justice.
Farhadi's gifted storytelling and direction is on show again in a damning look at Iranian society.

A punchy examination of an oppressive corporate machinery in full swing.
There were high hopes of a warts-and-all follow-up to Paine's first film exposing the big guns of automotive, but it hasn't materialised.
A fun, sweet family film.
[An] ambitious but flawed heist-cum-love story.
Shot on a shoestring with a crew of seven, there's quirky delights in this lo-fi road movie.

Markovics flexes his muscles on the other side of the camera with terrific effect. A fine, moving debut for the new writer/director.
Hansen-Løve again shows what a gifted storyteller she is with this tender, realistic portrayal of young love. Highly recommended.
movie_title: Un amour de jeunesse (Goodbye First Love) (2012)

Michel Ocelot's ravishing animation and magical storytelling is a delight from start to finish.
Over-the-top but blackly funny along the way.

Director Christian Petzold's fifth collaboration with muse Nina Hoss often feels like a Douglas Sirk melodrama tinged with a bittersweet "ostalgia" for the repressions and privations of 1980s East Germany.
A micro-budget Brit flick with an experimental flavour that generates real insights into married life.
A lovely jalopy ride around British cinemas.
Tennessee Williams might struggle with the idea of inspiring this project.
Enjoyably satirical and occasionally insightful, it's betrayed by some lazy stereotyping.
movie_title: Les femmes du 6e étage (The Women on the 6th Floor) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: As well as providing a generous helping of shocks, Kneale's script gives his complex themes and theories plenty of space...
movie_title: Quatermass and the Pit (Five Million Years to Earth)(The Mind Benders) (1967)

movie_review_blurb: A truly insightful art film that still manages to be easy-going and unpretentious.
The doughty spirit of D'Arcy and Donlon shines through, as they keep on defying the odds to play another day.
This gently off-beat romance may boast more corn than a packed silo in summer but it's got a tender heart and charm to spare.
A beautiful piece of work: heart-wrending, atmospheric and truly poignant. Recommended.

Suleiman's marvellous and insightful film charts the history of his family in Nazareth from 1948 to the present, and completes the deeply personal trilogy that includes Chronicle of a Disappearance (1996) and Divine Intervention (2002).
Making exceptional use of stillness and silence, this is a rather sad study of the passing of traditional concepts of American masculinity along with the landscape that forged them.
Tabakman makes evocative use of enclosed spaces and silences, and tempers the melodrama with a sociological authenticity that confirms the centrality of belief in Jewish culture.
Poetic, provocative and unstoppably powerful. But, depressingly, it probably won't change a thing.
Astonishingly accomplished debut feature that combines Hitchcockian suspense with a showdown whose unflinching attitude to violence will pin you to the seat.
An early, classic manifestation of the chick flick if ever we saw one, it achieves everything it sets out to.
Disarmingly restrained and terrifyingly tense.
Simmering study of a petty hood-cum-wannabe pianist succumbing to his innate violent side -- but there might be a touch too much ivory tinkling for some.
movie_title: De Battre mon Coeur s'est Arrêté (The Beat That My Heart Skipped) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Cocteau's visual imagination, leading us through mirrors into a bomb-scarred dreamworld governed by the femme fatale of Death, is enduringly magical and strongly cinematic.

Unstintingly raw and cynical.
Even if Rupert Murray's film does turn out to be a hoax, there's no denying the ingenuity involved in its making.
Russian Dolls might not have as many layers as its namesake but when it's this sweet and feisty, it doesn't really matter.
A charming and beautifully planned drama that resolves nothing -- and doesn't need to.
movie_title: Céline et Julie Vont en Bateau (Celine and Julie Go Boating) (1974)

movie_review_blurb: A superb cast valiantly attempts to keep the contrivances of an initially intriguing plot within the bounds of credibility and are ultimately confounded by an excess of ambiguity.
A desperately sad look at two men whose determination to rebel against their heritage and succeed in their artform has rendered them unable to communicate. Compelling stuff, though.
Long, but engrossing and frequently enraging drama that not only exposes the flaws in the Romanian health service, but also in modern humanity.

Despite debunking some of the romantic myths surrounding this fascinating time, Philippe Garrel's ambitious May '68 epic is more interested in mood than drama and, thus, devotes too much time to posturing introspection.
Insightful as ever but a little dated in the set-up and treatment of the shooting.
Suspense gives way to metaphor in a stark thriller that hints at the work to come from master Carol Reed.
Rarely has a kid's-eye view of the adult world been captured with such innocence and insight.
This sexy melodrama and intense psychological thriller provides an original and satisfying mix of romanticism, artifice and realism.
movie_title: Sunrise: A Song of Two Humans (1927)

movie_review_blurb: With its emphasis on harmony and its implied criticism of the decadence of consumerist society, this study of tradition is a rewarding experience.
movie_title: The Story of the Weeping Camel (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A disarmingly sweet, darkly funny charmer.
The performances are better than the material deserves, but, even so, there's often no tangible friction between the female leads.
Masterfully manipulative and bloody scary.
This veers from the heartfelt to the satirical, the scathing to the loving, the funny to the melancholy -- in short, it's everything that great cinema should be.

Federico Fellini's parody of the parasites who bask in the glory of cheap publicity not only exposes the emptiness of their lives, but also of those who report their antics as if they were of world-shattering import.
Whimsical but gritty.
Compelling as much for its wartime release date as its gripping subject, this is melodrama at its most justified with a great group of diverse and interesting characters and real sense of urgency.
The special effects are of a high order as Los Angeles is razed, so it is unfortunate that the same intelligent attention is not extended to either script or direction.
Sometimes unintentionally funny, and it could have done without the customary moralising.

Slick and frequently mesmerising, but ultimately it feels as calculated as the murky, melodramatic denouement.
By recording events with such detailed dispassion, the Dardennes avoid undue melodramatics. Consequently, this Palme d'Or-winning confirmation of the world's cruelty remains unflinchingly powerful.
Compelling, challenging and irresistibly beautiful, this delicate metaphysical masterpiece only emphasises how much cinema lost through Krzysztof Kieslowski's tragically early death.

A compelling study of a small-town lawyer's determination to challenge Cameroon's institutionalised chauvinism, which judiciously combines small triumphs with a daunting sense of the task that lies ahead.

Lacks the charisma or the ingenuity to hook mainstream audiences.
Comedy has rarely been so intricate, incisive and inspired.
With its all-pervading sense of doom, this is a serious contender for the finest celluloid Shakespeare of them all.

Packed with cultural references and sly satire, this is also a hugely entertaining comic romp.

A savage indictment of the system.

Ignore accusations that this is sluggish and inconsequential. This is textbook Kaurismäki, from its drolly laconic style to its delicious cinematic nostalgia.

Not a cheerful evening's viewing, this, but a superb and compelling example of melancholic realism.
