Sally El Hosaini brings sensitivity, distinctive identity and an invigorating adrenaline charge to a story of criminally inclined youth in suburban East London in her dynamic first feature.
Despite the talent involved, this is more a snooze than a dream.
Jamie Linden's minor-key serio-comedy pulls us in eventually, delivering its share of poignant insights and melancholy reflections, even if it does all feel a tad familiar.
There are few surprises in Mary Tobler and Savoca's script as it progresses, but the director has always shown skill at accessing the inner lives of women.
There's hellfire and hot rods aplenty here, but a mindless exploitation entry that should have been appallingly awesome instead marshals too little style or intentional humor.
An impassioned evaluation of the cultural footprint of a landmark play considered both revolutionary and retrograde.
Miguel Arteta's comedy takes a while to find its mojo, but gets there eventually with humanity and heart.
There's yearning as well as stubborn emotional isolation and anger in these characters, and any harshness in the observations of this richly satisfying film invariably is balanced by warmth.
This is an intense exploration of the corrosive effects of human violence. And its eventual glimmer of redemption is entirely earned, not artificial or consoling.
A riveting genre blend of thriller, domestic drama and supernatural horror propelled by a brilliant lead performance.
A key weakness of the documentary is that it doesn't do enough to refute the charges long leveled at the Laurel Canyon league by music critics.

The film captures some impressive landscapes and layers an eclectic mix of original and traditional Armenian music over its unhurried travel time. But unless you count doing a lot of vodka shots, this is a dramatically uneventful two hours.
An enjoyably off-kilter hybrid of The Blair Witch Project and Where the Wild Things Are.
A powerful and emotional story of protracted injustice backgrounded by a potentially even more fascinating account of entrenched corruption in the Los Angeles D.A.'s office.
There's a lovely somber undercurrent at play here about recognizable people doing their best to carve out a decent life in a punishing economy.
A stimulating reflection on the American countercultural protest movement examined through the prism of one of its most impassioned and underappreciated voices.
movie_title: Phil Ochs: There But For Fortune (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Is it too much to ask for a little character development and a touch of humor between the infrequent set pieces?
The less welcome news is that most of the same shortcomings that cramped the first installment are still dogging the sequel, which delivers on action but dawdles through downtime.
movie_title: Lara Croft Tomb Raider - The Cradle of Life (2003)

movie_review_blurb: City of God delivers a bruising, visceral experience of the vicious spiral of violence that draws kids into a life of crime, brutality and murder as the only avenue open to them.
Flavorless writing and direction and a low-wattage cast turn potentially strong material into a routine crime thriller.

A vanity production so self-inflated they needed an extra dimension to contain it, Michael Flatley's Lord of the Dance 3D won't win many new fans for the high-stepping dancer. It might even cost him a few old ones.
Everybody Loves Raymond creator Phil Rosenthal makes a droll guide in this enjoyable first-hand chronicle of how a U.S. sitcom gets adapted for Russian television.
A tender tribute from Elton John to one of his key influences, Leon Russell, and from filmmaker Cameron Crowe to both musicians.
This one-dimensional biopic reduces important 20th century political figures to cardboard cutouts.
Director Juan Carlos Fresnadillo's technical skills are impressive, but this psychological chiller loses traction in the over-explanatory concluding stretch.
The post-Cold War evolution of MI5 is a potentially juicy subject, but while Hare lines up the elements, he fails to take the story anyplace especially revelatory or combustible.
Solid in construction and persuasively acted, the drama is strongest in the establishing sections of intoxicating passion.
A romantic comedy that takes time to find its groove but steadily accumulates heart and humor.
This sophomore feature is a stumble backwards in terms of maturity.
A stirring, finely crafted human-interest story about underprivileged lives touched by the rewards of shared experience.

The primary appeal of Americano lies in witnessing the attempt of a famous progeny to forge his own creative path, as Demy's struggle with artistic inheritance resonates throughout unmoored Martin's voyage between past and present.
Its charms feel somewhat calculated, but this reflective tale of outsider solitude has enough humor and poignancy to win admirers.
This naturalist reflection on a violated world is a little too high on its own holiness, but it introduces a new filmmaker with a distinctive sensibility.
Gripping but grueling, this Spanish debut feature scores on technical prowess but its nihilistic viciousness is hard to take.
The chief function of this trite debut feature appears to be as a job application for its writer-director to join the Hollywood rom-com assembly line.
Rich subject matter and persuasive presentation make this visually appealing nature documentary worth buzzing about.
movie_title: Queen Of The Sun: What are the Bees Telling Us? (2011)

movie_review_blurb: With customary restraint, the Dardenne brothers have added yet another exquisite entry to their masterful body of work.
A star-making turn from the Olsen twins' baby sis will put this disturbing drama on the map.
Soporific in every sense.
An infectiously larky extraterrestrial invasion movie that respects the genre conventions while spicing the brew with distinctive local flavor.
This stiflingly restrained French dirge about morality, guilt and atonement is chilly and constipated, mistaking ponderousness for intensity.
Gayby doesn't break a lot of new ground in the rom-com or parenthood fields, but its agreeable balance of humor and sentiment makes it worth adopting.
A decisive transitional chapter in Chilean history yields an absorbing account of one country's unlikely route from oppression to democracy
Despite her accomplished cast, French director Anne Fontaine summons neither the dramatic heft nor the humor to put across this absurd forbidden-love scenario.
An engrossing reflection on radical violence and its fallout.
A short, sharp burst of concentrated character-based storytelling that builds considerable emotional intensity.
Austrian iconoclast Ulrich Seidl delivers one of his more challenging tracts in this screwy reflection on religious devotion.
Roman Polanski is in playfully perverse form with this nimble pas de deux adapted from David Ives' stage hit.
Rigorously subdued in performance and tone, this low-key character portrait is distinguished by its empathetic honesty.
his gripping film presents a persuasive case against keeping the species -- and by extension any wild animal -- in captivity for the purposes of human entertainment.
The characters overall lack definition, and the writer-director is only moderately successful at accessing the pathos of a story that should be steeped in it.
There's scant originality here, but witnessing America's hearth and home under siege still brings an emotional frisson to the silly thrills.
Neil Jordan interviews a whole new set of vampires but draws precious little blood.
The love between a well-heeled gay Israeli lawyer and a struggling Palestinian student serves to examine harsh realities in both communities in Michael Mayer's textured drama.
A menacingly atmospheric mood piece that will not disappoint devotees of the Nicolas Winding Refn church of fetishistic hyper-violence.

Far more sober than that premise suggests, the unapologetically derivative sci-fi outing doesn't have the scripting muscle to deliver on its early promise. But the solid cast keeps it reasonably gripping nonetheless.
A stylishly made but unyielding drama that will consolidate more than expand director Claire Denis' devoted fan base.
A diverting but generic dose of psychologically thin B-movie suspense from the normally more outré Takashi Miike.
A virtuoso narrative and technical experiment that doesn't stint on dramatic complexity or heart.
A refreshingly mature genre entry that plants queasy dread and unleashes a good dose of scares, tempering its gruesome bloodshed by wrapping it in serious-mindedness.
The film's quiet pleasures creep up on you.
A former P.O.W.'s extraordinary story gets a plodding retelling in Jonathan Teplitzky's poorly-structured drama.
A riot of color and confusion stitched around a flimsy plot, director Jeremy Wooding's debut gets off to a vibrant start and offers intermittent charm, but runs out of steam fast.
A compassionate and frequently funny look at sex addiction that rolls out too many pat developments to muster much depth.
Its protagonist hits an unplanned target, but this increasingly risible mishmash misses at almost every turn.
A fascinating contemplation of adolescent sexuality that will be a star-making platform for its young lead, Marine Vacth.

The director's austere minimalism has always been suspended between the mesmerizing and the distancing, and in his latest feature, the concentration on elliptical observation, mood and texture signals an almost complete rejection of narrative.
Ponderous, overwrought and more than a little pretentious, with a brooding self-seriousness that at times veers into camp.
There's a weird purity to the storytelling even at its untidiest, which enables Franco to remain true to the spirit of McCarthy's vernacular lyricism.
Where it really works is in Cage's bone-deep characterization of a man at war with himself, as tightly leashed as the badass bulldog that guards his house.
A journey of arduous physical challenges and incalculable spiritual rewards is evocatively rendered in this superb adaptation.
An utterly formulaic but sweet movie that does what a crowd-pleaser is meant to do.
Supermensch is very much a celebration. But Gordon comes across as a refreshingly candid man who feels no compulsion to varnish the truth.
movie_title: Supermensch: The Legend of Shep Gordon (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A bone-chilling genre piece about religious fanaticism taken to deadly extremes.
A minor-key film distinguished by fine performances from Toni Collette and Thomas Haden Church, and an unexpectedly poignant payoff.
An entertaining adaptation, delivering flavorful rewards in some sharp supporting turns that flank the central mother-daughter adversaries.
This sorry misfire will provide enjoyment only for rival television creatives invidiously rooting for Matthew Weiner to stumble.
This is a full-bodied characterization that will take McConaughey's already impressive career regeneration several steps further.

Olivier Assayas has made a distinctive and nuanced film about the much-chronicled post-1968 years of radical European politics, as well as providing droll insight into his self-discovery as an artist.
Standout performances from Dennis Quaid and Zac Efron and an intelligent script distinguish this drama from writer-director Ramin Bahrani.
It's neither unpredictable nor exactly fresh, but audiences willing to surrender to Susanne Bier's gently comic romance will find plenty of rewards.
The hot-button issue of public school reform gets unsubtle treatment in this pedestrian and insultingly tendentious drama.
Feisty girl + troubled young man + house full of ugly secrets = hackneyed horror movie you've seen a hundred times before, even if Jennifer Lawrence keeps it watchable.
movie_title: House at the End of the Street (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The redoubtable Michael Shannon leads a superb cast in Ariel Vromen's compelling portrait of New Jersey career criminal Richard Kuklinski.
It has hypnotic visual style and a dense, driving soundscape. But it's also too monotonous and thematically empty to be seriously provocative.
Vivid characterizations from Ralph Fiennes and Helena Bonham Carter are the highlights of Mike Newell's traditional retelling of the classic Dickens novel.
There's way more wit than weight in Martin McDonagh's second feature, but still much to enjoy.
Bradley Cooper and Jennifer Lawrence expand their range in David O. Russell's winning comedy romance about two people struggling to rebuild their lives.
Robert Redford makes a welcome return to double-duty as director and lead actor in this clear-eyed drama about a former Weather Underground radical forced to reconcile with the past.
In this spare, striking drama, Melissa Leo's unerringly contained performance provides shattering insight into a woman powerless to resist the destabilizing forces of her life.
A stiff central performance diminishes its emotional impact, but the visually alluring film's sensuality and tenderness give it a lingering spell.
Arguably the raunchiest, funniest and most enjoyably nonjudgmental American movie about selling sex since Boogie Nights, its obvious if considerably darker precursor.
Newcomer Tom O'Brien shows promise in this mellow drama about three buddies from small-town coastal Massachusetts.

While its catharsis is somewhat muted and its script uneven, this splendidly acted drama explores its themes with sensitivity, gentle humor and poignancy that will appeal in particular to older audiences.
[Shankman] succeeds in draining most of the fun from a vehicle that was all about the winking humor of its flagrant cheesiness.
Deadfall is slicker and more compelling than its overdetermined script has any right to expect.
In his first feature, David Chase returns to the New Jersey suburbs to cast a bittersweet glance back at the rock-fueled restlessness of the Sixties.
Barry Levinson gives folks another reason to stay out of the water in this queasy biological catastrophe thriller.
A 3D multistyle animated tribute to late Monty Python member Graham Chapman that falls short as biography but honors the spirit of the beloved British comedy troupe.
movie_title: A Liar's Autobiography - The Untrue Story of Monty Python's Graham Chapman (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The anomie of entitlement pushed to poisonous extremes is the basis of this provocation, which is as frustrating as it is intriguing.
The thematic points are made clearly, with well-sustained tension and no shortage of dramatic impact. It's just that it's all a bit obvious ...
A somber and striking drama that takes some wrong turns but features a charismatic performance from Ryan Gosling in the leanest and best of its three sections.
When it stops preaching, the film is on surer footing, even if for a drama in which peace hangs in the balance, the stakes never seem very high.
Further back on the evolutionary chain than the Flintstones, and also lagging in the comedy stakes, this sweet Stone Age clan nonetheless will captivate the youngsters.
Moving away from the literary costume dramas that have been their principal terrain for many years, the Taviani Brothers explore a fascinating encounter between theater and reality.
The filmmakers have made a smart, sobering movie that speculates with compelling detachment on how the abhorrent urge to take innocent lives might evolve.
An exhilarating history of the studio that spawned countless rock classics, not to mention a welcome reminder to aspiring musicians to step away from the laptop once in a while.
Does it sound patronizing to call a slice-of-life film about teenage Bronx graffiti artists adorable? It's not meant to.
Alex Gibney's docu-portrait of WikiLeaks is both a juicy chronicle of recent history and a provocative reflection on the role of secrecy in an instant-access world.
movie_title: We Steal Secrets: The Story Of Wikileaks (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Don't expect a rash of David Sedaris screen adaptations to be sparked by this bland effort.
Steve Coogan's performance is consistently amusing, but the poignant dimensions the director appears to be seeking don't quite come together.
Perhaps Green's chief accomplishment in this odd little gem of a movie is that he coaxes that mutual compassion out of the characters without having to put it into words.
And the Beat goes on, this time in a syncopated study that sheds light in particular on the young Allen Ginsberg.
While plot-wise it's a little slender, not to mention heavy on studied eccentricities, Jordan Vogt-Roberts' debut feature also has a generous share of rewards.
A provocative wakeup call that presents vital evidence in the ongoing global healthcare debate.

Caouette certainly knows how to manipulate images and sound, painting on a vibrantly textured, semi-experimental canvas. But aside from visual stimulation set to some cool music, none of the fictional stuff adds much.
Dakota Fanning and Elizabeth Olsen are wasted in veteran screenwriter Naomi Foner's underwhelming directing debut.
A warmly satisfying comedy about dissatisfied people seeking to escape from the personal prison of their mundane lives in soulless suburbia.
Over-plotted and at times incoherent but never dull, this is a stylishly designed, highly entertaining bloodbath full of offbeat comedy and inspired musical moments.
The film outstays its welcome and is more than a little too knowing in its manipulation of standard audience expectations for the genre.
Frakes, who reinvigorated the Star Trek franchise with First Contact, fails to pump the same energy into this tube-to-screen transfer.
Scores more hits than misses.
A thoughtful, melancholy story of love, loss, pain, betrayal and the lingering after-effects of tragedy.
The Chronicles of Riddick may not quite gain entry to the hallowed pantheon of interstellar cheese of a Battlefield Earth, but it's not far behind.
A stunningly crafted work from first-time feature director Nicole Kassell.
Material that might have turned to standard dysfunctional family treacle in other hands is given stirring poignancy, warmth and emotional insight.

While it's somewhat bloated and intermittently dull at two hours-plus, the polished visual treatment and Caviezel's sober performance lift this above the standard network movie-of-the-week level that might otherwise have been its natural domain.
McKinney's cheerfully cynical zealousness and de Medeiros' waiflike quality provide some pleasures, but the film's chief glory is Rossellini's inspired, imperiously vampy turn.
movie_title: The Saddest Music in the World (2004)

movie_review_blurb: As she did in Freaky Friday, Lohan displays plenty of charm, verve and deft comic timing as she switches between innocence and craftiness.
Salvatores' classically illustrative treatment should open arthouse doors for the visually sumptuous production.
movie_title: I'm Not Scared (Io non ho paura) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A thoroughly charming performer with a bracing freshness about her that carries the film, [Hathaway] establishes credible chemistry with Brit thesp Dancy.

In all departments, Collette is far more nuanced, her timing sharper and her comic skills more inventive than her co-star's nonetheless vivacious, appealing performance, but the camaraderie between the two is infectious.
Superficial but entertaining.

This gritty genre piece about four men whose paths intertwine largely overcomes key cast weaknesses to deliver a jazzy, darkly textured rendering of the ghetto pulp of late African-American ex-con author Donald Goines.
Hampered by narrative incoherence, sluggish pacing and emotionally remote characters.
Despite being overlong and lumbered with some clunky broad humor, the sharply lensed film remains compelling, driven by the curiosity of seeing what the director will throw in next.
Utterly lacking in imagination or suspense, this inane effort is strictly for hardcore Argento cultists.
Marston's strikingly confident debut maintains an unblinking focus and sustains an almost unbearable level of tension.
Provides stimulating evidence of how thoroughly news can be skewed, political agendas served and a climate of fear created.
movie_title: Outfoxed: Rupert Murdoch's War on Journalism (2004)

movie_review_blurb: While not all the many arguments laid out are fully developed, the consistently fascinating material provides an uncommonly eloquent, provocative statement against globalization that's sure to stimulate thinking audiences.
While the drama's emotional observations could have been brought together more cohesively, its sorrowful mood resonates beyond the end credits, allowing key themes to continue to gel.
The writer-director's story sense is far too distracted, clouding the film's themes and even its basic plotline and allowing only the most glancing insights into its characters.

The Polar Express may succeed via the motion-capture process in replicating human movement by digitalizing the performances of live actors, but it fails to capture the subtlety of facial expressions or to fabricate sympathetic, evocative figures.
While the cast is uneven, Mackie and Robinson both create sensitive, sympathetic characters.
Skillfully acted, handsomely crafted frock piece toys cleverly with gender confusion and sexual identity.
While the drama is emotionally harrowing it's also riveting, profoundly affecting and observed with a real generosity of spirit.

A one-joke affair about conjoined twins that feels like it bypassed the scripting stage and was filmed directly from the pitch, the comedy remains resoundingly unfunny despite the strained efforts of stars Matt Damon and Greg Kinnear.
Clever but distancing, this existential comedy bounces along on the backs of its tasty cast, witty writing and stylistic verve.
There's something to be said for the consistency of Waters' defiantly unrefined style, not to mention a certain naive charm in the '50s B-movie playfulness.
This feels like short film material stretched exasperatingly thin but nonetheless casts a certain sad spell, graced by moments of droll observational humor.
Awkwardly juggles screwball and noir elements with macabre black comedy in a mix that calls for a far lighter, more stylish touch than the obvious one at work here.
A brooding, original drama that commands attention.
A boldly intriguing if not entirely satisfying subversion of American family values.
Recalling the ultra-earnest granola movies of Sundances past, Evergreen has so many requisite ingredients it's like a humorless parody.
Plays like a Lifetime movie on estrogen overdose, barely held together by a script that should have been tossed out with the kitty litter.
While it's overlong and unhurried, the film is consistently absorbing, intelligent and often bitterly funny in its own subdued way.

Despite occasional affecting moments and nuanced performances from Emile Hirsch and Sigourney Weaver, the film sways awkwardly back and forth between prickly humor and pathos, rarely ringing true in either register.
Kesselman's thin script generally is funniest when it's riffing on Jewish stereotypes and goyish bigotry.
Roberts gives the character her regular mix of high spirits and vulnerability, which never fully gels with the idealistic, savvy woman.
A film substantially lacking in personality, energy, magic and humor.
Malkovich's elegantly malicious performance gives Ripley's Game a magnetic center.

While staccato dialogue and edgy confrontations have always been the wordsmith's forte, the precision-tooled mechanics of an elaborate crime caper have not, and the physical direction here could use some muscle.
... its treacly mix of emotional manipulation and klutzy comedy will make it hard to digest for most audiences.
Cleverly juggling the elements and encounters of a simple thriller scenario by using multiple viewpoints and a domino effect to create different destinies...
Despite Bellucci's strong presence in a role with little dialogue, the central character never really comes alive in any way interesting enough to give her ordeal much genuine pathos.
Dazzles with a heady atmosphere of romantic melancholy and ravishing visuals ... but neglects to construct the kind of dramatic complexity to provide any lasting emotional resonance.
A dramatically minimalist, emotionally rich saga.
An eccentric modern-day fairy tale set against magnificent rural landscapes.
Toilet humor is the last resort of a desperate director.
Distinguished by its quiet, intelligent, admirably restrained approach and by two finely wrought performances from Harris and Marcia Gay Harden in the leading roles.
Schnabel has fashioned a dense, emotionally satisfying portrait of a man, a time and a place.
A compelling story of love and obsession...
There's a light touch in evidence, balancing the bleakness with odd lyrical moments and unexpected humor.
A cogent human drama.
A stylish cast and some clever scripting solutions help Chicago make the transition from stage to screen with considerable appeal intact.

Character-driven pic provides strong opportunities for a fine ensemble of actors and for Lee, maintaining his signature style, to depart from his regular ethnic territory ... and to deliver one of his more interesting recent films.
An affable but undernourished romantic comedy that fails to match the freshness of the actress-producer and writer's previous collaboration, Miss Congeniality.
A delightful experience.
Flavorless blender-mix of dance movie cliches draws from the stagnant well of everything from Flashdance to Save the Last Dance.
An enjoyable throwback to the occult psychological horror-thrillers of the late 1970s.
The sweet-natured outsider fantasy neither skimps on nor overplays its sentimentality.
A thoroughly entertaining comedy about love, lawyers and fat divorce settlements.
A subject more suited to docu treatment.
A bland romance that suffers from choppy development, dramatic overload and dearth of personality.
A misconceived comedy that despite a warmly empathetic performance from Kathy Bates, never makes its characters' unorthodox chemistry gel.
The drama's uncompromising nature and, above all, Charlize Theron's powerful, physically astonishing performance should attract the kind of critical attention necessary to mine the specialized niche.
The screenplay is taut and intelligent, sizzling with enough sharp dialogue and dark humor to coast over its flaws.

This overlong and unwieldy grab-bag of vintage monster-movie elements starts intriguingly as a snowbound deep-woods chiller, but gradually dissolves into a mess of other-worldly invasion and military counter-offensive.
In Cradle 2 the Grave, producer Joel Silver returns with gusto to the mix of martial arts action and urban attitude that proved so potent in Romeo Must Die.
Story of a middle-aged man preparing to undergo a sex change and of the woman who slowly comes to accept him is rendered with sincerity and restraint by director Jane Anderson.
A stylish, compelling crime caper full of smoothly navigated plot twists.
A Thanksgiving family reunion comedy that sparkles with acerbic wit, original characters and genuine heart.
Refreshingly devoid of flashiness or artificially pumped-up action, this gripping, well-constructed police thriller ... showcases a tightly controlled performance from Kurt Russell.
As maudlin and monotone as the whiny alt-rock that drenches its overly articulated emotional disclosures.

While the mockumentary formula is showing signs of strain, the gifted repertory company again creates an amusing gallery of incisively observed characters, riffing off each other with enjoyment levels that frequently prove contagious.

Full of surprising warmth and charm, unexpected plot turns and droll characters that bounce off each other in refreshing ways, this genre-defying Columbia pickup may struggle to overcome its lack of an obvious marketing handle.
John Travolta and Scarlett Johansson make this tale of misfits thrown together an agreeable enough time-passer despite newcomer Shainee Gabel's flowery dialogue and pedestrian direction.
movie_title: A Love Song for Bobby Long (2004)

movie_review_blurb: While the director's penchant for extended silences and stagy character positioning make it all seem rather studied, the drama nonetheless is compellingly unsettling.
A massive undertaking and an accomplished piece of filmmaking in a solid tradition of intelligent, meticulous literary adaptations.

Combines original vision, a drop-dead command of the medium and a successful marriage between a dazzling, kinetic techno-show and a complex, credible portrait of the out-of-control relationship between the crime's two schoolgirl perpetrators.
An accomplished marriage of elaborate style and content.
Jia creates some poignant images to convey key transitions in the characters' lives.
Kopple's discreet, quietly revelatory style creates a fine balance between public and private personae that veers more pointedly toward the personal in an incongruous but fascinating coda.
Stays true to the source material while standing on its own as a fully reimagined movie.
In its present form, however, the film's merits are compromised by structural and conceptual flaws.
As thoroughly generic as its title.
The whimsical ugly-duckling fable becomes more uneven as it proceeds, straining too hard to manufacture its quirky charms.
[The film is] better when it acquires a melancholy strain than in the early, more comic action
movie_title: The Postmodern Life of My Aunt (Yi ma de hou xian dai sheng huo) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A drama that steadily succumbs to self-conscious artiness, drunk on its own sense of contrived poetry and cloudy existential reflection.
Regardless of the liberties taken, there was an integrity and character-complexity to the 2005 release that's missing from this glossier biopic.
Naggingly thin and unlikely to withstand much theatrical scrutiny.
Coming during a period in which the collision of politics and gay rights has created perhaps unprecedented sparks, Poster Boy is a flawed but absorbing drama.
The central subject is such a volatile, complex eccentric and his establishment is such a uniquely New York institution that the charming character study should land quality cable slots.
Slender but appealing.
This drama about a shocking reality from recent history balances a light touch with searing intensity and a sense of moral outrage.
While Alba shows several variations on the classic pout, she often seems more bored than scared...
Offers more mild amusement than outright laughs...
An amusingly caustic, straight-up serving of film noir staples spiced with star charisma.
A mildly diverting farcical caper.
Tone and atmosphere mirror subject to perfection in Kiyoshi Kurosawa's hypnotic trip into the lower depths of the human mind.
[A] bold, inventive, sustained adrenaline rush of a movie...
It's depressing to see a deluxe cast wasted on such by-the-numbers material.
All this unrelenting bleakness would be fine if it went someplace interesting, but the film's themes never coalesce into anything beyond basic existential angst.
movie_title: Code Unknown (Code inconnu: Récit incomplet de divers voyages) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: Very much a mood piece, the film's deft balance of humor and poignancy makes it both a pleasurable and melancholy experience.

The accomplished filmmaker and her able cast still manage to provide rewards in the delicacy with which they sketch the way a woman in a marriage neither happy nor unhappy drifts into an affair, and persists despite clear indications of extreme danger.

The intimately personal chronicle is more impressive for Famiglietti's disarming self-exposure than for any fully formed cinematic style or consistency of tone, but the modest production has a genuine, warm spirit.
This numbing barrage of demolition humor scores only a modest laugh count.
Pacino is at least dynamic, something harder to say about the women in the cast.
movie_title: William Shakespeare's The Merchant of Venice (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Original in every sense, this often difficult film about family, relationships, sexual politics, spiritual questing, faith and obsession further explores the director's abiding fascinations in excitingly unconventional terms.
Devilishly inventive and so far out there it's almost off the scale.
Provides powerful drama thanks to its trenchant core story and harrowing re-creation of the brutal chaos of war.
Hallstrom's film could have used more dramatic muscle but is nonetheless a touching, old-fashioned charmer that ultimately satisfies.
A turgid erotic thriller that plays like Zalman King-meets-vintage Brian De Palma without the latter's wit or style.
"Elizabeth" is superior historical soap opera that shrewdly sidesteps all the cliches of British costume drama with its bold, often modern approach.
Richly human in focus, the drama steadily cranks up its political and emotional charge, poignantly viewing its themes through the eyes of two 11-year-old boys.
The emotionless, overwrought movie's lack of psychological depth or dramatic verisimilitude makes the boy's grim odyssey a curiously remote and unshocking horror show.
movie_title: The Heart Is Deceitful Above All Things (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Ingram illustrates how gay bars function as oases of acceptance and alternative families for his good-humored, enduring subjects.
Somewhat haphazardly organized yet fascinatingly detailed and enriched by the candor and dignity of its shockingly deprived interview subjects.
While the film is lazily directed, it strikes an agreeable balance of wry humor and the soulful observation of lives lived in the shadow of everyone else's achievements.
Starts out bracingly but gradually loses focus.
Docu moves at a snappy pace, threading together recent interview material with a treasure trove of vintage footage.
movie_title: Lipstick & Dynamite: The First Ladies of Wrestling (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Feels false and platitudinous -- a calculated crowd-pleaser that, despite being an original story, plays like a poorly condensed novel with a scripter unable to make choices.
Bracingly twisted.
Story of a still-grieving widower and his two troubled teenage sons is distinguished by its emotional integrity, sustained mood of aching melancholy and superbly understated performances.
The venture's extreme unevenness will make it commercially viable mainly as a DVD curio.

Less burdened by earnest intentions than other indie examinations of Asian-American women's experience, the film's appealing characters and amusing situations prevail over its general shortage of energy.
Gregg Araki delivers his most challenging and arguably most mature film.
A disarmingly silly confection.

Behind its slick veneer and the glibness of its preposterous premise and dark twists, there's a yawning absence of charm or substance in this London-set love triangle, as well as a lack of chemistry between its three leads.
Dramatically pallid and unconvincing.
Endowed with captivating simplicity, gentle humor, rich humanity and infectious generosity of spirit.
The story's conflicts between modern and traditional attitudes, family and independence feel like familiar fodder, and the pedestrian approach fails to inject much freshness into the material.
In the central role, Castellitto's powerfully focused performance manages to keep the complex drama grounded.
movie_title: L' Ora di Religione (Il Sorriso di Mia Madre) (The Religion Hour) (My Mother's Smile) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: A richly textured drama with an angry poetic edge that gets inside the obsessive subculture of New York graffiti artists.
The tireless volley of ideas and inventions make this a delight that should connect with kids and adults in both dubbed and original-language versions.

Swanberg moves into more conventional though quite satisfying territory with a personal exploration of the anticipation and anxieties encountered on the road to maternity.
Every single development in the Wood family's plot trajectory is telegraphed, and these actors deserve to be in a less emotionally bogus drama.
A bitterly divisive strike in Margaret Thatcher's Britain fosters an unlikely union of solidarity between embattled mineworkers and militant gays in this rousing true story.
The Case Against 8 remains a powerful advocacy film as well as one of historical record.
Despite threatening to overload on melancholia, the modest film maintains emotional integrity through to its final note of hope.
While the film is absorbing and not without pathos, there's insufficient insight or shape to the screenplay, which drifts between Hollis and Jacob without building momentum.
While the film ultimately is not as satisfying as it promises to be for much of the duration, it remains bracingly creepy and off-kilter.
Mickle's bracing sense of style and cinematographer Ryan Samul's moody visuals keep it gripping until the final bullet is fired.

Funny and frank in its observations, the film is a delightful snapshot of female friendship at that age, from the giddy highs to the melancholy funks, from the sustaining bonds to the jealousies and stinging betrayals.
An absorbing if not quite definitive patchwork of the life and legacy of an unorthodox artist.

There's neither topicality nor bite in this bland pseudo-thriller, which lathers on composer H. Scott Salinas' high-suspense score like shower gel after sweaty sex, yet rarely musters an ounce of genuine tension.
The slender, seemingly autobiographical film has its share of neurotic charms and funny one-liners, but it's too tentative about digging into its identity conflicts -- sexual or cultural.

Conventional narrative detail is certainly not a requirement, and many directors can sustain a movie based on little more than suggestion and mood. But Partisan begins to feel like a short film treatment stretched beyond its limits.
A lovingly assembled appreciation of the key transitional album in the late artist's career.
movie_title: Michael Jackson's Journey From Motown to Off the Wall (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The balance of humanistic and ethnographic filmmaking with poignant, often seemingly unscripted drama has many rewards.
A harsh but gripping study in uncontrolled male aggression.
Watchable leads elevate a downbeat story that takes its time to ignite.
The movie succeeds on its own quiet terms, binding the three parts together with assurance and tonal consistency to cast a lingering spell.

Even if the film could be accused of lacking subtlety and overloading on whimsy, it spreads a sobering message in a lucid story that remains visually alive and inventive throughout -- its aesthetic keeps constantly shifting yet remains fluid.
movie_title: Boy and the World (O Menino e o Mundo) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Berg does paper illuminating personal observations throughout, before landing a satisfying emotional punch at the end.
Its freeform riffs on highs and lows from the musician's life are a fine example of structure emulating the ever-evolving style of an artist defined by unrelenting experimentation.
[A] numbingly idiotic vampire yakuza tale.
The film's payoff more than compensates for a lumbering setup, laden with cloying voiceover narration and strained whimsy.
Not the most imaginative or politically trenchant retelling, but entertaining and at times quite moving.
Driven by a powerfully internalized performance from Dolores Fonzi as the title character, Paulina eschews straightforward answers in favor of questioning observation.

What makes the transfixing film so effective is that the director refuses to portray them simplistically, as misunderstood angels, and she has enough trust in her audience to leave the drama's implicit feminism unstated.
While it's well acted and has strong moments on a scene-by-scene basis, the film lacks an emotional center, keeping the impact cool and diffuse where it should be affecting.

While admirers of the director's work might sit still for the glacial pacing, the overlong film becomes steadily less involving after a promising setup, trading mystery for a sentimental vein fed by its sudsy romantic score.
movie_title: Journey To The Shore (Kishibe No Tabi) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This one is straight out of the old-school Sundance manual. Still, there's enough warmth, humor and heart in the very slick package, not to mention a gaggle of accomplished and well-cast actors ...
This absorbing docu-drama hybrid works equally well as detached case study and revealing performance piece.
A warmly satisfying screen translation of a work by an author who has rarely been served well on film.
A rite-of-passage romance wrapped in a let's-make-a-band scenario, the disarming film colors its social realism with the kind of wish-fulfillment fantasy often found in a four-minute music video.
If the movie is over-reliant on slo-mo, voiceover and almost wall-to-wall music to drive scenes, its silky blend of lyricism with urban grit marks it as a promising debut.
[Baskin] offers little in the way of narrative involvement or scares but doesn't stint on sustained, stylized revulsion.

Anvari deftly builds and sustains tension throughout, crafting a horror movie that respects genre conventions (right down to the safe/not safe ending), while firmly establishing its own distinctive identity.
Any comment on the total commitment of Tim Roth's performance as a palliative care worker in Chronic seems inadequate to describe the intense degree to which the actor loses himself.
The story of Perkins' collaboration and friendship with Wolfe remains stubbornly resistant both to drama and emotion.

The Patriarch aims for classical screen storytelling, but the result, while entertaining for a time, becomes clunky and predictable, its sentimentality amplified by awkward incorporation of songs into the lush score.

Nichols' screenplay expertly peels away exposition and drops us in a story already in motion, with scenes set up to infer one situation only to reveal another via meticulously parceled out fragments of information.
Acutely observed and graced with equal parts humor and honest feeling.
Jia Zhang-ke's... exploration of change, loss and regret has never felt more personal than in Mountains May Depart.
movie_title: Mountains May Depart (Shan he gu ren) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Brooks generally is so bewitched by her characters' opacity that they remain frustratingly remote, even in the rare moments when they open up, diminishing the sorrow of the final-act tragedy.
The strained humor of straight dudes exhibiting girlfriend behavior is a long way from the unselfconscious charms of, say, the Magic Mike movies.
An at-risk youth movie we've seen many times before in more authentic versions.
A tribute made all the more affecting by its quiet, contemplative approach.

First-time writer-director Miles Joris-Peyrafitte's plotting could be more muscular, but the film shades its confused tangle of friendship, love and desire with atmosphere, intimacy and a lingering sense of outsider yearning.

With a simple eloquence that never gets preachy, it makes the point that the gay marriage movement was driven by the white middle class, while the marginalized transgender community remains largely unrepresented.
A deceptively small movie that sneaks up and slays you with its emotional authenticity.

The imbecilic charms of a character that began as TV sketch material are too often misplaced in this wildly over-plotted, under-energized action comedy, plumped to bursting point with celebrity cameos.
A delectable riff on transformation, desire and sexuality that blends the heightened reality of melodrama with mischievous humor and an understated strain of Hitchcockian suspense.
A movie that initially struggles to define what it wants to be, but gets there eventually.
It's involving but seldom deeply affecting, with the core drama continually shoved aside to examine more commonplace matters of parenting, abandonment and broken families.
Robert Gustafsson has been called "the funniest man in Sweden." Meh. Must be an acquired taste.
movie_title: The 100-Year-Old Man Who Climbed Out the Window and Disappeared (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This tonally uncertain romance is both surprisingly conventional and tame.
A heady recap of Spandau Ballet's rise that becomes less insightful in tracking the group's demise and eventual comeback.
movie_title: Soul Boys Of The Western World (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A wonderfully alive behind-the-music chronicle that rescues two genuine mavericks from the footnotes of rock history.
The sensitively observed drama is distinguished by its structurally adventurous approach and the intimacy of its storytelling.
The story of a behavioral psychologist specializing in sexual surrogacy provides insight into intriguing characters for whom professional intimacy supplants personal relationships.
Despite its strong sense of place and a solid central performance from Nathan Phillips, Zak Hilditch's film is too blighted by the deja vu factor to stand out from the apocalyptic pack.
Intriguing stuff.

Anyone nostalgic for childhood dreams of transformation will find something to enjoy in an uplifting movie that invests warm sentiment in universal themes of loss and resilience, experience and maturity.

While Helen Mirren elevates the material with her usual aplomb and the events being depicted inevitably are stirring, this is a stodgy crusade-for-justice drama, directed and written with minimal flair.
Life doesn't deliver on its considerable promise.
A passionless trudge that lacks both sweep and psychological complexity.
Freeheld underwhelms even as it more or less delivers ...
A generous salute to the unfiltered firebrand whose impassioned outspokenness helped break institutional inaction during the AIDS crisis.
movie_title: Larry Kramer in Love and Anger (2015)

movie_review_blurb: [A] viscerally scary fantasy horror tale ...
While the film has infinite problems, casting is key among them.
movie_title: In the Name of My Daughter (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This is a smartly observed, understated biographical drama that sidesteps hagiography and treats its complex subject with integrity.
It's not uninteresting but too self-consciously arty to rank Decker as a mature filmmaking voice.
It also helps that Holmes, Jones and Duress, as well as the mainly non-actors in secondary roles, all inhabit their characters with real conviction.
While it's uneven, A Perfect Day builds to a nice melancholy conclusion.
Continuing the sad slump in Atom Egoyan's career after last year's The Captive, this plodding new drama is perhaps a shade or two less risible.
Could still benefit from some structural polish but a blast nonetheless.
Kaufman and Johnson create a vivid, dismally relatable world here, both droll and dreary, but fascinating precisely because of its numbing banality.
The future looks pretty but dull.
[A] strained though mildly enjoyable ensemble comedy.
This uneven but sweet bildungsroman is distinguished by its light tone and idiosyncratic handle on genre conventions.
Fort Tilden, the debut feature co-written and directed by Sarah-Violet Bliss and Charles Rogers, showcases a satirical voice so dyspeptic it's almost endearing.
If the movie remains safe, there's no questioning its integrity, or the balance of porcelain vulnerability and strength that Eddie Redmayne brings to the lead role.
The movie is well acted and mostly absorbing, but it spells out everything so painstakingly that there's zero room for subtext.
For filmed theater, this is about as immersive and immediate as it gets.

The intense, uncomfortable drama's downbeat nature is offset to a degree by the sensitivity of its observation, but the film serves primarily as a showcase for the emotionally raw lead performance of Rory Culkin.
While the unhurried pace is challenging for a film with relatively little narrative incident, it's a pleasure to put yourself in the hands of such a confident director.
The mix of limpid naturalism and lyricism that has often distinguished David Gordon Green's indie films slides into sentimentality -- or worse yet, whimsy -- in Manglehorn.
The reverential film takes itself far too seriously; it ends up being neither sufficiently inventive nor revisionist to surmount its archetypal cliches.
Equal parts ethnographic and poetic, this eloquent drama's stirring soulfulness is laced with the sorrow of cultural dislocation but also with lovely ripples of humor and even joy.
This is the kind of contemplative cinematheque piece that washes pleasurably over you, inviting the viewer to tune in or out, to free-associate or locate the subtle connections and recurring themes.
Hard to believe, but there was a time when the phrase 'starring Vin Diesel!' was more of a promise than a threat.
Wham, bam, thank you Liam! Neeson is a man on fire: an unstoppable army of one scrapping and shooting his way around the City of Love. Both reprehensible and enjoyable in roughly equal measure.
A History of Violence ranks high on the Cronenberg scale as one of his more disturbing forays into depravity.
As Ryer (Burns)...says, 'We have to make sure this never happens again.' We beg you.
Demme never loses sense of his destination and, more the point, is always willing to take a detour, convinced that something unexpected and exhilarating is available at the end of the road.
The pleasure that these two men share in one another's company, both as characters and performers, radiates through every frame.
This picture remains blissfully aloft, borne by engaging actors and a warm heart.
In the end, what resonates is the fragile yet unfailing grace of the human spirit embodied by Weber's subjects.
The film is probably best characterized by a comment from a review quoted in the DVD commentary by Kurt Russell: 'Absolutely fabulous and terminally hip.'
A gleeful amalgam of hijinks and heroism.
movie_title: I See a Dark Stranger (The Adventuress) (1947)

movie_review_blurb: Melville remained, in all his work and particularly his policiers, a classicist of calamity, a master of transforming the chaos of criminality into a form as refined as a sonnet or a minuet.
Siodmak captures both the romance and world-weariness of the post-WWII film noir with consummate skill.
A daffy romp.
movie_title: Drole de Drame (Bizarre Bizarre) (Drôle de drame ou L'étrange aventure du Docteur Molyneux) (1939)

movie_review_blurb: The Man Who Laughs demonstrates that, however much we gained with sound, we lost opportunities that arise when storytelling prioritizes vision.
While some may be put off by Preminger's glossy presentation of the idle rich, his direction in Bonjour Tristesse engages the mind while it stimulates the senses.
Carpenter had little time or money to meander off the point, so it possesses an expositional leanness that would not stand the loss or a single scene.
The wealth of detail about gay life at the time and the often adverse public perception of homosexual behavior ensures Victim's lasting fascination as a social document.
Suffice to say, you're best off forgetting this sorry mess ever happened.
Already an indie fan favourite thanks to the no-budget romp Funny Ha Ha, director Andrew Bujalski here slays the sophomore slump with another scruffy but bang-on look at life in the slow lane.
With Brand Upon the Brain! filmmaker Guy Maddin proves he's just like the rest of us.
A cloying, tween-oriented confection that clearly doesn't think much of its target audience.

More of a Valentine to the original than a recycled cash-grab.
No matter who's responsible, the movie is a dud -- one so sped-up and illogical, it's almost painful to sit through.
[A lame] attempt to cash in on the same ghost-in-the-machine craze that begat The Ring, The Grudge and Phone.
Further proof that those fueling the Hollywood remake machine are the ones who could really stand to have their vision restored.
The phrase 'It is what it is' was practically invented for movies such as High School Musical 3: Senior Year.
A more accurate title would have been The Annoying Flashbacks of Molly Hartley, or Molly Hartley's Possibly Genetic Mental Disorder or even Molly Hartley's Series of Super-Sucky Unfortunate Events.

The lives of nine assorted down-and-outers converge in frequently funny and sometimes tragic ways, giving Yates a chance to put his own spin on a template perfected decades ago by Robert Altman and reinvigorated in recent years by P.T. Anderson.
Deserves to die a quick death.
A chilly and efficient thriller.
